After all of the hype I had created for my friends, the second trip was a little underwhelming. It was a Saturday night and the place super packed even for its own high standards but it tasted like the pizza had been sitting out for a while. The sauce quantity was also lacking this time so please keep up the consistency and I'll never cheat on you guys with another deep dish establishment.

This pizza looked and smelled so good when it arrived to the table I was sharing with a lesser colleague.  The server (I believe her name was Sam) gave us each a huge greasy piece and said enjoy.   I enjoyed the first bite but then my stomach starting turning partly through my meal!  I am sensitive to dairy, but figured a slice wouldn't hurt.  I landed myself on the bathroom floor for the next 48 hours and have no one to blame by myself.

Good Chicago deep dish pizza, our waiter was great about explaining the menu and wait time for a deep dish pizza which takes 45 mins to bake.  The floors were extremely sticky, they said the floors had just been refinished but not sure if that was the case or they just aren't cleaned regularly.  I'd return for this pizza if in town.

I do like Lou's... I'm still on the quest for my favorite pizza and I could eat pizza everyday! Lot's of competition out there as well as many types of taste buds.  I'm not a huge sausage fan so maybe that's the 4**** reason.  (That's what they ordered.)   It is a really good place and if you've never been... do give them a try.  It does get really busy and a long wait so get here when they open.  Friendly and competent service. Good wings and I love the atmosphere... a very warm feeling restaurant.

There was nothing deep or good about this Pizza. Great service and staff though. The wait is ridiculous, plus 20 minutes once seated for your order. I expected a traditional deep dish, but was informed by the manager that thats their signature deep dish style compared to the other popular deep dish styles around. After the long wait we were super hungry and ordered the soup of the day, which far exceeded my expectations than the main dish of the house. For me the pizza lacked flavor and was not worth the wait. Willing to give it another shot as it was a super busy night!

Anytime I'm in a new city I like to try it's pizza, and this did not disappoint. Great deep dish pizza, with gluten free options if necessary. The only downside is the long wait, but because the pizza is made to order, it is to be expected with deep dish pizza. I would recommend leaving at least an hour and a half if ordering deep dish.
Had the classic deep dish. Buttery crust was great. Plenty of sausage and cheese. Pizza was well worth the wait.

First time here on vacation with my husband, recommended by our hotel concierge and it's the best Chicago pizza ever! I'm back in California and have been dreaming about it since! My husband and I had the bruschetta appetizer and made our own pizza. We about licked our plates, long wait but so worth it, all the flavors in every bite! I wish they were in California

Hey, it's Chicago Deep Dish Pizza at it's finest. I love Lou Malnati's and have been there countless times.  The sausage deep dish pizza is a classic, and one I gladly recommend to people visiting Chicago who want to try those "Chicago-Style" pizzas that they've heard about. I cannot think a bad word to say about Lou Malnati's, and I doubt that anyone can. It's good eating that will satisfy any lover of deep dish pizza.

Best pizza in Chicago. A hundred times better than giordano's. The art of pizza is decent, but not on the same level as Lou's. If you're in Chicago and want to try Chicago style deep dish, this is the first place you should go.
Malnati's is simply the best deep dish Chicago Pizza. Great crust, delicious sauce, the whole package. Period.

Best.  Pizza.  In.  The.  World.   Bar none. For over 40 years I've had Lou Malnati's on my birthday, every year.  I've had it delivered to me when I lived in New York (New York style pizza?  Vomit...).  We have family members from all over the country that want one, and only one thing when they come to Chicago.  Lou's. It don't get no better.

So glad we have a LM in Lincoln Square, now. Same great pizza and salads. If you're in the mood for thick crust, Lou's does a great job. Nice dining room and outdoor patio. Usually easy parking on Lincoln.

The five stars is for the appetizer Pizza Chips and Trio of Dips. Fantastic!!  The hummus topped with giardiniera is the absolute BEST!!  Our deep dish classic was really good but pales compared to the app.

So this was pretty much the best pizza and bruschetta I'd ever had in my life...This was my first time having real Chicago pizza, and it did not disappoint! I loved the butter crust. It was like a pie crust, but not crumbly. On top of the crust was a thick layer of melty cheese. On top of the cheese was a layer of REAL tomato sauce (with some chunks) and sausage. You could taste the quality of ingredients! I was very impressed! And the bruschetta! Oh man...the tomato/onion/basil mixture was sitting on garlic bread slices! What was there NOT to like??? Made me wonder why I hadn't thought of that myself at home...the service was fantastic and we had a great time overall. If we are back in Chicago we will be returning and bringing all our friends and family with us.
It was good but have had better. Pizza did not come out very hot. Sauce not very thick. I did love the amount of cheese on it. The wings were great!

Always have great service and food!!  I mostly take out since I live close by and the ladies who handle the take out run that ship tight!!  I love how organized they are and how efficient.  I do have a wait sometimes beyond the time given to me when I order but it's to be expected on a busy night. I actually don't like thick crust but I love their think crust, the Lou!  And the salads are good, too ;)  Neighborhood favorite!!

With the hype, I expected this place to be great.  It was ok and it was no where near Giordanos or Leona's pizza.  Price wasn't bad, delivery was fast, guy on the phone was great.  Pizza is just ok, didn't love it like I thought I would.  I would eat it if it was there but I wouldn't go out of my way to order it again for myself.
Great Lou's location. What's neat is that you can pre-order pizza while you wait, so that everyone wins. Love the sausage

I had the worst experience of my life this weekend at this restaurant. I lost my wallet there and never got it back. I left the wallet at my seat but when I called them they did not cooperate at all. They were so rude over the phone that I had to go down there and ask about it. Still could not get it or any good response from them. They did not care a bit about asking their employees working at that shift if they knew something.
I'm it's malnatis, hello?? Welcome to Chicago.we get the deep dish they deliver to the door we have parties and love life. Can it get better than this? Maybe but this is pretty darn great too.

My friends got the fried calamari which I don't generally like but I had a couple pieces and it was crispy well-seasoned. I always get an appetizer here because if you're wanting deep dish it means you're hungry but deep dish takes 40 minutes.  We got The Lou instead of the classic since I'm a vegetarian. Despite not being stuffed with sausage, the two guys I was with said it was delicious and very flavorful. I really liked it as well. I'm not a deep dish fan but once in a while it hits the spot. The crust was thick and crispy which is great; I like it over thick bread-y pizza. I think we got the medium for three people and we couldn't finish it but we tried to.  We were seated promptly before the rush of dinner service on a Saturday and saw the entire door area filled with people who were waiting and eyeing our food. Get there by five!

This pizza was AMAZING. Oh my gosh, the butter crust MAKES this pizza what it is...so. damn. good. Me and my husband just visited Chicago and stopped here on a food tour we were attending with Chicago Food Planet. This was our FIRST stop and it was one of my favorite places! We just had the cheese version and only had one slice, but net time we make it back to Chicago, I would love to come back and try a pepperoni or sausage. I haven't tried any other deep dish pizza places in Chicago, but if you went here you will NOT be disappointed!

Best deep dish pizza in Chicago? I haven't tried them all but I think I'm convinced. The butter crust matched with the pizza is truly quite a combination! The calamari fritti is a must! Unexpectedly it was a little spicy, I got this for our children but they couldn't enjoy it The stuffed spinach bread with the crusty loaf we got as it was frequently recommended. It was good, nice crust but spectacular? Not really.  The atmosphere at d second floor seems spacious and modern. The downstairs where we were felt dark, old n moody... But one could call it traditional I guess.  Verdict: it would be gluttony to have this regularly, but when friend come over, this is d place to go!
The service was great. Pizza was very good. We had bruschetta as an appetizer and it was really good as well. Definitely worth a visit.

Great spot for visitors, locals and anyone looking for some good food. I have bought this food for work catering and have brought friends and family here. The thin crust is my favorite, the crust is so buttery and delicious! I also appreciate that the chain puts their calorie counts on their menu.
The line was long but totally worth it!  BY FAR, the best buffalo wings we've ever had.  The deep dish pizza is awesome.  We're only here 3 days and we want to go back again before we leave town.

They do a good job of getting you to pre-order your pizza while you wait for a table. One would assume this means hot pizza. After waiting an hour and fifteen minutes we got a cold pizza. Our server told us he'd see what he could do, then returned five minutes later saying they'd taken the pizza off the bill. Okay, but the pizza was still cold. We asked that they maybe heat the pizza, which they did, and when it was warmed, it tasted alright. Wouldn't go back as it wasn't exactly stellar, even for free pizza. The house salad was meh.

Yummy pizza, salad and beverages we had delivered for our staff and it was hot, offer rewards for return customers and delivery service has been accurate and hot. Thin crust the most loved here with authentic sauce and all the fixin's for  a great lunch.When pizza is good it does not take a lot of words to express it. we will be back.
The pizza is good, however I perfer UNO's pizza. Though I love their buffalo wings, salads and cookie sundae...I usually go to the location on State st.

I went here and got a small deep dish pizza. The crew was very nice, ordering easy, but... I was not happy with the finished product. - My pizza was barely luke warm. Maybe because it was smaller than the rest? The larger ones didn't seem to be an issue.
Really love the Chicago Classic with Sausage.  Very tender calamari and always like the bruschetta.  Order your pizza while waiting for seats!

There is a lot of discussion as to which pizza is superior - Lou Malnati's or Pequod's. Having now eaten at both, I would give the edge to Pequod's for the ambiance and a slightly superior pie. We got a small Lou's Classic, which is the perfect amount for two people. I really like the sweetness of the tomatoes, which balance out the sausage. The crust and cheese aren't so crispy, which I don't prefer but can still enjoy.  The atmosphere is a nicer sit-down, but a little touristy for me. I would rather spend my time at Pequods, but if you can only choose one you won't miss out either way.

My friend and I where visiting Chicago, decided to go here after reading reviews online. The restaurant is run like a spaghetti factory style chain. You are rushed through with no personalized service. The staff where nice but seemed over worked. They where constantly running around not spending any time with you. Revived the calamari which was excellent. The pizza however took 45 min to arrive as advertised. While eating the pizza a sharp shard of metal was found In the pizza the waitress and manager both knew where it came from. They both seemed as if this has happened before. The manager did offer to take of the food but not the drinks that was a total of $14. Luckily no one digested the metal shards from the cleaning brush. Totally disappointed with this restaurant.
Very good pizza. Tried the new location in suburban Flossmoor.

Amazing experience at Lou's. It was a wet and cold day yesterday but we found comfort and delicious food at Lou's. You should trust all the hype about this. The service was excellent - shout out to Anna! We ordered a salad (so we wouldn't feel too badly about ourselves), a small deep dish with sausage and spinach, and a pepperoni with peppers thin crust pizza. Everything was delicious, including the salad. I live in New York and love New York style pizza but after visiting Lou's I'm now questioning my loyalty...

The deep dish at this location was over-the-top and yet managed to be entirely forgettable. One does not simply slap a ton of red sauce onto some dough and call it a deep-dish. The other Loop location does a far better deep-dish.
This was my first time at Lou's and I was not disappointed! The deep dish pizza was really good. Not too stuffed. And our dessert Tre dolci was just as amazing as well!

Came here 1130 on a Saturday and it was half empty. Definitely come early because when we were done at 1230, there was a long wait outside.  It takes 40 minutes for them to make the pizza. We ordered the Chicago classic which was delicious. It's not going to blow your mind, so don't have sky high expectations when you come here. The small was more than enough food for the 2 of us, so don't order more than that because the portions are large and you're going to end up with a lot of leftovers I personally liked the pizza more than pequods because it wasn't as greasy, and the meat was spread more evenly throughout the pizza. It doesn't have that burnt crispiness that pequods had, but that's based on your preference. It's definitely a more touristy destination than other deep dish pizza places, but it still delivers a solid pizza.
Really good deep dish pizza. I've loved it since the location in lincolnwood was the only one

Quick trip to Chicago with the Lovely wife. The weather did not treat us right, it was a wet and cold weekend, but we were very lucky to be seated immediately as we arrived. Ordered the Malnati's Chicago Classic, fried calamari, and spicy wings...Great pizza, love that buttery crust, well balanced combination of quality ingredients, the calamari was fried to perfection, not chewy at all, the wings were surprisingly good for a pizza place, our waiter was attentive and even paired my pizza with a nice cold beer..a young gentlemen (sorry,but forgot your name). The whole experience was great except that the music was a little on the loud side. One recommendation: if you are a party of 2, and  you are going to order more than one dish, ask not to be seated in a small table, we had to be moved to a larger table, the small table couldn't accommodate 3 dishes + our drinks

My 2nd time here. And I have to seat I wish I went to Pizanos. The veggie deep dish was bland, the crust was a bit doughy/not crispy. The mahlnatis special was good but the crust was too hard on the edges and doughy in the middle. Hmmmmmm
Great pizza.  Very busy but worth the wait.  Decor is a little dated and could use a refresh but it is really just about the pizza.

Honestly, I don't know what luck I had coming here when I did because my partner and I got seated right away, no wait, around 5 pm on a Saturday! There is always a great debate as to which place has the best deep dish in the city. In my opinion, Lou's classic deep dish is just the perfect melange of cheese, sauce, sausage, and a delicious buttery crust. The buttery crust seems to be a point of contention but I would say that it is what makes Lou's better than the rest. Beyond the delicious pizza, the three cheese bread here is a great appetizer to munch on while you wait for your pizza. The service here is just great. Our server was friendly and very accommodating. The most annoying thing that you might run into here is the wait to get a table. Basically, when we left, there was a line around the street corner, which is pretty crazy. If this is your only time visiting Chicago, it probably is worth the wait. Otherwise, I would highly suggest coming at an off-time before the dinner rush or just take out.

People always ask me where to go for Chicago deep dish pizza, and I always recommend Lou Malnatis.  If you're vegetarian, go for The Lou, otherwise, definitely try the pepperoni (which can be on the spicy side) or order sausage.  There is 2 ways to order sausage at Lou Malnatis, so make sure you know what you are getting into.  If you order sausage, it will come as a giant sheet of sausage as an entire layer of the pizza.  If you tell them easy sausage, it will come in the more traditional way of having pieces of sausage sprinkled on top of the pie.  You can't go wrong with either, just a matter of personal preference.  Either way, this is my hands down favorite place to go for authentic Chicago Deep Dish pizza.
Wow best deep dish pizza in Chicago. Can't wait to go back to Chicago and taste it again. The ingredients so fresh, the salsa oh wowww so good

I was in Chicago for a night on business and came here with co-workers. They all were saying that Lou Malnati's is better than Giordano's. I personally like Giordano's more as my last visit to Lou Malnati's wasn't great.   As I was told that they don't take a reservation, we came here around 4:30pm and sat at the bar until other folks arrived.  We told the staff that we wanted to have a table at 5pm, and they were able to accommodate our request. The staff called us and took us to the table where was on the second floor.  We first started off appetizers: Malnati salad, mozzarella stick, buffalo wings, and calamari. Malnati salad was very delicious! It wasn't too heavy, so I could eat it all. Salad dressing was perfectly matches to the salad. Loved it.  Mozzarella stick was okay. Nothing special. I didn't eat wings or calamari.  For pizza, we ordered Large The Malnati Chicago Classic and The "Lou" with pepperoni. We ordered right after we ordered appetizer, so our pizza came a little after we finished our appetizers.  The Lou which I had last time wasn't great, but I had with crustless and personal size, so I was hoping this time was better, but no. It was the same. I didn't like it. On the other hand, The Malnati Chicago Classis tasted good which was good surprise. I wish I knew that at the first time. It had chunk of tomatoes and very flavorful.  When we were leaving, there were so many groups waiting to be seated. I'm glad we came here early enough, so we didn't have to wait! The staff was nice, and the service was good. I'm not a big fan of pizza, but Chicago pizza is better than regular pizza personally. I may come back if others want to come.

I am updating my review of Lou Malnati's Pizzeria because the manager personally reached out to me to ask about my experience.  The manager was very apologetic and let me know my experience was atypical of what the restaurant sets out to achieve.  He asked if there was anything he could do to help.  He offered me a refund but I told him I was willing to try it again since the reason I chose it was based off recommendations and feedback.  Also, they obviously care about their customers.  He offered to pay for my second pizza and asked me to try the deep dish.  I was supposed to go back Friday night since I was still in town but was unable due to an unscheduled business dinner. I was very impressed with how they handled my experience and what they offered to make it right.  I go to Chicago at least once a quarter and will retry the pizza.
Their lunch special has went from no beverage included to $11 from $9 within a year.

The Lou Malnati Classic with homemade sausage to me is deep dish pizza perfection.  I live in New York but the moment I return to Chicago I will be eating another one.  I don't care how long the line is (which is usually long at dinner time).

Over the years there has been a TON of hype about Chicago style deep dish pizza. My family along with myself got together and went on a family reunion slash vacation to Chicago. One of the things that excited is the most was trying true deep-dish pizza. Honestly we were and are truly disappointed about what was put in front of us. The canned tomato sauce that was on top of a artificially butter flavored limp crust was watery and the whole thing lacked any depth of flavor. It was a true letdown. However while at this place we discovered the classic chopped salad. It was to die for! That salad is the only reason that this is above a one star review. We had a similar experience at giordanos--great salad terrible pizza!!!

SOLID Chicago pizza place...wow. I'm impressed!!! This is the real deal. Yes, it's a chain, no, I don't usually go for that, but....YOU GOTTA TASTE THIS PIE. Seriously. These are fresh, amazing, delicious pizza pies. We got the butter crust (c'mon, you gotta go all the way when you're visiting Chicago and only have one night to try pizza)! I think our pizza was the equivalent of the "kitchen sink" in some other shops, and I'd get it all over again even though I'm usually a one-topping gal. With a pint of beer and a salad to start, I couldn't have been more pleased. The wait? Painful. The payoff? Amazingness. Would wait in the cold all over again for Lou's pie. Anytime.
A bit long of a wait, but definitely worth it! Definitely the best deep dish is Chi-town. If you love meat, just get the meat lovers -- don't even think twice. You won't regret it.

Fair warning, pizza snob here. I just moved to Chi and am checking out all the pizza spots, Lou's is close to me so I gave it a shot this last Saturday evening. Long wait for the pizza, expected this, so no problem there.  Got seating at the bar, drink options pretty standard.  The place ooozes a touristy feeling, I suppose this is also to be expected. Got the classic chicago, it has a layer of cheese, sausage, then sauce on top.  The crust was great, very buttery and crisp.  Though before I even took a bite I was pretty certain the tomatoes were frozen, just from the appearance.  I am pretty sure that I'm right after tasting. The sausage was also clearly not fresh, or high quality.  It honestly seemed like that cheap stuff they throw on pizza in high school cafeterias. To me, you have to use quality, fresh ingredients to set your pizza place apart.  I know Lou's is cashing in on the tourist factor and long lasting name.  But as a local (new), I'll be taking my visiting family members to Pequod's in order to show them deep dish in the city.

I went to Chicago for a conference and this place was a must. Of course I had never tried deep dish and so my daughter and I stood in line for almost an hour to eat on one of their street side table, which we thought was nice to take in the city views and people watch.  It was really delicious and one huge piece filled us up right away. We did a half pepperoni and half 'Lou', which is a spinach mix, mushrooms and sliced roma tomatoes covered with blend of mozzarella, romano and cheddar cheese on garlic Buttercrust. I got the minestrone soup because we were hungry and had to wait another 30+ mins because it took longer to make our custom half and half pizza. Next time you're in Chicago you must try it out.

Caveat: this is from the perspective of a tourist. If you don't call ahead, be prepared to wait about 30-40 minutes for your pizza, but it's well worth the wait. I had a house salad which was fine, but nothing special, but the sausage deep-dish pizza was amazing! Decent prices, and the service was good.

Very slow service. The pizza was okay. I got a thin crust pepperoni. We were going to order a cookie thing for dessert and the waitress said to wait to order it because it takes less than 10 minutes. We ordered it later (per her suggestion) and she said "okay but it's going to take 20-25 minutes". When she brought the bill I gave her my card and didn't even look at it and told her we were in a hurry. She stopped at three other tables on the way to run my card and one table on the way back. I know that we were not her only table but she was taking forever with everything. We were the ones on the back burner.

Pretty disappointed, this was my first time in Chicago, and I was told to come here by multiple people. You enter this place, while you wait for a seat, you order your pizza (since it takes about 45 min to make) great idea! So we get in around 1pm..  We were seated probably about 30 minutes later and we order some apps. Apps come out at room temperature. Probably been sitting on the expo window or wherever for a while. We were starving so we just ate them and didn't say anything.  It's about 2:15 now - still no pizza. People all around are all getting theirs before us, so I ask them to check on it for us. They bring out this pizza. It's 2:30 now, so an hour and 30 min after we had put the order in to begin with. It takes an hour and 30 minutes to make pizza. No joke there's like a watery  substance sloshing on the pizza, probably from the veggies, the pizza looks like it had been sitting out for ages. I already in my head told myself there's no way this pizza is cooked. I have a tiny bite and it's cold. Not sure why you'd even bring this pizza to someone by the way it looked. They clearly rushed this pizza, probably forgot to bring it out, I don't even know, nobody could explain to us why this took so long or why our pizza was so bad. They offered us another pizza which we accepted but at this point we are just over being there for so long. Waited another 30 minutes, finally got another pizza. Was alright. I guess the whole experience overall made me lose my appetite. We watched 3 sets of people sit and leave by the time we finally got to eat. Not how I wanted to spend my day.  They did comp our food, which we appreciate, but a little more communication would've been nice. Not just keep us waiting forever in the dark wondering where our food is.

Great food, good Bloody Mary, friendly bartender. Hosts ignored us when we walked in and seated people that walked in behind us (was super awkward) so we sat at the bar (which was fine bc the bartender was good). Salad was awesome and I'm glad the bartender suggested it because the pizza took a long time to make (as the bartender had warned us it would). So overall: very good.

Okay 3,2, and 1 star Yelpers...we get it, you like New York style pizza.  Okay self (and life-long New Yorker), you like Chicago style pizza, and it doesn't matter what your family and friends say, you're going to go to bat for it.  My partner and I's first stop on our trip to Chicago was Lou Malnati's. It came recommended as the best of the bunch to try deep dish and a location was conveniently located near our hotel. First, I had no idea that these deep dish Chicago pizzerias were more like chains (atmosphere reminded me of New York's UNO locations), which already creates this allure that there's nothing particular special or authentic about it. And while I must agree that message carried on through our meal, I still really loved the Chicago classic with sausage, veggies, ripened tomato, and crispy butter crust. There was just something comforting about it, rich but not overly so, solid cheese, tasty lean sausage, served nice and steamy. For the price the portion seems enormous, and although there's a bit of a cook-time wait, it's well worth the extra minutes. I think we need to bury this age old battle of which pizza champions the other - they're different and satisfying in their own right. Now New Yorker's let's focus on educating the people like-minded to those who sat behind us, that you don't eat "three-cheese bread sticks with dipping sauce," before you eat a damn pizza.

Visiting Chicago and ate here on the advice of a friend who lives in the city. Ordered the classic. Excellent flavor and crispness of crust. Also had a cup of minestrone soup that was very good. Haven't tried other pizza here in the city but we'd definitely come back here!

The staff were kind,  but disorganized. After minutes someone brought a pizza to our table which was not ours. We told the server and he seemed irritated at us. When our pizza finally came out, it was wrong because of server gave our pizza to another table. They quickly made us a personal size of what we were supposed to get on half of ours. No compensation or apology was offered for the numerous mistakes. Good pizza, good calamari.

First Chicago pizza from a place that I was told is one of the best in Chicago. Sorry but I was not impressed. Crust was a bit hard, tasty but hard. Positive: Service was good and our server was really nice, but foodwise, not worth it. If you live in L.A. or anywhere with a BJ's, it will do if you like deep dish.

I'm not a huge fan of deep dish pizza, but with it being a staple in Chicago, I definitely wanted to try one of the more popular ones.  The place was crowded, but we were seated relatively quickly. We ordered a deep dish pizza, which was quite good. It wasn't too cheesy and the tomato flavor wasn't too overpowering like other deep dishes I tried.  We also ordered a pasta dish. It wasn't bad, but definitely not a must try. If I'm ever back in Chicago, I would definitely visit again.

Local guy here.. order thin crust! It's amazing. Of course many people come for the deep dish but the thin with a salad is another great route to take. Very friendly staff and very easy to do carry out.
The best tasting deep dish pizza....ever!

Visiting Chicago ...we were told Lou Malnatis was a great Chicago institution and fabulous pizza.   Instead we were met with mediocre pizza (at best), mediocre service and a rather dirty establishment.  Disappointing.

Amazing pizza! Their deep dish pepperoni and deep dish veggie are amazing! The crust is buttery and crispy and the sauce is so fresh and delicious!! Lou Malnatis is hands down my favorite deep dish pizza in Chicago!
I've tried Lou Malnati's, Gino's, Giordano's, Uno Pizzeria, and every other small pizzeria in Chicago. Malnati's is the the BEST.
First time having Chicago deep dish and it did not disappoint! I did not expect to have that much sausage on one slice!

Love the lasagne , patio seating on rush street when the weather permits , gets pretty packed on weekends , so make some time for a wait or reserve your table in advance , they have a pretty decent salad selection and pizzas , there's also some nice house made gourmet food to take home .

We had higher expectation for this place since it has high rating and lots of our friends had recommended this place. The wait is long but while you wait, you can order your food and they said that they'll time it so by the time you sit down, your pizza should get to you. However this was not the case. I waited an hour to be seated and another 30 mins to get the food.

My family of four shared two small deep dish pizzas - "The Lou" (vegetarian) and a cheese.  Both were excellent and we were all full without any leftovers.  I especially like The Lou after I jazzed it up with some parmesan and red pepper.  The restaurant was visually interesting with all of its historical and industrial decor.
My buddy Dustin and JBaz took me here the first time I come to Chicago. I loved it. It was de-licous. If you need a Chicago traditional slice of deep dish pie, do this. You'll be happy
The restaurant was packed but it didn't take the 45 minutes to get sat as informed by the hostess. I tried the deep and dish and it was very good. It is worth a try.

If your looking for the Chicago deep dish pizza this is by far the best. Went on a quest at all the places here. Unfortunately I started here so everything else was sub par and I regretted spending the calories on. This place is worth the wait and you will wait. But be patient. It's the best in town

We ordered the lunch special, and some appetizers and was very disappointed. We ordered the combo platter and everything was good except the pickles. They tasted like a plain cucumber breaded and fried. The calamari  and ranch dressing was amazing!!! The pizza was ok, we were told after we ordered the lunch special(personal pizza) that they are made ahead and frozen and that's exactly what it tasted like. Maybe we should have ordered one and had it made fresh.
Really, the best in the area but it is always crowded. Great deep dish as well as thin crust.
If you are in downtown Chicago, you MUST try a Lou Malnati's deep dish pizza. Awesome staff and incredible food.
I ate a tasty large salad, drink, and personal pizza for $8. Good value!

It's deep dish, it's buttery and it's delicious.  Lou Malnati's is my favorite for deep dish because of the buttery thin crust and the cheese.  I am not by any means a thin crust person I actually don't prefer it.  But here it is very good.  I recommend you try it at least once

Not for me. I love the crust but I prefer a sweeter sauce and more cheese. It was my first ever experience with Chicago Pizza. It was delicious and I ate every ounce of it bc it was a treat for me to have PIZZA. I am Sicilian so my favorite is fluffy pizza, with sweet sauce, and a lot of cheese!

Visiting from Ohio & meeting a local friend for lunch, we suggested Uno's for the kids but my friend said no - that's too touristy and not authentic Chicago pizza- he suggested Lou's. So glad he did! We had the Lou's and a half cheese-half pepperoni and they did not disappoint- loved the buttery crust. The pleasant surprise of the meal? The house salad! My friend ordered the family side for all of us to share, and the home made dressing was amazing! I'm not a big salad eater but I could have filled up on that! Definitely coming back!

THIS IS FOR ONLINE ORDERING ONLY!!!  I have not been to this place but have heard so much about it.  I live in LA and ordered a couple pies-- something was lost on the ride out here.  I still have one in the freezer and not overly excited about it. I found the pie's small for the price and ok in flavor

Fabulous Chicago-style, deep-dish pizza! Went for the special, and wasn't disappointed. Ordered a medium, which was too big for two people. On the positive, I brought the leftovers home the next day to bring a taste of Chicago down south to family! Could highly recommend for a tasty pizza!

I am not a big deep-dish pizza person but when in Chicago.... I have been to a few of the different pizza spots in Chicago and Lou Malnati's is definitely my favorite when it comes to deep-dish. The atmosphere is casual with tvs and sports memorabilia on the walls. They have lunch specials on the weekdays where you can get a personal pizza or half sandwich with a salad or soup. This location in particular gets really crowded so try to come for an early lunch or dinner to avoid waiting.  For the deep dish pizzas, there are different sizes as well as different types that you can order or even build your own pizza. It takes about 40-45 minutes for it to cook so make sure you aware if you are on a time crunch and order some appetizer if you are hungry. My favorites are the Stuffed Spinach Bread and the Combination Platter, especially the cheddar cubes on the platter. As for pizza, my favorites are the "Lou" and the "Classic" with adding pepperoni.  So if you are in Chicago, make sure you stop by here to get your deep-dish fix!
Great place to take the inlaws when they come in from out of town. Food is always good and it gives them the "authentic" chicago style they are looking for.

What can I say! Has to be some of the best pizza I have ever had. Lots of cheese and a nice ratio of sauce to dough. Pepperoni was stacked 5 think! We even ended up going back the next day and bringing more home to Toronto. Highly recommend while in Chicago

Lou Malnati's is my favorite deep dish pizza in Chicago. Great atmosphere and good service. Deep dish isn't my go-to pizza style but you gotta try them all. Prices are comparable to other area Chicago deep dish institutions.  A definite must if visiting Chicago.  There are several locations but I always end up at Wells.

Came here for lunch because it was recommended by folks back home. I liked the decor and the prices. The lunch special was 8.95 and includes a soup or salad, a personal pie and a drink. The food was good but not the best pie I had while in town. And it still took 45 min. So it was nice to have a fresh pizza.

Chicago friends encouraged me to visit after hearing my love for Gino's East.  I was not disappointed. Chicago classic with add on mushrooms and green peppers delivered. Loved the butter crust. Next time, I plan to try pepperoni instead of sausage. The layer of sausage was a bit too much for me, but overall this deep dish has a slight edge over Gino's. And that is high praise.

So...I really always thought of myself as a devout lover of NY style pizza that could never love Chicago style pizza as much. Well, I have never had Chicago style pizza before. And that is because I have never been to Chicago and never trusted anything deemed "Chicago style pizza." After extensive research and gaining approval from some locals, my husband and I settled on Lou's. We were not sure how much pizza to order because we can typically devour a large thin crust pizza. So we figured 2 smalls would allow us to indulge while having the chance to get a couple different kinds. We opted for plain cheese deep dish and the Malnati classic pie. The classic was by far our favorite but the cheese was so good as well. In the end, we did not finish the two smalls but we came pretty damn close. The result was us being extremely full until bedtime that evening (lol!) It was definitely all that cheese! It was layer upon layer of thick, warm, gooey cheese and I do not regret one bite regardless of how large my food baby was.  The service was quick, friendly, attentive, and honest. I say honest because they tell you that the pizza will take about 45 mins to cook (if you're ordering deep dish...and I don't know how you couldn't!) So, take that 45 minutes to drink a couple beers and build up the anticipation of great pizza to come.  I loved everything about that pizza. So thick and unlike any pizza I've ever tried before. I am so sad that I've waited so long to try this style pizza but I am so glad it was at a place that clearly is doing something right. To make it clear, I am no expert on Chicago pizza but I am certainly an expert on pizza in general...and by expert I mean I eat a lot of pizza. Hehe.  So if you're a newbie like me, give it a try and you will be surprised at how much you could love something you were so unsure of. I hope to try more Chicago-style pizza in the future and at least I will have a really great place to compare it to.
Best pizza in Chicago. Everyone is getting good pizza when they come out here. Good beers and a friendly team. Highly recommended!

If you're going to eat Chicago pizza, this is the place to be.  The rest are just tourist traps and lesser quality products.  Four stars because of the weak ambiance and lack of the menu options.  If they had better salads, appetizers, and beer selection then yes.  But if you just want pizza then this is the place to be.

I had to try authentic deep dish pizza while in Chicago, so I came to Lou Malnati's. This place seems to be crazy busy, as I went twice and both times there were 45 minute waits to get a seat on a week night. I ended up ordering a pizza online for carryout, which worked well for me. I ordered a personal-sized deep dish pizza with sausage, green peppers, and fresh tomatoes. The pizza was amazing, so I'm glad I chose to try my first deep dish pizza here.

I have been to several places in Chicago for deep dish pizza, including the original Unos long before it became a franchise/chain.  Sadly, these guys disappointed me. It was billed as "the best deep dish in Chicago" by some local friends and while it was OK, it was far from great For starters, about the only thing deep about was the pan it was baked in. It was roughly half an inch thick. Second, it lacked depth of flavor. No hint of garlic, the sauce was generic and the cheese was uninspiring. Gino's may be consider another chain that also sells frozen pizza, but I personally think it is ten times better.
I have to say this is the best deep dish I have had!! Our waiter was awesome and super friendly. Will definitely come back here next time I'm visiting !

D' best thin crust pizza in the midwest! Drove from the gateway arch to have a good pizza, and it's worth the 300 miles to try this deliciousness of a round dough. When we arrived the line was also 300 meters long that we just opted to go, and after the first bite I got a taste of mecca decca pizzeria fantasia. And let me correct my first statement, Drove from the gateway arch to have an excellent thin crust pizza.

Not at all impressed. Took nearly two hours to get out order of 1 pizza and a salad. They forgot to cut the pizza and did not include the sides or  any napkins or plastic ware.  Over thirty minutes later they finally show up with it but by this time it is ice cold pizza and in a hotel we have no way to even warm it up. Won't recommend and won't go back.
Great pizza , visiting on  business from our of town,  figured why not, and happy I did!!!  There pizza was delicious and the creme cheesecake was delicious..
Soooo delicious! Had the Gluten-free pizza, house salad & Sangria. I'm in Chicago heaven lol!

It's a Chicago classic that I bring visiting family and friends while touring downtown. It's pretty busy on weekends and during peak hours, but service is always nice and there's always a friendly and energetic vibe. Can't go wrong with the Malnati classic deep dish with the sausage baked right in. The vegetarian version isn't bad either. And something that is delicious and unexpected here is the calamari. YUM!

Good pizza, not too cheesy. I've only been there for the deep dish pizza and it's quite nice. I have taken my out-of-town friends and family there and they liked it. When it's busy, waiting time can be long

What can you say that already hasn't been said went on Saturday afternoon about 4pm didn't have to wait which was cool.  Pizza was great if you don't like a lot of dressing they put a lot on but everyone loves their dressing.  All was good keep it up!

I wanted to love it.  I had so much hope for Lou Malnati's.  Ultimately, however, I have come to conclusion that it might not even be deep dish. I'm no expert.  In fact, this was my first EVER experience with deep dish, which is why I'm so disappointed that it was bad.  We read every review and weighed about 5 different pizza places, ultimately narrowing it down to Lou Malnati's and Giordano's.  We picked Lou's because everyone said to.  We called up friends who are from Chicago, we read reviews that said that Chicago natives all seem to prefer Lou's. The crust was crunchy, not soft at all, anywhere, and a little bit mealy.  (This was the butter crust, ordered "just right").  It also tasted somewhat of baking soda--it had that off, objectionable taste I get when I try, and fail, to make homemade dough.  Despite the fact that we ordered extra sauce, what we got was basically nothing (and I'm not suggesting they forgot).  It tasted of nothing but stewed tomatoes--no flavor or seasoning almost at all!  The cheese was good, although there was too much of it in relation to the sauce. Worst of all, the entire pie altogether was only about an inch thick at most.  If that's what deep dish is, I suspect I prefer New England greek-style pizza--but I'm holding out hope for a better future, when I'll come back to Chicago and order Giordano's or something.

Very disappointed to be honest, we tried them because we are fans of Gino's East and giordano's.  (Yes we have a split house hold) From the moment we walked in to the what we felt was outdated and dirty place to the 2 pizzas we ordered to try different tastes we were underwhelmed.  The sauce was bland and to chunky and the crust we I am not sure what to say about the cardboard burnt taste.  We have not returned to any location and never will.  There is much better Chicago style pizza out there.

I've been living in Chicago majority of my life and I have to say that Lou Malnati's is C+ pizza at best. It honestly depends on what you want, they are good for office parties and if you have a group that wants something fast and easy. My company orders from here whenever we have an event and they deliver fast and on-time. They just deliver C+ plus pizza really well. If you want mind blowing pizza keep looking but if your office is having a pizza party this place is  an ok choice.

I went really early to avoid the wait and was one of the last people to get a table without a wait. By the time I left you can't get in the door. Sat at the bar and had trouble getting anybody's attention. Finally ordered and was told 35-40 minute wait for pizza to cook which I knew about. After 50 minutes I asked what was up and people who ordered after me got their pizza. He told me 10 more minutes. After 15 more minutes pizza came out. A total of one hour five minutes. Not sure what happened but that's a bit too long. Pizza was ok and I may have thought better than that but mood was low due to excruciating wait. You can take 40 minutes to make a great pie but after more than 1 1/2 times that long you should be ashamed.
I just rec'd 4 pizzas in the mail from Lois for my birthday. And I live in idaho! Thanks lou! Not as good as fresh out of the oven but beats not having any!

The Malnati Chicago Classic just do it don't ask questions just order it and buckle yourself in for the most fantastic ride of your life. Also their Malnati salad is off the hook. Basically Stacy's mom because they've got it all going on

After living in Chicago for four years, today I finally had my first slice of deep-dish Malnati's. One of the managers at my office ordered in several pies for a lunch meeting. Such anticipation! I expected something sublime after hearing people gush about the place. So I took my first bite, and...bleh. What a huge disappointment. First of all, it seemed like it was only half-cooked. I like my pizza sizzling, with big beautiful crusty bubbles of cheese, and this pie was mushy and covered with very wet, sloppy tomatoes. Second, it was so bland; it badly needed salt, and some oregano and basil wouldn't have hurt either. Third, one slice seemed like a pound of food; it was way too heavy and sodden. So next I tried the thin-crust plain cheese. I liked that even less. It was tasteless! One of our out-of-town attendees asked me if I could get the salt shaker out of the kitchen, and he was right. The crust is completely tasteless. Blech. Pizza is a very personal thing; just because I didn't like this doesn't mean you won't. It's worth a try. But for me, if I never eat another piece of Malnati's, that's just fine with me. In the Giordano's/Malnati's face-off, put me on the Giordano's team. On the plus side, the delivery person was very nice!
Never tasted a pizza like this before! Greasy, cheesy, delicious. I recommend starving yourself before you eat this.. you will gain 3lbs! So good, and what I imagined a real dip dish tasted like.

From out of town looking for traditional Chicago deep dish- boy, were the reviews right! Had the classic Lou and it was amazing! Ordered the personal size and it was just the right amount- also had their classic minestrone soup and it was fantastic! Will come again!
It was my first time trying deep dish pizza. The food was really delicious and I especially loved the salad

Thanks for making my deep-dish pizza experience a great one! My colleague and I were in town for a convention so having a Chicago style pizza was an order. We dined here on 3/9/17 and though this is my first deep-dish pizza experience, it is save to say that their pizza is bomb based on the quality of the crust, sausage and the sauce. Beware that they make the pizzas to order so you'll have to wait 30 minutes for it to come. We occupied ourself with a house salad (the single order is plenty to share between two people) and we also ordered the deep fried calamari for app and it was tasty, the batter was crunchy but the squid itself was tender (yay it wasn't a frozen calamari that comes in a bag!) I'm more of a thin crust pizza person, however, Lou Malnati did their job of convincing me that there are other ways to have your pizza! :) I'm craving their pizza just from writing this review

So we're in Chicago for the weekend and of course you have to do the touristy thing and try the best Chicago style pizza. So I hit up yelp for recommendations. Lou's apparently is the place to go, and his father is one of the original creators of this pizza masterpiece. But wait, why would a masterpiece not receive 5/5? Because it is a pizza joint that only serve 6 beers. Because its a pizza joint without the pizza joint vibe. Because the pizza was lacking. No spicy or even richness to the sauce. No well seasoned toppings or crunchy, chewy crust; it was too flaky like pie crust. To be honest I am not sure if I went to this location or not, but considering this is a local chain and a local favorite this is applicable to all of them.

Take your time with this place. Great pizza doesn't miraculously happen in 10 minutes. You can go to pizza hut for that! This pizza is so yummy and gives you the Chicago deep dish pizza experience you have been looking for. The sauce is fresh and full of flavor. The sausage is tender and flavorful, and the cheese!!! The crust is buttery and nice and thick. The service is also very friendly and the energy of the place is great for tourist and locals alike.

Between Pizzeria Uno, Gino's East, and Lou Malnati's, this is my favorite. Get the classic with tomato sauce, extra cheese and sausage. Ordering system for those dining-in is a bit different than other pizzerias, since these deep dish pizzas take so long to bake. You order your pizza at a counter and are then seated. If you order take-out, it takes about 45 minutes. My pizza was ready right on time.

We went to dinner here while visiting Chicago for Spring Break. It also happened to be my husband's birthday. He is a huge pizza fan and always wanted to try this place.  We were told it would be a 45 minute wait and encouraged to look over the menu so we could order in advance since the pizzas take about 40 minutes to make. We had almost decided on our choices when we got the text that our table was ready. It had only been 10 minutes at most.  We got the family salad and the three cheese bread to start. Both were great. I had a mule which was pretty good. The pizzas were fabulous. The crust was rich and buttery and the sauce was slightly sweet. I had a personal size "The Lou". Perfect.  Our server (I think her name was Jelena) was quick, friendly, helpful, and attentive. It was a bit loud and almost rowdy for a Tuesday evening, but that just added to the fun atmosphere. I really don't think I can say one bad thing about this place. Our entire experience was wonderful and I would definitely go back.

We're lucky that they were open the night we went looking for pizza. Most of the other places like Gino's closed at 9:00! The deep dish was fantastic and the service at the bar was excellent! We'll definitely get our pizza here next time we're in town!
I love this place!   I never knew I could love Chicago style pizza until I went here!  The wait can be long at times but it is sooooo worth it!

Wow is this good pizza. Expect to wait about 45 minutes for your pizza, but it is so worth it. This is one of my favorite pizza places in Chicago. The deep dish was awesome. I went with some friends here on a pizza food crawl, and I'm so glad we stopped here.

Lou Malnati's did not disappoint!! Everyone we spoke to recommended this place to us!! The butter  crust was sooo good!! Ordering the pizza when you check in helps on the wait time. Even on a Saturday night we didn't wait all that long. We will definitely visit again when we come back to Chicago.

I've been to this place already twice since moving to Chicago a couple of months ago. The deep dish pizza is reaaaaally good and I always take my visitors to experience it here. The servers are really nice, and I found it to have a lesser waiting time than usual deep dish places around River North. I highly recommend. Oh and also way better than Giordano's!

The pizza was good, I'll give you that.  I've never been one to worship at the altar of thin-crust pizza; I like a thicker crust.  So, on that score, Malnati's deep-dish was already ahead of the game -- I needed no convincing.  It was tasty, and very filling.  On food alone, they would have earned 4 stars. The wait staff was nice. But 40 mins from the time you place you order until they bring the pizza?  That's ridiculous.  And this was during a non-busy time on Sunday just before noon. The night before, we had gone there for dinner -- a 40 min wait, plus pizza-making time.  Time to take out? 40 mins.  Time to deliver? 1 hr 45 mins. The staff was up-front about it, to their credit.  But this is not some one-of-a-kind restaurant...  It's not the cronut, or tickets to Hamilton.  Sheeeesh... In NYC, they would have figured out a way to get you your deep dish pizza in under 40 mins.  Or they would have been out of business. So, three stars.  If you want appetizers before your pizza, this is a fine place.  Or, if you want to finish those last 80 pages of James Joyce's Ulysses in a setting in which you won't be disturbed for a while, this is fine.  But otherwise, go to Portillos and enjoy the char-grilled sausage with grilled onions...   It won't satisfy your pizza craving, but you'll be on your way to your next stop a lot more quickly.

We were recommended to try this place by a friend. I had never had deep dish pizza before and was very eager to try it. We came on a Thursday evening and the place was packed. However the hostesses were very service minded and they had a great system for writing down your number and text you when your table was ready. We waited in the bar and was seated within 30 min. We ordered one deep dish pizza with pepperoni and one with sausage. It was good but nothing amazing or impressive. I will stick to my thin pizzas.

Every time I tell somebody I live in Chicago, they ask which club I'm in: Lou's or Giordano's. I can now say I support Lou Malnati's! I ordered a personal Chicago Classic pie with added Roma tomatoes for delivery, and I was not disappointed.  First off, the butter crust is absolutely delicious. Probably my favorite deep dish crust I've ever had, and I was pretty in love with Patxi's (in California) version. This version is sweet and flaky, almost like half crust and half pastry. Unfortunately though, like pastry, it got a bit soggy. I thought it was the moisture from the tomatoes, but from reading others' similar reviews it sounds like the mozzarella is so moist that it bleeds into the crust and doesn't keep it crispy. I didn't mind it terribly, though; it was still delicious.  The cheese is fresh, well-melted, and perfectly portioned. There was plenty of it, but I never felt like I was getting just a mouthful of goop. Toppings were SUBLIME. That sausage is one of the best I've had on pizza, and the Roma tomatoes were exquisitely fresh. You can tell that they put a lot of care into their ingredients, and it pays off! I really didn't notice any sauce underneath my tomatoes, and from what I read in other reviews the sauce layer is pretty thin. But what amount there is, I was happy with it because I felt that the pie had a great amount of depth in flavor and seasoning. Lots of different notes going on. The delivery was at the tail end of the 15-minute window I asked for when I ordered online, but still on time. I would certainly order from Lou Malnati's again!
Pizza and beer was good. Authentic Chicago pizza makes me happy. Had the Lou pizza and was delicious.
Chicago deep dish, and the way to be. Their crust is tasty, but there is one other deep dish place that might have them beat just slight. We must be honest and say we love thing crust better.

The epitome of Chicago deep dish.  You gotta go with the Chicago classic if you've never been here before.  It's always crowded during the dinner rush so I'd recommend getting a table early.  Service can summer if your waiter gets stuck with a huge party.  Lou's and Giordanos are 1a and 1b for me and I can't visit the Windy City without paying either a visit.  I really like the flavor and buttery crust of the Lou's pie.  Can't go wrong here.

This place gets packed and for good reason. On our last night in Chicago, a group of us decided we wanted some deep dish to close out our trip. This place was highly recommended, and by the look of the crowds waiting to get in, was popular among the locals as well. One thing that's really awesome about this place is that they let you pre-order your pizza (because they take up to 50-minutes to cook) so that it's ready to be set at the table when it's finally your turn snag some seats. With our group of five on a Thursday night, it was a 45-minute wait even around 8PM, so we enjoyed each others company while grabbing a few drinks at their bar. What I liked is that within a few minutes of being seated, pizza magically made its way to the tables and we were ready to eat. We got two medium sausage and pepperoni pizzas to share as well as a salad to break up the gluttonous amount of cheese we were about to indulge in. The salad was a great starter and that pizza was nothing to scoff at. The crust was super buttery and they didn't skimp on the meaty toppings. Two pieces are enough for most, but because I was starving, I went for three. I felt like I was pregnant for the rest of the night, but didn't regret any of the bites I had to force myself to take. Service was friendly and the company was even better. I'd definitely recommend Lou Malnati's if you're craving deep dish deliciousness!

Lou Malnati's is now my favorite deep dish pizza place. I used to think it was Gino's East, but I was so wrong. We came to Lou's on a Friday afternoon and sat outside on their patio. My husband and I both had drinks and ended up splitting one of Lou's pepperoni deep dish pizzas and a ceasar salad. The combo was perfect and it was just the right amount of food portions for each of us.  #1 reason why I love Lou's versus Gino's? The crust. Lou's crust is cooked perfectly, unlike Gino's that takes away the flavor of the pizza with their cornbread style crust. The pizza is also extremely flavorful and the service there is great. Plus, they have more than one location in Chicago, which I love.  If you want real, authentic, delicious deep dish pizza, go to Lou Malnati's!

We heard that this is the best pizza in Chicago. We shared Bar-B-Lou wings with honey barbecue sauce, a Malnati salad, and a Malnati Chicago Classic deep dish pizza (lean sausage and buttercrust).  Everything was great. I have no complaints.

Regular pizza is now ruined forever, because the pizza here is out of this world. We got the Chicago classic and it was heaven in a pan. Butter crust is everything to me now. Wait was shorter than they told us it would be- they obviously have a great system going here. Looking forward to my next trip just for this pizza!

Had my first ever deep dish in chi town ... I was told this was a better location so I went here. I got your standard deep dish, nothing fancy. It was pretty darn good but I wouldn't go back if I wish in chi town again. Of course, when you're in Chicago you have to try a deep dish at least once. It didn't disappoint.  We also got the bruschetta which was decent and a huge portion.
Walked 40 minutes to get here and worth every minute. The highlight of my visit to Chicago. Easily the best deep dish I've ever had! So happy.
My Science! So good! The calamari was legit! The deep dish was amazing! Good ambiance with that classic Chicago charm.

Lou's deep dish is the best around. My cousins recently came to visit from Italy and couldn't get enough.  This pizza is the definition of Chicago deep dish. I have grown up ordering via delivery and in restaurant in the suburbs and am never disappointed. This location is no different.  When you order make sure to order uncut to keep the pizza warm and keep the cheese from sliding!
One of my favorite pizza spots in Chicago! Took my mother here for a deep dish pizza and it was delicious. Chicago has the best pizza in the world. Hands down.

Best deep dish pizza in Chicago hands down. Because they are the best there is always a long wait. What Lou Malnati's does that's wonderful is they will take your order if you call ahead and put your pizza in the oven so that it is ready or almost ready when you do get a table and sit. So call ahead they are helpful! You can't go wrong on what pizza you want. The Classic is always a great go to option if you have never been there before. If you create your own pizza always ask for the butter crust! They also are able to do gluten free crust for any food sensitivities someone in your family might have. Stick to their recommendations I have found a large is just the perfect amount for four people and their is usually a piece left over. Eating two deep crust pieces is like eating four regular pizza slices anywhere else if you ask me. If you are dining in they will cut and serve the first slice for the family. So if you are in the area this is a must try!!

This is always our last stop on the trade show circuit. The salad is the show stopper, maybe better than the pizza. Be prepared to wait, but you do order before you sit, so it's not and eternity for the food to come. We get one deep dish one thin crust

Whenever I visit Chicago I pay my respects by eating at Lou Malnatis or Giordanos. Both great deep dish pizzas! The butter crust is delicious, full of flavor and crunch. The service was friendly and prompt. Overall great experience! Only deducted one star because for me thin crust all the way!!!
Great pizza and friendly staff. Make sure you pre-order your pizza at the stand if there's a wait, helps it come faster once you sit down.

Love this pizzeria! We go to the one in Oak Park and the pizza is always great. Love the crispy crust. I also love their chop salad for an alternative to a pizza. The decor is great, contemporary rustic, along with great service. They have a large sliding glass wall curb side that opens up in the summer time for  great dining al fresco style.
I had to put salt on my pizza.  The service was impressive-- they CHURN people in and out of here. I found the food to be extremely bland and disappointing.

David - bartender, was seriously amazing, despite a busy Saturday lunch crowd. Guy knows how to hustle. Thanks for taking care of us, and Thanks to Lou's for some awesome pizza. Had the Chicago-style deep dish, added fresh spinach mix.

For 4 people at 8:30PM on a Tuesday night, they said we would wait 30 minutes but ended up waiting 10 before being seated! Yes!! We shared the spinach salad with chicken, a small Lou deep dish pizza and got the pizza cookie for dessert. Spinach salad: Good, simple but lots of it, great to share. Lou deep dish pizza: Toppings (spinach, tomato, mushrooms) were good but I though the dough was really underwhelming. On it's own it really doesn't taste like much. Pizza cookie: I'm going to say it: it's just a cookie in a pizza pan. It is good, warm and gooey but it's a cookie, nothing special about it. It comes with ice cream and whipped cream, which compliments nicely the cookie. Overall nice place for groups but I don't think that the food was that good.
Good god this is my fav pizza place in Chicago. It has a great deep dish pizza! I normally get the pepperoni deep pizza and it's on point!

True deep dish Chicago pizza is not just a meal, it's a way of life. Okay enough for cheesy lines (see what I did there?). We waited an hour or so around lunch time to eat inside. The pizza took a while to come once we ordered but once we got the food, it was incredible. It was some combination of anticipation and hunger and the fact that it's PIZZA, the greatest thing on the planet, that really drove the experience home. Deep dish is the best pizza hands down and my review is a reflection of that bias. We ordered the Malnati Chicago classic. I'm not one of those people who doesn't eat the crust and, to me, the butter crust was excellent, one of the best I've ever had.  Service was good. It was a busy Saturday, so for me there was no expectation of fast service or anything like that. Even so, our waiter was friendly and asked us where we were from and chatted a bit.  All in all, great experience. Better pizza. (No, this is not meant to be an ode to the Papa John's slogan).

The bruschetta was incredible -- best I've ever had!  The deep dish pizza (get the butter crust) was amazing.  Calamari was very good. The only drawback was it was packed and the wait was one and a half hours. That was rough.  We were famished.  Definitely call ahead.  Great service.  Would come back no doubt!  As good as they say.

I had the pleasure of dining here awhile back and am so glad I did!! My first trip to Chicago wasn't complete without a visit here.  It is definitely better than I'd heard! Our waiter was phenomenal!  From the bread,  the pizza and the atmosphere,  simply great!  That crust is like Crack,  you just can't get enough! We had just the basic pepperoni which was delicious.  I cannot wait to go back!

Tasty pizza, but terrible service. The wait for pizza was an hour plus, so we decided to get a drink at the bar. My buddy was denied a drink, despite being sober at totally in control. The rest of the party was also denied drinks based on this. Bartender Bobby was not at all accommodating and resulting in an overall very negative experience. Go elsewhere if you want to be treated like a human...

After viewing all the competition for best deep dish pizza in Chicago, my girlfriend and I decide to try Lou Malnati's. We went here on a Wednesday night around 6pm, so it wasn't too crowded. However, around 7pm, all the booths and tables were filled, so try to get here early if you can. The booths are extremely comfortable and the service at Lou Malnati's is quite good because the waiters are attentive and even slice the deep dish pizza for you. The GF and I ordered a medium sized Malnati Chicago Classic and the chocolate chip pizza for dessert. In regards to the deep dish pizza, the Malnati Chicago Classic was amazing, it came loaded with sausage and the crust was out of this world. The cheese was well melted and extremely flavorful. Initially, the medium size pizza looked too small for us, but after consuming that beast, it was a total hunger buster! My only complaint about the deep dish pizza at Lou Malanti's is that it is a bit oily (also the 30 minute wait for the pizza to be freshly prepared), but other than that this deep dish pizza was out of this world and I would come back to Chicago just to eat here again. Lastly, the dessert was also pretty good, we got the larger portion of the chocolate chip pizza and it was loaded with vanilla ice cream and whipped cream. I would tell them to go easy on the whipped cream because it was an overload. However, the chocolate chip portion was warm and soft, which complemented the ice cream very well. Overall, I highly recommend trying Lou Malnati's if you want some high quality deep dish pizza at an affordable price.
Sooooo good man~~ I hate pizza but I love deep dish pizza. My boyfriend and I waited here for 10mins even though we were told to wait 25mins. It's definitely worth it, and it's cheap.

I was disappointed. Last time I was in Chicago I was pleasantly surprised by Chicago pizza being a New York girl.  Make sure you ask for the butter crust. I failed to do so and I think that was based on the crust. I had a great time talking to other tourists at the bar. The place gets packed on a Saturday around 1pm. But Giordani's is better!

I believe they started it all. It had to be Lou, Gino's or Unos. Lou is my favorite of the bunch. Gino's East was amazing back in the day. Uno's was incredible. But Lou? Addictive. I would wake up in the middle of the night craving more of the butter crust. I've been told that I make a pretty mean pizza and I have to say I cribbed a few tips from Lou. I would eat there more often but I have to get some sleep at night, I can't afford to wake up craving crust.

Every trip to Chicago includes a trip to Lou's. Have been coming here for years and it's always over the top good. The pizza is uniquely different from NY pizza. It's in a class all it's own. Definitely worth trying. You won't be disappointed.

Today is a sad day. I have raved for years about Lou Malnatti's. I brought some colleagues to the Wells St location and was SO upset at the quality of the food! We waited for an hour for a pizza that had a HARD crust! I know all the Lou fans can't believe it. Now I have to go somewhere else to redeem Chicago Pizza for this crowd. I told you today is a sad day!!

We were disappointed to taste this pizza which is supposed to be the best Chicago style pizza in town. We ordered personal pizzas and they were very bland.  Crust was boring, sauce tasted like it was out of a jar.  Toppings were nothing special.  The only good thing was the cheese. The cheese was delicious. Otherwise, would not recommend it and I can't see why so many like it. Maybe they all like bland pizza.

This is my most favorite place to go for pizza.  Crust is amazing, good sauce, and nice cheese.  If folks come from out of town to visit me this is always our first stop.  Bar none the pizza in Chicago!!!!!
I recently asked for a pizza to go (the Lou with all the trimmings), and I was disappointed with the final result. I used to like this deep dish pizza, but not anymore :P

This is a wonderful place to go as well as to take your visitors from somewhere else. The deep dish is as expected. A full meal, of course, in maybe one slice. Also, the salad here is great, a surprise. The thin crust is also really good. I always recommend Lou Malnati's.
This is Chicago pizza at its best.  The deep dish is so good - from the cheese to the vegetable, you don't want to miss this one.
Calamari Great, Salad Great, Pizza Great (Recommend Extra Sausage, Extra Garlic), Wine Great, Dessert Great, Staff Great.  Notice the theme...Great!   Cheers!

This was my first deep dish pizza experience and I'm so glad I had it here! Our waiter was really nice and attentive, but the pizza. The pizza! We ordered their house classic and I wish I could have brought a dozen home with me.

The pizza was very good. The cheese was fantastic and the sauce was great but there wasn't enough of it in my opinion. I wasn't happy with the way the sauce didn't taste fresh and it didn't taste like fresh tomatoes even though there were huge chunks. We opted for the Classic Chicago deep dish stuffed pizza. I ordered from the hotel BEFORE we arrived at the restaurant to make the wait shorter, we arrived, clearly the order had been submitted but we still waited 35 minutes. Our server was "meh" at best and when I had to ask him about my order that was placed BEFORE we got there...he realized we had been waiting a long time but never checked on anything until I asked. Customer service was pretty lousy but the pizza was very good. NOT great but very good.

We got to the restaurant on a weekend afternoon around 5:30p and boy was that the right choice! There was no line, no wait, and our order came out within half and hour! (as rumors have it that the thick crust takes a while) Service was great and the food was even better. Our waiter offered to pour our wine for us, dished out our salad servings one by one, and offered to plate our slices of pizza to each of us. The food was hot and fresh. The deep dish was steaming hot inside and out. The crust was buttery and delicious. The thin crust was soft and chewy but still held a great flavor. I usually don't like pizza but I definitely feel like I have been left out. If only I had tried Chicago deep dish pizza earlier!! This will be a memorable place for me during my visit to the beautiful city of Chicago.  love love love*
Was there tonight picking up my pizza and I think it was the manager but he was the nicest guy ever and the best customer service I ever had at a lous or any other restaurant!!! Love this place

This place was recommended by a few of our uber drivers so we figured we must try it. It was delicious, my friend got the dip dish and she loved it, I got the thin crust and loved it as well. It took 30 min to make the pizza but it was well worth it.
deep dish - period.  they have perfected the pie at lou malnatis!!!!

This was my first time eating Chicago Style pizza, and it was fantastic. Our waitress was Deborah, and she was one of the best waitresses I've ever had. Not an exaggeration. She was so friendly and helpful to someone in our group that couldn't have flour (she got the sausage crust). Deborah made the experience even better than it already was. I highly recommend if you're in the area!
Absolutely love Lou's. Had the cheese deep dish last weekend, leftovers today, and I plan on ordering again in the coming days. Make sure you select the butter crust!
Best pizza I have ever had, I get every year as a birthday treat! Try the pan crust Lou and the thin crust mushroom they are the best!
The spinach deep dish is amazing. The thing weighs like 5 lbs so I always have leftovers for lunch the next day. It's best hot, but still quite yummy cold. Lou's is the best deep dish in Chicago.

I visited on a weekday night and was a little surprised to see that a Lou Malnati's wasn't jam packed at 7. After eating here I guess I know why. I ordered the Malnati classic personal pizza, and for some reason what I got that day was not what I was expecting. The tomato sauce did not taste fresh, and the cheese wasn't exactly tantalizing either. The crust was crispy at least, but when the tomato/cheese/sausage are all subpar at best, I can only give two stars. I can't explain why it really just tasted as if the pizza ingredients all came from a can as I've had amazing pizza experiences at other locations in other parts of the city.  The wait was also insanely long, I waited 50 minutes for a tiny personal pizza that was not very tasty. Not recommended, will not return to this location.
One of my favs other than Gullivers on the north side. Pizza is a personal preference of course. Their butter crust deep dish spinach my go to. Their salads awesome and big!! Love their dressing.

Thick crust and mozzarella cheese as thick as bar of soap. We had the classic along with a family salad that had a vinaigrette dressing. Brick walls and atmosphere. We like this just as well as Giordanos and worth walking west of Miracle Mile to find.

Yum! My favorite pizza ever ever ever in my entire life is The Lou deep dish! So much so that my entire family knows that The Lou is officially part of my hospice plan for whenever that is needed.  The house salad with the creamy lemony garlic dressing is also great for a family style meal. But back to the pizza--get the butter crust.   Love it, love to take guests to this location when showing them Chicago--but also order delivery up in Mt Prospect or take them to the Buffalo Grove location.

Always amazing, every time. From the deep dish to the thin, you can't go wrong. Order it with extra butter crust if you like a richer kind of crust. The salads and dressings are all also amazing. You can not go wrong here for classic. Chicago pizza. Great for big groups and kids!

One of my favorite pizza places in the city.  The deep dish with butter crust is excellent and feels a bit lighter than most deep dish pizzas.  Something about the tomatoes used stands out, in particular.  The thin crust is decent (also, it is much better when first ordered than when eaten as a leftover).  You really aren't going to go wrong having pizza here, but if it's too busy, then go to Pizano's, which serves essentially the exact same pizza.

I was visiting Chicago for work and figured it was only right to try deep dish pizza while in Chicago. So I found a Lou Malnati's near by and went in for dinner. It was packed!! A very long wait, luckily there was one seat left at the bar. I had drink and ordered my pizza... overall really good pizza but I went in with what I think was unrealistic expectations for my deep dish pizza and was expecting something out of this world. Don't give me wrong, it's really good deep dish pizza but I thought it was a doughy and not the best I've had.

Went to Lou's on a Tuesday night. It was pretty empty. Sat at the bar and ordered beers that weren't very cold. We ordered the Lou's signature deep dish (cheese and sausage). It was okay. I liked that despite being a deep dish pizza, it didn't feel very "heavy". But overall, I thought it was kinda bland. We chose Lou's over other deep dish places based off reviews and suggestions from locals. It was a let down:-(

OMG this is one pizza place I'd recommend to anyone going through Chicago. You can't go wrong when ordering the Malnati Chicago Classic and Stuffed Spinach Bread :) We had a party of four and we must have had perfect timing because as soon as we were seated (which was right away)  the lunch rush started to flow in.

We tried to do our own pizza tour this trip. Pequod's vs Lou's. Maybe it's cause I'm from the Heartland where pizza is a food and not a way of life, but the dough at Pequod's didn't do it for me. I know this is blasphemy to Chicagoans, but Lou's was better as a whole. Same basic elements except Lou's sauce had salt and seasoning (Pequods was just tomato, very natural, a tad sweet), more gooey cheese, and a better crust (more common to me). The elements just came together better for a more gooey, garlicky pizza that wanted to be a lasagna. Lou's was our winner.

Had a small cheese deep dish pizza. It's the first deep dish I've ever had and I think it might not be for me. I didn't like the crust. It was too soft in the center and the edge was too hard to eat. It was not buttery, flaky and crispy like others described at all. Also, I think there was too little tomato sauce. 3 stars because the cheese taste good. Overall, I didn't like the ratio of crust, cheese and tomato sauce.
Quintessential Chicago pizza. Rumored to be the first deep dish. Maybe, maybe not, but they certainly have the recipe. Expect to wait but expect to enjoy yourself

Other than BJs, I've never had a deep dish pizza! We ordered the small pepperoni and it was more than enough for two people. Would i go back for seconds, yes! We even ordered pizza online and had it shipped over!

Whenever I'm asked by "out of town" people where to go for the best Chicago pizza, I say Lou Malnati's.  The deep dish pizza is my absolute favorite in the city!  The Lou Malnati's salad is also a must!!!!  They don't take reservations but the wait is never that bad!  You can always have a drink at the bar and relax:)  I've been here so many times I've lost count!
