Obviously being from New York City, we had to try the deep dish pizza. There's a great spot in NYC called Emmett's which is a Chicago based bar with deep dish, but I need to try the real thing. We started with cheese bread before we ordered our pizza. I did think it was a little too much to have right before eating more bread and cheese after, but the pizza takes about 40 minutes so we wanted to nibble on something. It comes with a marinara dipping sauce and was very good. We ordered a pie with sausage and pepperoni. I would have to say I do like NYC pizza better than the deep dish in Chicago. The best part though about deep dish is the meats. Each bite was covered in meats. The crust was also very tasty. It's definitely a more filling feeling you have when eating this type of pizza. Overall, was a great pizza experience and I would have no doubts that deep dish will help my pizza crave we all suffer from.

I ordered a personal sized deep dish and a salad for delivery tonight, and probably won't be ordering from here again. The pizza was decent, which is why I gave 3 stars, but the salad dressing was completely spilled in the bag. Not only did it make a mess, but I didn't have any dressing for my salad...

The pizza is exceptional! This was my first time having deep dish and I had one slice of the Classic and the Lou. I liked veggie pizzas more so I enjoyed the Lou more. Why 3 stars? The service. They had SOOOOO many staff members and they all seemed unorganized. We had a party of 5 and for whatever reason the party of 4 for seated before us with no wait but we had to wait about 10 mins to get seated. We were all hangry (hungry and angry) so we ordered ahead of time in hope of having the pizza semi ready by the time we got seated. We sat down and our waitress was pretty inattentive. Our drinks went empty quite often and the table of 5 females that sat down after us had their pizzas before us. We waited about 50 mins from the time we ordered until we got our food. I would suggest coming here when you aren't super hungry because you'll be waiting a while! Too many staff members with too much confusion amongst them! There's no reason to have 3 bus boys cleaning one table or 5 hostess at the hostess stand.

Went here with a group last week, a few from out of town.  So where do you take someone from out of town, Lou Malnati's of course.  Everyone loved the pizzas!  Stuffed spinach bread and comb. platters are great starters.  Malnati's salad is goes along great with the pizzas.  Never been disappointed.

Omg.......... Amazing pizza.. Long long wait with a great solution of ordering before you're seated. Beer on tap. TV around the bar. Lots of seating and great for families/ parties.  This pizza was highly recommended and it did not disappoint. Two pizzas.. 4 beers ... $50. Such a great deal.

Being a Chicago native, this place is one of my faves and must-go places when I'm back in town.  Living on the East Coast, I miss the Chicago flavor and heartiness that represents my city!  The chocolate chip cookie dessert is right on point after a delicious pizza.  And no, when I come back to Chicago, my diet is on splurge-mode so you won't here me concerned about calories.

This place seems like a tourist trap...and I don't care! I wanted deep dish pizza, and I got what I came for and left satisfied! Super-friendly staff and a full bar added to my great experience of having a butter-crusted, saucy deep-dish pizza.

Excellent Chicago deep dish pizza!!! Always packed with a long line so either order for takeout or be prepared to wait. I recommend 1/2 "The Lou" and 1/2 "Malnati Chicago Classic" ... both so different and yummy!!

They don't take reservations so sometimes can be a pain for large groups but i thought the pizza was going to be over rated but surprisingly the experience, pizza, apps and service met our expectations and were up to par! I'm not usually a huge fan of deep dish pizza but Lou Malnatis changed my mind :D glad i mustered up the courage to give this place a try.  (for people who love thin crust pizza they also have a few of them so its easy to mix it up and order a few thin and crispy and deep dish to share for the table)

I had low expectations coming here, but obviously we had to try deep dish while we're in Chicago no matter what. I've had deep dish from Zachary's in California (which I've heard is pretty authentic) and I've always just thought it was ok.  We looked up a couple spots, but this standard and in a central location. There was a wait, but you can order your pizza ahead of time, which is awesome! They got it down to science. A bunch of the pizzas looked pretty good but we stuck with their special--gotta go with the classic to set expectations. So I ordered ahead of time, and they said they'd get a head start but it'd still be 10-15 after we're seated for the pizza to be ready. I thought that was reasonable and great that they did that.  The deep dish pizza itself. OMG so good! The crust was really good and buttery, it was not overly saucy. Good flavor, everything worked together really well. It's different than your traditional pizza, but I really liked it! Definitely hefty, there's a lot of cheese, all of it was yummy. Loved the crust.  Also, I thought the prices were really affordable. It was like $15 for 2 of us and it kept us nice and full! Definitely exceeded my expectations, it's good. I'm a fan of the Chicago deep dish!

When it comes to deep dish pizza you can do better. When it comes to pizza in general you can do way better. When it comes to...ok you get it. This place does the job if you're in Lincoln square area and can't leave and want deep dish. I have no major complaints about cleanliness, staff or environment (they bumped it up from 0 to 2 stars) but the food is just meh.
Really good gluten free pizza if you have an allergy problem. I've had it several times and its delicious and trustworthy.
Lou's always deserves a visit when you are looking for the BEST Chicago DEEP Dish. The thin crust is very good also, and highly recommended.
Food was good. Even if you pre-order, you have to wait 20 minutes at the table. Good to know.

Standard great Chicago deep dish and even thin crust. I added the jalapeños to my personal size deep dish for extra spice and it was awesome. The 312 beer was refreshing. I highly recommend the stuffed spinach bread for an appetizer.

I wasn't a fan of Lou Malnati's until they moved into the Oak Park community.  I have to say, I now enjoy their thin crust, one-topping pizza, as I like it simple.  I also love the ambiance of the dining area which can accommodate small or large parties. The sliding doors makes it fun to dine during the summer, especially when you want the feeling of dining al fresco. I recently discovered their "back door store" which offers half-baked and frozen pizzas.  Great addition to the Oak Park community.

This place has changed my mind about deep dish pizza and the most amazing part is that it changed my sisters mind as well. I was here for a short three day weekend and came here on two of the days because it was that good! My sister has been to Chicago a few times and has tried other places and didn't like deep dish at all, after trying this spot she likes deep dish again! Their ingredients are fresh, the crust is buttery and my personal favorite pie is the "Lou" which is pretty much a veggie pie that comes loaded with fresh tomatoes and etc, I have tried the minatti Chicago classic on the second day after reading reviews on Yelp and I thought it wasn't bad, the sausage was yummy and it's slightly more salty compared to the Lou but still a delicious pie itself for those who love sausages. The only downside is the wait for the pizza is 30-45 minutes but I would still recommend everyone to come try this. I considered going to Gino's on the second day but the prices for their pie was ridiculous and I would rather get two pies from Lou's with toppings compared to one pie from Gino's that is just a plain cheese pie. Oh yea the personal pie is really enough to feed three people! So if you are going with two or three people I would recommend getting two personal pies just to try the different toppings and share !

Had the chance to try Lou's and Giordano's to compare and Lou's is by a long shot my favorite! Beat Gio's out of the water big time. Seriously thinking about ordering some online to have sent here in Hawaii haha. I love deep dish pizza!!! Lou's FTW!!!

So I lived in Chicago since 1990 and never stepped foot into this restaurant. First off, I am not a huge fan of pizza.. I know!! What!!! I recently had family members visit from overseas and they wanted to try traditional Chicago favorites. What better place to take them to then Lou Malnati's for the deep dish pizza. I read the reviews here on Yelp and I knew we were looking at over 1hr wait to be seated since they do not take reservations. After 1hr & 20 minutes, we finally got seated. I know! This better be the best pizza in the world.  We ordered for starters the calamari, caesar salad, cheese bread with dipping sauce, and a bottle of red wine. The calamari and the caesar salad were fantastic. We could have done without the cheese bread. We ordered 3 medium pizzas. The Lou, The Malnati Chicago Classic, and The Sausage thin crust pizza. Hands down, The Thin Crust Sausage Pizza was the top favorite for our table of 5 people. The 2nd choice was The Malnati Chicago Classic. The Lou, we could have done without. The crust is amazing good. So buttery and it just melts in your mouth good. The pizzas are very filling, so we ended up taking 1 1/2 pizza's home.  Overall it was a good experience. Was it worth the wait? Yes. Would I do it again, probably not, but I would order for pick-up or delivery next time.
It's better than pizzeria Due and Uno. I think the crust is the same as pizzeria uno and due. But I like the topping better. I haven't been to Gino's yet so I can't really compare.
Very good pizza. We had a grope of 9 and they was on time and good service.  I'll come back anytime.

The only reason I give this pizzeria 2 stars is the appetizer and pizza were quite good. This being said, we looked forward to ordering dessert. However, after dropping off the appetizer, our server, Gloria, never came back, not even to check for refills (we wanted more wine). After we waited a half an hour with empty glasses and plates, I finally flagged Gloria down. At that point, we still planned on more drinks and desserts. However, Gloria was rude and dismissive, losing money for the business and herself.

Went there with high expectations but felt disappointed, the wait for both seating and food were way too long, so be prepared if you go there with an empty stomach. The pizza itself was okay, didn't wow me. Average experience!
I would like to compliment the Lou Malnatis salad, very tasty the dressing was sweet and perfect the right amount of toppings already tossed.

When visiting the University of Chicago I polled the faculty where to find the best deep dish and Lou Malnati's was the number one answer.  We have The Uno's chain by my house (Probably it is not the same as the original in Chicago) so wanted something a little more Chicagoan.  Coming from Jersey where pizzarias are as commonplace as the tourist at the shore looking for Snooky and JWow, needless to say we are Pizza snobs. I ordered the Malnati's Chicago Classic.  The sauce was savory with chunks of tomato, the cheese was a melted stringy mozzarella gooeyness, the sausage was juicy and the deep dish buttery pie crust was crisp and tasty.  Definitely worth going to if in the area and never had a deep dish.  I gave it 3 stars because service was just okay and the pizza while delicious did not wow me.  Next time I will try the other two big deep dish names in Chicago.

I have been dying to try this pizza for years and I just moved to the area from Los Angeles.  I decided to just order a simple thin crust cheese pizza because we are staying in a hotel, and didn't have a fridge.  I know they aren't known for thin, but this should be a pretty easy item for a place known for pizza.  Crust was pretty bland and overall have had better frozen pizzas.  Was a total let down!

Love! This is my go-to place when I arrive in town. This is my second location I have been to and both have been packed to capacity both in the main room and bar.  I recommend looking at the menu beforehand and ordering an app while putting your initial order because a true deep-dish pizza takes approx. 45 minutes to create. With this being said, an app is truly a tease (cheese bread was delicious) while waiting for the main dish (Malnati Chicago classic) to arrive.  The pizza was stuffed with lean sausage, extra cheese and vine-ripened tomatoes was delicious as the cheese was oozing out and crust was buttered as well. If you are going for two, getting the small is the way to go as we both barely completed eating (being 1/2 thick). I recommend this place and another as I have been to three different deep dish places in the city and commend on the staff for their honest opinions and great service. As I said earlier, I love this place and will return in the future.

Good food, HORRIBLE service. Our waitress, Gloria, stopped to see how we were after the appetizer arrived and never stopped again. After 45 minutes we finally flagged her down and she was defensive, rude and dismissive when we asked for some service. We would have loved some more wine, water and to try the desserts but were sick of waiting. Poorly played, Gloria.

I am a huge fan of pizza, but I cannot handle deep dish. I mean seriously thats not even pizza.  You don't cook pizza in a skillet. If you like deep dish though, its great.  Great family place, and not too expensive

After reading reviews on Yelp and seeing where the stars like to eat, we decided on this place. I was looking forward to having really Chicago style deep dish. We got there before the crowd. and ordered the signature salad and pizza. The salad was HANDS DOWN THE BEST. the house made sweet vinaigrette was so deliciously tasty and mouth watering that I couldn't wait to try the pizza (you can buy the dressing in a bottle!). The pizza came after about 40 mins. it looked tasty and gooey. But I was disappointed from the first bite. The house made lean sausage was terrible. it had not flavor and didn't bring anything to the pizza. The cheese was way to thick (who says that!). It was like eating a mozzarella cheese stick, not the business on pizza. and the tomatoes on the top was a very thin coat that also lacked in flavor. No amount of salt or parmesan cheese was going to make this pizza better.  The whole table was truly disappointed with this pizza. The only reason this place got 1 star was the salad which I wish I could have more. We wont be coming back.......

After some careful consideration, I have dropped down the number of stars this place deserves from four to two.  There are many reasons for this, and I will elaborate.   The GF and I came here at a not so busy time; after lunch, but no quite time for dinner.  We were seated in the back room with two other parties, despite plenty of room in the front.  Our server greeted us and took our drink orders.  We looked at the menu and decided on the spinach stuffed bread and the small pepperoni and mushroom deep dish pizza.  Our server told us the pizza would take 45 minutes to bake.  At first, I thought he was joking, but soon realized he was serious.  45 minutes for a pizza to cook is a bit excessive.  It is a really good way to get customers to order more food though.  By the time they finish eating all the appetizers and salads, they will be too full for the pizza.   The stuffed spinach bread came out in less than ten minutes.  It tasted great, maybe because we were so hungry.  The bread was soft, and as you ripped a piece off, cheese oozed out.  It was seasoned perfectly, and was devoured in a quicker time than it did to bake the thing.   The pizza did in fact take nearly 45 minutes to make its way to our table.  By now, the dining room had filled up quite a bit.  The pizza tasted good, but the amount of time waiting, really hyped up my expectations.  The expectations fell short once reality hit.  It was just an average tasting pizza once the high wore down.  For dessert, we shared the chocolate chip pizza.  We decided to tell our server to put the order in while we were still eating the pizza for fear that it would take forever to come out.  Good thing we did though, because it did take quite a bit of time.  The heat from the cookie paired perfectly with the cold ice cream.   In conclusion, I clearly did not enjoy waiting 45 minutes for my pizza even when there were hardly any other patrons dining.  I just can't seem to fathom that it actually takes that long for the pizza to cook.  It is absolutely mind boggling.  They were pretty stingy on the toppings too.    As my first deep dish experience in Chicago, this place was a let down.  One up side of our experience was that the service was great, and our guy was super friendly and helpful.   I would recommend going to Pequod's Pizzeria instead, which we tried the next day.  Their pizza was hands down the best pizza I have ever had.  It took less than half the time for their pizza to make its way to our table.
Best pizza in Chicago period! And that's all I have to say about that. Don't waste your time looking for another great pizza joint
Loved the pizza!  Loved the atmosphere, and the pizza was worth the wait ( 45 minutes).  I am thinking about ordering a pizza in the mail.

Out of Towner here. Obvious tourist. Came in here at 9pm after a long flight and long train ride on the "L". They promised a 15-25 minute wait and they delivered. They take down your cell # and give you a call AND a text which I appreciate.  You can always get drinks at the bar while you wait which makes the wait much shorter! You can order right after you let the hostess know how many people you need for your table and they'll get your pizza started for you right then and there.  Super highly recommend the Malnati Chicago Classic --- best deep dish pizza I have ever had. It was just my husband and myself so we could barely finish a personal size.  We also had the "Lou" but if you can only eat one -- get the classic.  Make sure to get the spinach stuffed bread --- it's really mozzarella with a tinge of spinach but I ain't complaining. Sooooo delicious.  Grab some Goose Islands, sit down, and have some really good pizza!!

Visiting Chicago from Oregon, and looking to see what all the hub bub is about, Chicago deep dish pizza. Lou Malnati's was strongly recommended by staff at my hotel. I am now a believer. Best pizza I have ever had. From excellent customer service, to fantastic food, I will only order pizza from Lou Malnati's when I return to Chicago. Order, relax and enjoy. You won't be disappointed.

My friend's favorite place for pizza.  I'm definitely a fan of the deep dish here.  The only reason I give it a four instead of a five is because it's not particularly unique or different than any of the other very respectable Chicago deep dish locations in the city.  I love when a restaurant is clearly able to differentiate themselves and Lou Malnati's could easily be the same as any of the other dominant pizza places.

I'm from NYC, and Lou Malanati's is the only Chicago deep dish pizza I would consider as an equal to NY thin crust. This pizza is seriously amazing - the perfect combination and proportions of crust, sauce, toppings, and cheese. My go-to is always the Sausage, peppers and onions deep dish. It's so heart and delicious. And honestly, just as good as leftovers in the morning - is it sad that I always order extras just to have some the next day? If you manage to save room for dessert, the deep dish cookie is delicious too.

A good friend recommended us to try this pizzeria. The place is a great. Everything you would want in a restaurant including sports bar. Wide variety, fresh ingredients, friendly and attentive staff. Try deep dish pizza and salad. They get really busy though and walk in wait is long (must be good sign) so book your reservation ahead of time. You will not regret going here.

Don't hurt me but I am not a huge fan of deep dish.  I came to Lou a few years ago and was deeply sadden about the quality of my pizza. Went back recently and the quality was much better. But I am still not a huge fan. None the less, the food was fresh, flavorful and tastey.... still like my nyc pizza
I've ordered carryout from this location a few times and the wait is 45-60 minutes, which is pretty standard for this area. Good food, good service- and their Malnati Salad is excellent!

What can I say, a first time deep dish eater, the sauce and sausage were amazing. The crust was crunchy and the cheese gushed out like it does in commercials. The staff and waitress were absolutely amazing. I even tried the salad, with italitan salami bacon bit things...needless to say I am a tourist, I haven't had all the deep dish Chicago has to offer, but this was the best possible way to be introduced!

Anytime we mentioned pizza in Chicago all the locals said we had to go to Lou's. We knew there would be a wait, which we had no problem with, but there was a 30 minute wait JUST to get your name on the list. The hostess was very friendly but the tablet she we was using to take down names was running super slow and backed up a line out the building. It was very inefficient and took away time we could have been at the bar. Once finally seated the pizza took 40 minutes to cook so by that time we were starving and anticipating the  best pizza ever! Unfortunately when it arrived it was boarder line cold, but I could have seen past it if the flavor was there. The sauce reminded me of canned pizza sauce as Prego and overall was not memorable. We'll definitely try another pizza place next time around.

This Lou Malnati's location is spacious and looks like a classic family style restaurant. The walls are adorned with Chicago sports memorabilia, really giving it that hometown flare. As for the pizza, it was delicious. No argument about it. We ordered The Malnati Chicago Classic and added some onions and hot giardinera to it. Everything complimented itself in this pie, and the crust had a solid doughy bite. I would have wanted just a little more sauce though. Because I had not tried any other Chicago style pizza at the time I tried Lou Malnati's I felt it wasn't fair to give it the full five stars. Plus, the server waiting our table was not as attentive as he could have been. Other than taking our order and bringing our food, he checked on us maybe about one more time. It was somewhat busy and I understand but I noticed other tables were getting just a little more attention than ours.  All in all, this is one pizza chain everyone should try. There's a reason why people wait around to get a table.

Not great pizza. I didn't care for their pizza sauce at all. Tasted more like tomato sauce-- no spices and things. Super disappointed that I wasted a meal in Chicago on this pizza. The buffalo wings were really great. Oreat flavor. Should have just had a couple orders if those.

5 stars for the meal I just had. Disclaimer: I am not a Chicagoan nor do I consider myself knowledgable about deep-dish pizza. But this was a damn good meal. Lucked into it on a short trip with the family to see the sights around the Chicago Loop. We knew we wanted to eat the local version of pizza and were staying close to several spots that make the lists for being "the best". I thought our decision was down to choosing between Pizzeria Uno or Due but the hotel front door guy told me to go to Lou's. At first I thought he was kidding because I couldn't find a place for pizza named "Lou's". He took pity on me when he realized I had no idea what he was talking about and told me it was short for Lou Malnati's. He told me that it was further away but the walk and wait in line would be worth it. His endorsement sold me when he said, "I think it's da best and I'm from Chicago." Found it without too much trouble and it had a 45 min wait for a table. Thought I was going to die from hunger while waiting since it smelled so good when we checked in. The wait was worth it. Got a great Malnati Salad to share and the Malnati Chicago Classic pizza which is described as extra sausage and tomato on a deep dish butter crust. The description does not do it justice because extra sausage in this case came out looking like a deep dish pain with a sausage manhole cover over it hidden by cheese. Unbelievable, huge, and tasty all at the same time! It was so over the top that I could only take down 1.5 pieces in my hypoglycemic state. The setting is loud with a lot of sports memorabilia on the walls and the wait really sucks. But who really cares about that stuff when the real attraction is getting to stuff your pie hole full of that amazing pizza.
My second favorite deep dish spot next to Pizano's

The best pizza in Chicago. I consider myself a pizza connoisseur, I do enjoy then crust New York style pizza. Chicago deep dish pizza it was in a league all on its own. Lou's deep dish pizza is by far the best deep dish pizza and Chicago. I will give them the greatest praise on the freshness of their ingredients.
Deep dish was good.  40min wait was tough for a small deep dish pizza that came out medium temperature.  The buttery crust great Service was friendly but slow on a Wednesday at 4:00

Go for the Pizza. Deep Dish or thin crust doesn't matter. Butter Crust or regular, doesn't matter. It's all so good. Don't bother with salads or any sides because they aren't very good, but why you would order a salad at Lou Malnati's is beyond me.  We've ordered delivery and it was great and didn't take more than the estimated time, and we've sat down in the restaurant which took a little long for our liking. Butttt it was worth the wait, and there was a cubs game on so, nuff said. Can't go wrong with Lous.

As a visitor from Boston, there is only one place I have to go every time I go to Chicago.  Lou Malnati's is the real deal deep dish.  I get the classic lou, which is everything you want in a true deep dish.  Classic crust, lots of cheese, tasty sausage, and a tomato sauce I wish I could take home with me. (You can actually order these pizzas frozen and get them ups to you)  They also have great gluten free options, my girlfriend got the crustless which is basically a classic lou with a sausage base instead of crust.  Make sure to get there ahead of time as you have to order before you are seated due to the amount of time it takes.  The wait is worth every bite though.  Don't bother with the pretenders.  Lou's is the only deep dish I'll ever eat in Chicago.  Period.
First time trying deep dish pizza and I love it . Customer service was great. Definitely worth a try.

Although this place has really great reviews I have to say, I think it's mediocre. And it's not just because I'm from New York and love NY style pizza. I tried Gino's deep dish and thought it was a lot more impressive. This pizza was not bad but it didn't blow me away either- I probably wouldn't return given the many options of pizza in the area.

Lou's has the best Chicago style pizza in the city. A great place to take out of town guests who crave this kind of pizza.  They also offer lots of options for people that need a break from Chicago style. The salad is actually my favorite item on the menu, passing the pizza.  Give it a shot if you are traveling in from out of town!

A great place to grab some pizza! But expect to wait at least 40 minutes for a table. That was the only exception but the wait was well worth it. The bar was quite small. When we got seated, we ordered a large thin crust cheese pizza and a half cheese half sausage pizza. I have to say it was the pizza in Chicago. Especially, you are going to run the Chicago Marathon.  It's a great place to store up your energy food.  The server was quite friendly. I highly recommend this pizza restaurant while in Chicago. I give it two thumbs up! Enjoy! #SeñorFood

Butter crust is good but the pizza isn't deep enough. Not enough cheese.  It's like diet deep dish.   It is a Chicago classic and there are two deep dish camps for me I prefer a more cheesey and deeper style but others love this style.  For anyone into exploring Chicago deep dish Lou's is a must but it isn't my personal favorite.

Warning: I'm an outsider. This was my first time visiting Chicago. Obviously, I had to try one of the famous, highly rated, traditional Chicago deep dish from Lou's.  My understanding of Chicago pizza is that there are three main types: deep dish, pan pizza, and stuffed pizza. Lou's is dd. I thought the Malnati Chicago Classic (sausage, cheese, crushed tomato, butter crust) was very good. It had a natural tomato flavor, with a nice helping of cheese along an interesting "butter crust". The sausage brought very little to the equation, lacking flavor but adding texture. The crust is much different (and not comparable to other types of pizza). This type of crust has a crumbly effect it, almost cornmealy, which holds everything together well. I would not say its my favorite type of pizza, and it certainly is not the best I have ever had; but it is a different spin on pizza, and it is good if you can accept it for its differences.
Best Chicago pizza in town! The crust on these pies is buttery and delicious. Also serves excellent salads.

This was my first experience tasting authentic Chicago Deep Dish and it was HEAVEN! The butter crust was so amazing the entire bottom layer of Italian sausage was genius. The sauce had great flavor. This pizza was so great I had it three times during my weeklong visit to Chicago. Can't wait until next time!

Pizza was good but service was terrible, the waiter was terrible and we had a friend who couldn't eat cheeses. They didn't allow her to change any of the thin crust pizzas to have no cheese,  and the chicken sandwich was sad. Don't recommend, deep dish pizza isn't that special anyway

What I got: Malnati Chicago Classic The Lou's What I thought: Rated as one of the top (if not the top) deep dish pizza joint in Chicago so it's a must try. I came here with a fairly large group so we ordered 2 medium sized deep dish pizzas and it really hit the spot! Flavors were definitely on point and serving sizes were perfect as well. The Malnati Chicago Classic is made with their Lou's lean sausage, some extra cheese and vine-ripened tomato sauce on a butter crust. This was probably my favorite of the two. Can never go wrong with a classic meat pizza.  The Lou's is more of a veggie style. I believe it had cheese, spinach, and mushrooms? Not bad either, but I'm a meat on pizza kind of guy so it wasn't my favorite.  All the toppings tasted fresh and the crust was crisp as can be. One thing about Malnati's is that even though it is a deep dish pizza, it holds together very well. I've been to several other deep dish pizza places where the entire pizza just falls apart when you eat it, but at Lou Malnati's the pizza is well composed. At other places, don't even think about picking it up and eating it with your hands, you need a knife and fork, but at Malnati's you can pick it up perfectly find and the crispy delicious buttery crust holds everything together like a champ! There's a few locations down in Chicago, so if you get a chance swing by and grab a bite of their famous pizza with that buttery crust!

Came here during the ridiculously busy dinner rush and was seated in about 30 minutes. They take your pizza order when you put your name in so it comes shortly after you are actually seated - great planning on their part. Pro tip: try to get a table in the back so that you aren't surrounded by the noisy crowd around the bar and folks trying to get their names / orders in. We got a Malanati's Salad (the salami bits taste quite a lot like bacon bits) and a small Lou pizza. The pizza was fantastic. Everything I could have wanted out of a true Chicago deep dish pizza. Highly recommend, but as there are many other locations, perhaps trying a different, less touristy/busy area might be a better option!

First: I don't do five star reviews! But this place is the bomb! Dinner for two for under $30, really?! And the food was fantastic. Try the classic dish pizza with sausage cheese and butter crust. This is unbelievably delicious. They don't skimp here. We also threw in a Caesar salad for less than nine dollars and it included chicken! All this with family atmosphere timely friendly service and a taste of Chicago that I'll never forget. Thanks Lou
Great deep dish pizza, but you can really go back with cheese and bread, long queues though!... So no difference other than branding to other deep dish pizza

Deep dish pizza is a must have when visiting Chicago, especially for a first timer like me! And of course we had to eat at this renowned establishment.  Came to Lou's on a weeknight at 530pm so we could avoid the long wait. Friendly servers and a nice ambiance. By 630, the place was filled with people.  I love me some pizza, but I don't think deep dish is my style. 30-40 minute wait for the pizza to be made fresh & hot, yet when the pizza arrived it was rather cold. We ordered the "Lou" and "chicago Classic". Solid choices, but found that the pizza fell apart quite easy.  Deep dish is a classic Chicago must have, but I prefer New York style pizza or just pizza that doesn't fall apart easy. We also ordered wings and salad (way over dressed) and they were just average.

This lives up to the hype !! We tried to come for dinner but it was jam packed and a 45 minute wait so we decide decided to go back the next day for lunch. We went back the next day and were seated immediately ! We knew the deep dish takes a while so we order bruschetta , minestrone soup and I ordered a small dinner salad which was pretty big ! My friend ordered a personal cheese but my other friend and I got the "Lou" oh my god - heaven the butter crust is out of this world the first bite was a divine tasting explosion ! This place lives up to the hype please do yourself a favor and come here you won't regret it for dessert we shared a peach cobbler with vanilla ice cream it was perfect as we were all stuffed prices are very reasonable too. Our waiter was great too !
Love it!  Best deep dish in the city. The staff is super friendly.  The service is outstanding. Not much more I can say.  I strongly recommend.  This is a Chicago favorite!

I thought this place was amazing! The pizza tastes amazing, the waiters are very attentive, and its not too far out of the way.  We had a spinach pie and the famous pie. Both were good. The spinach pie was lighter than expected, which was great considering the heaviness of the sausage pie. The butter crust is definitely worth it, it adds so much more flavor and grease. You do not come here expecting a healthy meal.  Be advised that the pizzas are made to order and take a long time. We pre ordered our pies and it still took us a 40 minute wait before getting them to our table. In the meantime we had Caesar salad, which was okay and overdressed.
It's my favorite of the Chicago deep dish pizzerias.  To each their own, of course, but I'm a fan.  Always get the Malnati Chicago Classic (and share with friends, of course!)

When in Chicago, one must try a Chicago deep dish pizza! ... so we relied on Yelpers and they didn't steer us wrong!  It was good to know that the pizza's take a while (30-40 minutes per most Yelpers) so we started with a Spinach Salad with the goat cheese and balsamic vinaigrette on the side with tomatos.  Our waiter Jaime was super friendly, welcoming and helpful when we asked for menu suggestions.  We decided on two personal pizzas: the Chicago Classic and a Custom Spinach mix (spinach, garlic, onions & basil) on the buttercrust.  The pizza's did take about 30 minutes but definitely worth the wait. The buttercrust was like no other pizza crust we've ever had.  Not doughey and filling but crusty/crunchy much like a corn meal crust.  Loved it!  The toppings were very well distributed, not too heavy on the cheese or meat.  We both had tap water for drinks and the bill (without) tip was $29.84.  Can't beat that!  We're fans!

I was shocked at how plain and terrible the pizza was at Lou Malnat's. I have had Chicago style pizza other places before so I was really expecting something amazing at one of the most famous places in Chicago. The cheese was extra rubbery, the sausage was dry, the only good thing was the bread and the sauce. The line was also out the door expect about a 1 hour wait at a minimum. The prices are however reasonable but the cost of the pizza can't be much. I would say try another "authentic" spot this place does not deliver yelpers.
Well, we went with the thin crust...and it was delish. I know you are supposed to get the deep dish here, but what if you don't love deep dish?
Good deep dish pizza, service was ok.  It is a must go to when visiting the Windy City.  The kids liked the dessert, didn't eat much pizza though.

Absolutely amazing deepdish. just really exemplary. The wait is a while, but super worth it and they let you pre order (so part of it gets cooked before hand and it gets put in the oven to finish once you get seated) to maximize efficiency. The sauce is tangy, chunky and perfect. The cheese is obviously amazing but not overwhelming, and not bland. and of course- the buttercrust. BUTTER CRUST. please i do not need to say anymore. Obviously I could go on and on about how amazing their pizza is and etc, but you should know why it's worth the wait- the service is spectacular, friendly, and despite how busy it is, doesn't rush you. Also, for those out of towners... they deliver frozen pizza's. Needless to say they will definitely be getting an order from Philly soon enough :)

We stopped by this location as it was in the area close by the Doughnut Vault to pick up a small 9" pizza for two, which consisted of 4 slices of pizza.  It took 30 minutes to make from the moment you place the order, so we were lucky to have one person in the car (street parking is $2 per 30 minutes or so) and the other person waiting for the food.We chose to sample their Chicago's Classic Small Pan deep dish with butter crust for ~$16 and thought the toppings were just A-OK.  The crust definitely won us over, but the presentation and toppings did not blow us out of the water. We picked to have lunch at the Millennium Park close by, so maybe if we dined in next time our opinion will change.

I don't normally leave reviews on yelp, but I thought I should warn anyone considering this restaurant that it will take a sizable chunk of your night. In addition to the upfront wait for a table, it takes them forever to do anything, from serving your food to serving the check. All in all, we got there at 6:30, were seated at 8:00, and left at 9:15, and it doesn't seem like our experience is atypical. The food is good, but it's not worth the time it takes to eat it.

Fresh order nationally delivered for the best of deep dish pizza. Perfectly crispy pie crust with texture layered skim milk cheese. Sauce on top. I may just turn it into a personal pan it's so delicious.

Lou Malnati's always wins in the "best Chicago pizza" debate in my house. They have the most buttery crust and best chunky tomato sauce. I also think it keeps and reheats better than the others. I also appreciate that they offer a lower-fat cheese option (even if it sounds kind of silly, given the amount consumed in a slice!) Anyway, their classics are great, and the spinach is one of my all-time favorites. I also love that you can ship it--which we ordered numerous times when we moved from Chicago for a few years! Yum!!
The best pizza we have ever had. A long wait but very worth it!!  The pizza is very flavorful!! Hands down would recommend to anyone!!

I ordered a pepperoni mushrooms and olives  pizza I ask them  to make half with jalapeños the  covered the whole pizza  with jalapeños the girl told me that will take 45 min for delivery .. It took 1 hour 15 min and the worst pizza was cold .. I'm lucky that I have microwave first time I ordered and the last ..
This place has officially converted me from a thin crust NY style pizza to a deep dish lover!!! Get the classic, it's unreal!

We had a large Chicago Classic and it lived up to its name in a big way. The crust was just right - well proofed, just enough butteriness and cornmeal, and reasonably thin to perfect the texture. The sauce was what you hope for but rarely get with a great tomato pop. The beer selection is good and the service was outstanding. Every local chain has some locations better than others but this one is where you want to take your New York friends and settle the rivalry.

This is by far our favorite pizza in Chicago.  We lucked out and got there right before the masses hit on Sunday night around 6 p.m. The pizza is perfectly balanced,  unlike Uno which has too much dough. We ordered a large for 4 people and couldn't finish it,  but we sure tried.  Had the Classic,  which was delicious!
Food was very good. Deep dish was okay. I expected more given all the reviews.

Of course, I won't take off stars for waiting for forever but hey it's Chicago and it's worth it! The service was great and they cut your pizza when it arrives so that's cool. The pizza took about 30 minutes to arrive which is normal since it's a deep dish pizza and they are PACKED! I wasn't that hungry when I went but hell I had to have more than one slice -- the first bite sold me and I kept going. My friends and I got the Lou pizza which is the most original I guess, but there nothing simple about it! The cheese melted in my mouth so perfectly and it wasn't so hot (like you usually get) that you can't eat it right away. Totally recommend this place even with the wait -- TRUST ME.

I'm basically plagiarizing if I attempt to write an original review among 2100+ reviews, but here are my highlights from my siblings weekend getaway to Chitown. The 45 minute wait on a beautiful Saturday evening in Chicago was expected, but definitely worth it. The staff was super friendly upon arrival, and they even let you place an order when you put your name in. That way the wait time once you're seated is cut in half. The pizza was a monstrosity, and every bit as delicious as it looked. We also had a side of ravioli with meat sauce. That was also great, as it kept all but a few happy giggles from my 10-month old nephew. We stuck with the ravioli for him, because we decided the pizza should be reserved for people who are actually making memories. I also recently found out that "Buttercrust" is apparently trademarked. And for good reason. I'm a snobby mcsnobster from the East Coast, so I'm all about the quality of pizza crust, and Lou's nails it. If the east coast falls into the ocean, Chicago is looking like a decent alternative...

Don't really understand the hype around this pizza.  I guess the crust is ok, but the sauce was pretty flavorless.  We tried the Chicago Classic but chose the crumbled sausage instead of a huge patty covering the entire pizza circumference.  Meh.

This place lives up to the hype, it's a kick back pizza place to enjoy some authentic pizza. You can really tell they only use fresh ingredients; nothing processed or artificial. Don't be upset about the wait time to get food, it warns you on the menu that it takes about 30min, remember this is REAL pizza, not Dominos/Pizza Hut.

You can tell when a place uses fresh ingredients and it's evident once you take the first bite. The cheese tastes like authentic real cheese and the sauce is delicious. The crust has a crunch to it as it should and the pepperoni was sliced thicker and more tastier than other places. You can expect great attentive service and is a good lunch spot.
Best pizza in the city - stuffed with sausage is the way to go

What a great way to start off the first day in Chicago with this place! After a half hour walk to this place, I sat at the bar and the staff was courteous and attentive, even though it was packed and drink orders for drinks kept flying in. The pizza definitely took the 30 minutes, as promised on the menu but well worth it! Being a huge fan of my native New York style pizza, I really did enjoy this classic Chicago style pizza. The tomatoes were plump and sweet, the cheese was nice and gooey, but not overloading the whole masterpiece and the crust was just amazing! I got the personal size and that was all I needed to satisfy my craving! I may even go back to pick up their frozen pizza to take back home to NY.
Still the best deep dish around. Very affordable because the pizzas are big enough to share. Also have great salads.

Definitely some of the best pizza I've ever had. We made sure to get here early to avoid the lines, and we're glad we did, because it takes close to an hr to make the food.  Highly recommend getting their amazing salad while you wait.

Place was fantastic. Beat the rush by an hour as the place has no reservations and when we were leaving there was about a 2 hour wait. Great deep dish pizza and appetizer meals.  Took a little while to get our drinks however, a small price to pa my for great meal.

After tasting Gino's East and Giordano's, I knew the best big thing to round out the trio was a pie at Lou Malnati's. And man I do have some mixed opinions on this. Again, in accordance with my deep dish factorial analysis, I gotta judge it based on the crust, sauce, cheese + toppings, and ratios. How do we break this down? Crust: Lou Malnati's takes on a close second to Giordano's for sure, but barring anything else they are both essentially equal. Flaky and crispy butter crust, never burnt. I will knock on the fact that typically because Lou's and Gino's has smaller pizzas than Giordano's, the ratio of dough to ingredients seems to be greater. Still crispy and delicious though. Sauce: I actually prefer the flavor of the sauce at Lou's compared to Giordano's, but much prefer the consistency of Giordano's(which just seems fresher with larger chunks of tomato). The sauce at Lou's is a bit sweeter while still being spiced similarly(I'm a fan), but for the most part seemed like a paste rather than a more natural and made-to-order tomato sauce. We ordered two large pizzas, the Lou(Spinach mix, fresh tomatoes, 3 cheeses), and the Chicago classic(Sausage, extra cheese). Here is where I have mixed opinions. Despite the lack of meat, the Lou is probably one of my favorite deep dish pizzas in Chicago. The extra tomatoes and the fresh spinach mix really just makes it all taste vibrant, and the cheese with the sauce really just brings it all together in an oozing fatty mess of deliciousness. The Chicago Classic on the other hand....the plate of sausage was nice but I think I prefer the sausage at Giordano's(Lou's was about equal to Gino's in that respect). However the ratios of the Chicago classic were a bit off for my tastes: far too much cheese and crust and not enough sauce. In the end I sort of just wanted an extra side of sauce just so I could dip the extra cheesy bread. Overall verdict: Lou's can make some good pizza, and the namesake is there for a reason. As for the Chicago classic, if you want a meat based pizza I'd stick with just a regular pepperoni or sausage deep dish because the ratios will be a bit more favorable. Unless you're willing to say cheese.
This pizza was fabulous. We asked to sit outside, so we were seated right away. The pie was ready in about 45 minutes. Well worth the wait. Definitely a must try.
Pretty good buttery crust deep dish pizza Order the food ahead of time before you sit down since the pizzas take a long time to cook
Meh. Pizza was pretty decent but service was not good. Super slow and not that attentive on a Saturday night.

Great pizza, but was it worth the wait? I polled our 9 guests after we waited 2 hours for a table. We tried thin crust, deep dish butter, veggie and cheese. Everyone said yes, worth the wait to check the box that they have been here and tried it, but no, they would not come back on their next trip to Chicago. It was good, but not life changing. We had a great time and our waitress was amazing. If you can have Laura, get her! Sample the goods, check the box, say hello to the traveler next to you (because no one in here is a local) and enjoy your pizza.

Best pizza in all of Chicago! Absolutely worth the wait when you order...their sausage pizza is the best, in my opinion, but you can't go wrong with any topping you choose. The service is also great at any location - the wait staff is very attentive and quick to serve. Check them out!

Frankly, I don't know a damn thing about Chicago style pizza. This was my first time in Chicago, and damnit, I just felt like being a tourist for a little minute, so I ordered the famous pie. Ive had the contender too many times to count, but your not going to find Chicago style pizza in Charleston, so I took advantage of it while here for work.  I ordered delivery with no time to venture out and find it, and thankfully, there website is clean and efficient. Ordering a pie was super easy. No registration or signing up needed, which is smart because I would have skipped ordering from them.  They also provide a time that the pie will get to you which was very helpful because then I could plan accordingly to be upstairs when it arrived. Remarkably, it actually arrived within the time frame that was listed when I purchased it. Check check.  Take the handoff, and was not prepared for how heavy the thing was. This medium pie weighed some pounds..I couldnt help but laugh that I felt I was about to eat pounds of pizza. Open it up, its bulky, thick, heavy...its a lot. I ate a sliver of it, but honestly it didnt wow me. I really dont know what else to say about it. It was good, but not remarkable. I will say I am thankful they used real mushrooms and not canned--that is always worth noting. Im just going to chalk this up as the beginning and end to my Chicago pizza experience. It was also $30, so it is was coming back to South Carolina with me. For $30, I dont care how eh' it was, it was getting finished!

Unlike pretty much everyone else I didn't have any deep dish pizza here ... but I did have a deep dish cookie! I split his with a friend and enjoyed a cup of coffee with it. The cookie was perfect and it came topped with plenty of delicious vanilla ice cream. I really recommend this dessert. Service was very good and attentive too - which was impressive considering how mobbed the place was.
Best Pizza I've ever had!!! Pizza sauce was amazing and sooo many peperonis. Great prices too!!

When in Rome... eat Roman pizza. In the city for a conference and lacking any real knowledge of Chicago haute cuisine, I do the tourist thing and seek out two things: Chicago dogs and Chicago pizza. Having accomplished the former, I turn to Yelp to search out a reasonably well-rated place within walking distance of the conference. And thus I find Lou Malnati's, on whose shoulders I must place my entire opinion of Chicago-style pizza.  But I was not alone. I brought with me a friend from Russia who was also attending the conference, and I had the unlucky task of trying to explain this odd beast that vaguely resembles the Platonic ideal of pizza. "The sauce is on top." "But why?" "Who can explain the mysteries of this earth?" Fortunately, Malnati's provided an excellent example of the red-topped step-child of the pizza family, as our "Chicago Classic," topped with sausage, tasted fantastic and certainly stands as one of the best Chicago-styles I've had. Which is probably a good thing, because, you know, it's like authentic or something. Summary: Russian-approved.

I usually wouldnt be caught dead down in 'tourist row' but I had family in town that wanted to get their deep dish on... Anyone that doesnt understand what I mean by 'tourist row', this should help explain. It was the day of the Bears vs. Packers and 90% of people had Packers jerseys on... because no self respecting Chicagoan would be donning green and yellow in 'real' neighborhoods. Anyway, my rating has nothing to do with that... So, we entered the joint and asked to sit outside because it was beautiful out. The tables were set and no one was out there. They said we couldnt because it was closed. I said, it doesnt looked closed.. they said nothing and asked if we still wanted a table. I'm not a dick but seriously? No place in 'real' Chicago would have treated me like a tourist.. but alas, I was in 'tourist row'.. So, we sat in the stuffy crowded and loud back room.. ok, no worries - lets just get our pizza on and move forward. Server was not friendly but I can handle that... I asked for my Italian Beef to be made dry and she asked me what does that meant? I asked if this was her first day and she scowled at me... again, 'tourist row'. For those of you that dont understand - Italian Beefs are severed dipped or dry in Chicago. She then explained mid scowl that the au jus comes on the side - which is great but rare when ordering a Beef. I then asked for chopped onions to be put on the Beef.. She said, 'WE DONT DO THAT HERE' - I put this last part in caps because really.. like really? Its a pizza joint.. you have chopped onions. I have worked at like 5 pizza joints that severed Beefs as well.. YES, you can have f'ing onions on your Beef if you want. I had to explain to her that since they also serve pizza then I bet that they have onions in back that they can put on the Beef... She had the nerve to say, NO - but we can put them on the side... like really? Come on, was that really necessary? Sure, put them on the side, I dont care.. just give me some onions for Christ sake. Needless to say, Beef came out without an onion in sight... weak.  Now, I know that this might seem like nit-picking to some people but having shown my relatives some serious awesome neighborhood love for a few days, this experience was really getting my goat. Pizza came out and was great as usual... as was the wings and Beef overall. So there you go, solid food from the Lou's I have grown to know and love for 35 years.. wack service.  Oh - and when we left there were 3 or 4 tables sitting OUTSIDE... guess we didnt qualify.
Now that's some delicious deep dish pizza! By far the best crust I have ever had. Also the cookie dessert is good too

Stopped in for a late lunch with friends and family. Michael was our waiter. Kudos to the management at this location. My friend was trying to order a thin crust, in my mind I'm like why? This place is known for the deep dish. Our waiter convinced him he was in the wrong place and in a good way convinced him to deep. Can't get a bad meal at this place. One of the best Caesar salads in Chicago, definitely the best salad for a pizza joint. Just all around good experience. Thanks Mike

Wow! It was really busy and it seems like "it always is" busy but was on our "while in Chicago list" so we put our name on the wait list and preordered our pizza pies as directed. .after about an hour and I could have chewed my arm off..was so hungry!  When we were guided upstairs was surprised how busy it still was (about 8:30pm) but waitress was good & Lou's house salad was delicious with tangy dressing & olives, our party dug in!  Soon the deepdish pies arrived (The Lou, and Pepperoni).  Now we were feeling better,  very happy with company and even more so with dinner!  Our fave was The Lou..there was such a good amount of cheese and veggies & full of flavor that didn't even notice there was no meat on this one. .both good with thick buttery crusts.  Staff was very busy but beverage glasses weren't ever empty & plenty of leftovers!

Good service and atmosphere. There's always a waitlist, but is worth it. We had the "Lou's Bruschetta" appetizer and "The Manalti Chicago Classic" Deep Dish pizza and it was amazing! Best Deep Dish pizza so far.

Deep dish pizza at its finest. I typically don't do chain restaurants but after seeing this place recommended by the best of chefs on the food network, I had to try it. The only downfall is that it takes about 30-40 minutes to cook your pizza so I would recommend getting an appetizer or salad to start but it was definitely worth the wait. It is without a doubt not NY style pizza but that doesn't make it any less fantastic.

As New Yorkers, we are particular and picky with our pizza. Although we ordered the thin crust, it was delicious and satisfying! We are already planning on returning to try the deep dish. Excellent Caesar salad as well!
Visiting from out of town and of course I had to get the deep dish.  It was worth the wait.  While I was waiting, I got the wings and they were outstanding.

While visiting Chicago I ended up here for some deep dish based on some recommendations and let me tell you.. It was amazing!  First thing first.. When you walk in there is a slew of people and it is kind of confusing. You first put in your name for the table and then you put in order for the pizza. You can order salad and drinks at the table. This is so they can start the pizza while you wait.  We started with the entree size Caesar salad which was really good for a Caesar! Dressing was really good quality!  I then had an individual pepperoni If you want real deep dish, don't order the individual! I made the mistake of doing this, it is small and not full deep dish because it was made individually but still so amazing! The buttercrust is crispy yet soft. My favorite part is the amazing sauce on top! You can tell by the smell when you walk in they make great sauce! If I go back to Chicago I will be back!

We didn't have to wait at all! I was surprised by this, as the place was pretty full. Best pizza I've ever had! We ordered the classic, or original, or whatever but we were so hungry and excited that we just went with it and were very impressed. Great tomatoes! The only negative was that my fork was dirty and I had to ask a couple of times for a new one. I will definitely go back next time I'm in Chicago.

For lunch, two of us split a small Chicago Classic pizza with sausage and pepperoni.  It was fine but no better than many other deep dish pizza we have had.  The pizza made as feel crappy all day - it was just so heavy.  Maybe it was that extra butter in the crust that was just too rich with all that cheese.

Some of us are creatures of habit.  We find comfort and security in doing certain things in certain places.  In Chicago, I always do my best to tuck into the best Chicago Style deep dish pizza I can lay my mitts on.  Ya, not particularly adventurous or clever or healthy but fuck man, when I'm on the road I need something to tether my frayed nerves and disrupted patterns to. Like most non-natives I've worked my way through the typical stuff (Gino's etc.) but my last 3 visits I've settled in nicely with Lou, bolting down a regular dealer for my dirty habit.  I rationalize it in all kinds of stupid ways.  For example, I order take out and pick a route that requires a solid mile of running to get there and back.  I try to land early enough I can have it for lunch AND dinner later that day and I throw in a guilt assuaging salad.  "Ya, ya" you say, "whatever gets you through the night, man.  but how is the actual god damn pizza?" well, my brusque, review-reading friend, the pizza is fan-fucking-tastic. Dense resilient texture somehow balanced perfectly against the toppings, cheese and sauce.  Not gummy or clumpy, not overly cornmealed.  The sausage disc is amazing, the spinach mix is wonderful, I appreciate that the sauce isn't too chunky but add sliced tomatoes regardless.  This is the Baby Bear of deep dish pizza: not too cheesy, not too crusty, not too saucy.  Just good.  damn good.  I'm currently resisting the urge to take one home with me.  Let the magic stay here in Chicago, it always turns my travel frown upside down.
I ordered personal size Maltina Chicago Pizza. It was great! It's a little much for a female.

Yes, it's a tourist trap.  Yes, the people around you will act like they've never waited in a line before.  Yes, the wait will take at least 45-60 minutes.  The good news:  they use that time to cook your food since deep dish pizza takes a minute.  And this pizza is really, really good.  Five of us (swimmers, so we can eat) had the spinach salad, a medium Lou and a small classic and left two slices on the pan.  It was a TON of food, but we left full and happy.    Pro Tip: Know the system and be prepared.  Walk in door, get in first line (NOT in front of cashier) and pick up menu. Decide what you want to eat.  Give your name and phone number to the hostess and she will text you when your table is ready.  Get in SECOND line, in front of cashier, and place your pizza order.  They'll cook it while you wait at the bar!  No room at the bar?  Walk one block down to the Pepper Canister and have a beer there - the hostess has your number and she'll text you when your table is ready.
Deep dish with spinach = best pizza in Chicago = best pizza on earth

Awful, just awful. Tourist trap. Give me a totinos frozen pizza before Lou malnatis. Even their meatball sub tastes awful. How do you mess up a meatball sub?! I don't know, ask these guys and they'll show you. Subway has a better meatball sub. If you want real Chicago pizza stay away from here.
There was a long wait at this place and they don't take reservations. But it's worth it! Loved their classic sausage pizza, this was one of the highlighted food experiences of mine in Chicago.

"you MUST try deep dish chicago pizza!!!" although there's no argument to the above state, the best deep dish pizzeria in chicago is still up for a debate.  i am not really into deep dish stype pizza, so i let the hubby choose a place near our hotel which steered us to lou malnati's.   after hearing that pizza takes 30-40 minutes to cook, we started with the house salad with red wine vinaigrette dressing which was lovely, although a tad too sweet.  a small sized "malnati's" pizza was more than enough to feed 2 adults.  the infamous butter crust was not particularly buttery, but more flaky and crusty, similar to pizza hut's crust, and the cheese was rubbery and hard, however, the overall flavors exceeded my expectations.  the pizza was not oily nor salty, but i don't think i could take more than 2 slices of it, whereas i could devour the whole thing of pieology pizza. honestly, deep dish pizza is a little hyped up.  as a fan of neapolitan pizza, i can't say i was completely in love with lou malnati's, but i will bump up the rating for their salad, service and ambiance.  i also can't say if this is the chicago's best since i didn't care to try other deep dish pizza places after having my first bite here. come early or with some snacks in hand.  by the time we left around 12:30, the line wrapped around the block which meant you probably don't get to taste the pizza for at least 2 hours, factoring in the prep/cook time for the pizza.

Yummy!  My co-worker and I ordered the Calamari appetizer to share.  It was light and seasoned perfectly, with a slight spicy kick that we loved.  We munched on the calamari while waiting for our deep dish pizza.  We decided to order 2 personal pizzas to share.  We ordered the Chicago Classic and the Lou.  Both were excellent.  The service was great, our server was Patina.

This was my one and only real deal Chicago deep dish experience so I don't have anything to compare it to. Skip breakfast, skip lunch even. This pizza is rich and heavy! We made a mistake of ordering some appetizers and we could barely finish 1 slice when it came. We shared the Malnati Classic which is tomatoes, sausage, and a thick layer of cheese. It was absolutely delicious and we have craved it ever since but again, show up hungry! Our server was super attentive and nice.The restaurant is brimming with very cool black and white pics of celebrities that have visited along with Chicago history and cool sports memorabilia. Very authentic and memorable experience!

I think this is the best pizza I've ever eaten in my life. Let's put that on the table right away.  The butter crust is crispy and soaks everything up. The sauce still has tomato chunks in it and is still acidic. You can tell it's very fresh. The amount of cheese they give you is also ridiculous, in an awesome kind of way. You could tell the sausage was very fresh and they made it themselves. There's no way you could get frozen premade sausage that is that good. The whole pie compliments itself and everything goes together very well. It's like a symphony in your mouth. Every ingredient has a purpose and it works together in perfect harmony to create this pizza. This is something everyone should experience at least once in their life. It's as good as all the food channels and travel shows make it out to be. Lives up to the hype in every way.  I'm not from Chicago and everyone has their preference when it comes to Chicago style pizza, but I would come here again in a heart beat.
Try the thin pizza I know it not Chicago pizza but it's good! Great service and delivery!
This place is deceiving. It looks small from the outside but ends up being two stories and with a lot of tables. Spinach salad was good, pizza was great, their wine pours are very small.

This was my first deep dish pizza experience in the city of Chicago. It was delicious and did not disappoint! They were busy, but the service was quick and efficient. Buttercrust is the way to go (as if that was ever in doubt).
Awesome pizza! Best deep dish pizza in town, definitely! Price was also very reasonable - highly recommended!

We got here before they opened, and there were already a line. We had a party of two, and we got seated promptly. After sitting down for not even a minute our server promptly took our drink orders and gave us suggestions since it was our first time: Spinach bread and a "small" Classic sausage deep dish. Additionally, we had plates that were dirty, but the server took care of it. Another minor complaint: the two-person booths had really hard seats, it hurts after a while. Maybe it's a sign that I need to workout more for a bigger booty. The Spinach Bread came first. It was mostly cheese! it was so dense that it felt like a whole meal. The crust was nice a fluffy, and it had a nice garlic aroma. Then, the main show, the deep dish pizza came. Right off the bat, it definitely taste better the than NYC pizza. Chicago wins end of story. Great pizza, good staff. Get there early to skip the lines!

Lou's is a Chicago staple. Crust - buttery from the inside. Sauce - tomato chunks with a hint of red wine. Toppings  - sausage crushes it.  Cheese - literally - are you joking?  Just a great pizza and a taste of an iconic great that hits the mark every time. Order it uncut with a nice lous salad. It's a treat once a week if I can handle it.
Solid deep dish pizza, good three-cheese bread, fun atmosphere, this place had it all (including a steep bill at the end, which is all that kept this from being five stars!).

Pretty sure my gallbladder flipped out with this meal, which is a-ok with me! We started with garlic bread (nothing special) and the Malnati salad, which was incredible. Even the regular size is quite big FYI, 2 of us couldn't finish it.  So, pizza! Deep dish is all about proportions, and they've nailed it. Perfect ratio of crust, tomato sauce, toppings, and cheese. OH MY GOD THE CHEESE. I think they put crack in it. We also had a thin crust that was great. Both pizzas reheated really well in the oven over the next couple days. Keep in mind the pizza takes 45 minutes, so budget your time accordingly. Definitely worth it, I prefer their deep dish to Giordano's, which has too much sauce for my liking. Will be back!

Stopped in during a layover at o'hare. Place was pretty crowded but we had expected that. Ordered a salad and Lou's favorite Pizza. After about 15 the waiter cam back and said that the kitchen had crashed and he needed to put the order back in and just wanted to confirm it. The salad came out 15 minutes later. It was fresh and flavorful. The pizza came 25 minutes later and was well worth the wait. This is Chicago pizza at its finest. Buttery crust loaded with toppings and cheese. Heaven in a deep dish

Filling is the first word that comes to mind.  Fresh tomato base sauce and a thinner crust than I thought came on my sausage and black olive pizza.  The sausage can only be explained as an entire layer of mild Italian sausage covered with the sauce.  The cheese sits on the bottom next to the crust.  New York or Chicago style, have to vote NY style.  Good quality Chicago style, just like the flavor of well cooked thin style crust.

The wait can be long during popular hours but the food is delicious.  I've had the Malnati Chicago Classic as well as various combinations of toppings that sounded good together and I have yet to be disappointed. The stuffed spinach bread is pretty good but can be a little heavy after the first few bites so I would recommend getting it to share.  The chocolate chip pizza is amazing and I don't even like sweets. The cookie is served warm and fresh in a small deep dish pan and topped with ice cream and whipped cream. I didn't want to order it the first time I was there because I was already full from the pizza, but after the first bite I made room in my stomach for the rest of it because it was that good. The individual serving is big enough to share between 2 people but you might have to fight for it.

Best pan pizza (deep dish) in Chicago.  That's the only reason to come and it's a winner.  The crust is a traditional cornbread crust and is the right amount of chew and crunch.  Toppings are very good.  If you want thin crust, don't come here-but if traditional pan is what you want I wouldn't go anywhere else.

"Best Layover Ever" started off here at Malnati's Pizzeria. My wife and I were seated promptly upstairs in their dining area. The place is nice and clean and the atmosphere was exactly what we were hoping for. A lot of people our age were there and grabbing a bite on this Sunday afternoon. We were glancing over the menu, taking our time...waiting...waiting...about 15 minutes went by without anyone coming to our table. Major bummer, cause I was really hungry and I thought they were better than this. Eventually after making an obvious glance at one of the waitresses, she helped us with our drink order and we eventually got our pizza order in as well. Now for the good part! We got The Malnati Chicago Classic and it was pizza heaven. Tons of delicious gooey cheese and the crust isn't too hard and full of flavor as well. As an appetizer we got the Malnati Salad to share and it's pretty big! That might have been one of the best salads of my life though. Couple that with a local Chicago IPA and this meal turned out really good. Don't miss out on this authentic Chicago pizza!

One of the best pizzas I've tried in Chicago. I ordered the traditional Chicago style from the house and was not disappointed. The tomato sauce was incredible. The place is also cozy and nice, it's definitely worthwhile going there when visiting the city!

Went here for my first testing of Chicago's Deep dish pizza, the pizza was amazing, but the service was the worst!!!!! We sat outside, our waiter had 3 tables, and couldn't seem to handle basic server responsibilities like checking to see how our food was, do we need a box for our leftovers, would we like dessert or how about our check? I might mention that it was 8:00 on Labor Day Monday, it was muggy with humidity so I am assuming he wanted to hang out more in the air conditioning, then service the diners outside. I couldn't help but wonder how many people leave without paying for their meal  We asked the three employees standing around the hostess stand for a box, and they said they would let our server know, obviously they never did because he didn't come back with a box. We laid our credit card on the table to let him know we were ready to pay, too bad the attentiveness to customer's is so lacking at such a well known pizza resteraunt.

I took a day trip to Chicago and wanted to maximize my experience of Chicago and what better way to do that than with some deep dish pizza? I decided on Lou Malnati's due to suggestions from friends as well as raving reviews on yelp and I was not disappointed!  Arrived about 10 min before they opened on a Sunday and there were already a few people other than myself waiting to get in. Ended up ordering the spinach bread and the Malnati Chicago Classic and both were amazing! The spinach bread is a smaller sized loaf of bread filled with cheesy goodness and a little bit of spinach as well. The pizza with the butter crust is amazing as well! Took about 30 min for them to make the pizza but it was definitely worth the wait. The crust has a really nice crunch to it all around and every bite was filled with ooey gooey mozzarella goodness and Oh my, they definitely do not skimp on the sausage! Instead of bits of sausage, it seemed like they had sausage on every inch of the pie! A small pizza and the spinach bread were more than enough for two people and I would highly recommend the deep dish pizza here to anyone!

Lou Malnati's pizza is our favorite pizza place when we visit Chicago. We ordered the Malnati Chicago classic. It's the deep dish pizza with lean sausage extra cheese and vine ripened tomatoes on a buttercrust. It takes about 40 minutes to cook but it's worth the wait. The pizza is very filling. We ordered a large so we would have extra to carry out for later. Next time we are in Chicago we will definitely be back. Lou you need to open a location in Las Vegas so when we go there we can enjoy your pizza.

The fact that you can place your order while you are waiting for table is ingenious. We went on a whim based on fellow yelp reviews. The place was crowded when we got there, and by the looks of it, it always is! We had the melnetis original butter crust pizza. It was definitely good, but unfortunately, not life changing. Based on reviews, I guess I was expecting much, much more.
Pizza is awesome and classic has an entire layer of tasty sausage. Eating with someone standing over you is not awesome. Any place downtown is touristy and this is no exception.

Do NOT order the cheese squares (they WILL try to convince ) UNLESS you want fried Kraft singles bits. ALSO, do NOT order the salad if you want lettuce in there. It's mainly tomatoes, black olives, blue cheese, bacon bits, and vinaigrette. Pizza was honestly mediocre. If you're looking for pizza and can't go anywhere else, then this is good.

Awesome "Lou" pizza! Great customer service, really nice new location in Lincoln Square. Have also gone to Lincolnwood, which is great too.  Salad with bacon.bits on top is an excellent choice.  The Lou is the best pizza....

My friend and I were looking for a pizza place and we ended at a fancy restaurant. We told the server we wanted to try a Chicago style pizza (deep dish), and she recommended Lou Malnati's Pizzeria. After thanking her and politely exiting the fancy place, we walked to Lou Malnati's Pizzeria, and WOW...this was the best pizza I have ever tried! Service was great, and the flavor of the pizza was phenomenal. Even my friend who is a Chef was impressed about the flavor of the pizza and how it is prepared. If you are visiting Chicago, this is "the place" to eat a Chicago style pizza.

We flew in late and grabbed a large and medium pie to go. Both pies ran about $50. Either everyone was super hungry or the pie was just that good.  Yup it was so good that I ate every little bite. I've had Giordanos before and think LM's pie is just better. A must try when in the Windy City!

Visiting our favorite pizza joint on a long weekend get away to Chicago! Beat the lunch crowd and arrived early. Sat upstairs and took in the beautiful nostalgic loft-type building and cool sports memorabilia lining the walls. Started with the Lou Malnati's salad and a pitcher of Goose Island 312.   Delish! 10YO had the kids chicken nuggets and fries, rating them MMM MMM! Hubs and I split the Chicago Deep Dish and it was worth the wait.  Excellent!!!

I got here at 8:30 on a Thursday night and only waited for like 10 minutes unexpectedly. We ordered the malnati's salad and it was pretty darn amazing for a salad. It has everything you want in a salad and it definitely opens your appetite for the pizza so do not pass it up. We ordered two small pizzas for three people (and trust me it is enough bc my boyfriend is an eater and I can definitely scarf down a few slices normally without budging). We got the Malnati and the Lou pizzas. I think maybe because I ate the Malnati's first, I think it tastes better since it was served piping hot. The crust was perfect and so was the layering of hot melted stringy cheese and the sweet, tangy tomato sauce. The Lou had some pretty overpowering spinach that I didn't quite enjoy as much but I guess it is just personal preference. Our server helped make the experience even better by being super friendly and helpful. Come here, you won't regret.

I regret choosing Lou Malnati's Pizzeria for our last lunch in Chicago on Sunday. We ate lunch at the Wells St location on Sunday morning. We arrived right at 11 because we know that it takes a while to cook a deep dish pizza and these places can become very busy.  Gloria was our server and it's possible this review would be very different if I had been seated in someone else's section. However, our experience on Sunday was with Gloria.  We ordered the stuffed spinach bread and the small Malnati Chicago Classic, which is a deep dish pizza with butter crust, lean sausage, tomato sauce and cheese. Gloria said it would be 35 minutes. Everyone in the other sections who arrived at the same time as us received their pizzas, ate, paid, and left the restaurant. Our pizza was finally served an hour and nine minutes later. We were so tired of sitting there we only ate a piece each and got out of there as fast as we could. I really wish we had not wasted our time in the place.  Not a recommendation from me.

Some of the best Chicago Style pizza you will find. Generous ration and even distribution of toppings makes a big difference in pizza, especially deep dish pizza, and Giordano's does it right. The atmosphere is nice and has an authentic pizzeria feel right as you enter. The only real downfalls are that the pizza takes a long time to make (not their fault), and one time when I went there, one of my pizzas came out at about room temperature. It probably was ready before the other pizza and had to sit and wait. I would rather they brought it out when it was hot, even if not all at once.

Took a trip to the CHI for some deep dish. This was defiantly my favorite. Straight off the plane, found this place and it was heaven , the anticipation of the pizza had me on my toes lol 30mins was tooooo long but SO WORTH IT. Everything was so rich and cheesy , I can't explain the taste you just have to try it for yourself.

One of, if not the most famous, deep dish pizza joints in Chicago. I could sit here and tell you about the ambience of the restaurant; but, I'm not. Just know you'll feel comfortable when you first walk in. I actually ended up sitting outside to enjoy the beautiful anyway nahmsayin? To the point tho. I came to the Chi for the sole purpose of eatin some authentic Chicago Deep dish pizza and that's what the gawd did.
