Had to experience the deep dish pizza while driving through Chicago. Completely different than my normal thin crust choices. They have a size pizza for everyone, but I got the personal size cheese. Be prepared to wait 30-45 minutes for your pizza, so this makes a great time to order apps and salads. My table ordered the cheesy bread and the garden salads. The salads were a large portion, and just enough to keep you full until the pizza arrived. Pizzas were cooked great. It was a completely different experience of pizza, but I enjoyed it! Service was awesome, and we left happy.

Ah the wifey had a business trip in Chicago. I requested some pizza to go since we don't have Lou Malnati's in Indianapolis, but we do have Giordanos (don't get me started on this)... Lou's needs to expand to the Indy area too!  Anyways since I wasn't in Chicago she got a deep dish pie to go. The key is to request it half baked so that you can bake it again at home. We got the The Malnati Chicago Classic™, which has  a buttery crust, extra mozzarella cheese, the pizzeria's own sausage. Honestly it held up pretty well and I was happy it re cooked at home. Probably one of the best deep dish pizzas in Chicago, personally, I am more of a NYC slice person. But every so often I want some deep dish.

First time eating here and my daughter's introduction to Chicago deep dish. We were not disappointed! We got right in around 6 with just the two of us, and our waitress was great - just chatty enough and good with kids. Ordered a small pepperoni deep dish which was just enough for me to eat 3/4 of and her to eat 1/4. We both loved the cheese and pepperoni, but the best part is the crust! Somehow it's thick without being super dense. Definitely will go again.

Absolutely fantastic.  My wife and I share a deep dish for two....and a single salad.  Just amazing.  The taste was so intense.  The crust.  The cheese.  The tasty sausage.  The fresh tomatoes.  Perfection.

One of my friends came into town and she's never been to Chicago/had deep dish pizza. I had the daunting task of deciding which legendary Chicago deep dish pizza to show her. I chose Lou's, because I grew up eating Lou's, and figured it's the most well known.  We chose this location purely because of where we had finished our little walking tour of the Loop/central downtown. For 6:00 on a Friday, I was SHOCKED that our wait was only about 20 minutes. This location is a bit smaller than what I'm used to, but they use their space well and have a really efficient wait system. It uses modern technology (an iPad and texting) and they encourage you to order your pizza(s) while you wait so it cuts your wait time in half once you get to the table. Very efficient. Loved it.  They also make the waiting atmosphere thiiiiis much better because they have complimentary thin crust pizza while you're waiting! Score! We ordered a small pep and a small Lou's, perfect for 3 people, and we even took a couple "slices" home. Pizza was perfect as usual. My out of town friend loved it and asked if we could go back for more tomorrow.  The only reason this Lou's location doesn't get 5 starts from me is because of where we sat. There are about 5 or 6 high top tables right by the front entrance, bar, and waiting area. This is where we sat. Now, I'm sure on a normal day (not a cold-ish Friday night), sitting there is fine. But there was a swarm of people basically on top of us and we felt a cooooooold breeze every time the door opened.  Other than that, a near perfect Lou's trip.

The waiter was ver kind but the pizza was very bad. The bread was undercooked, the sauce is very bland in flavor and the cheese wasn't good either. I don't understand the reviews. Ordered two different pizzas one deep dish and one thin crust and both where extremely disappointing. Will not return. Edit: The manager didn't let us pay as it was our first time dining there. Very nice gesture.

My friend recommended as a "must eat" while in Chicago and is a good thing I listened!  Best pizza and salad hands down EVER! Service was excellent even though the house was packed!  Brandon our server helped to make it fabulous!

Finally tried this after trying most of the other "best deep dish" places in Chicago (Giordano's, Gino's, etc.) I must say, it was pretty good. Tourists flock to all the good places, and Lou Malnati's is no exception. Pro-tip: Always remember that deep dish takes at least half an hour to 45 minutes to prep, so make sure that you don't have any impending obligations less than an hour away, or call ahead. It also might be worth getting a few appetizers while you wait for that long. We got the original Lou's (roma tomatoes, mushrooms, spinach, cheeses), and the Malnati Chicago classic (sausage). The crust was pretty good, with a bit of a tart, sourdough taste, which complemented the rich toppings. Both were very good, and left all of us stuffed, with a few slices to spare. We ordered two mediums for 6 people, and the stuffed spinach bread as an appetizer, which was more than enough food. Service was a little spotty, but not enough to be a problem. The prices are actually pretty good, in my opinion, as each of us only paid around $18, including a 20% tip. Overall, not to be a deep dish hipster, but I still think Pequod's is still my favorite. Screw it, I relish being a deep dish hipster. That being said, Lou Malnati's has stood the test of time, and rightfully so. With so many locations, the convenience factor is there, and while they're all mostly tourist destinations, you'll likely get a good, consistent, deep dish pizza no matter where you go.
Great pizza and atmosphere would recommend this place to anyone in chicago that is looking for good pizza and a great chicago atmosphere

I am in Chicago for work and so far have only had pizza at Pizanos since it's the closest to my hotel, but tonight I decided to give Lou's a try and it did not disappoint.  I got the Malnati Classic and it was awesome, fresh ingredients and sausage in EVERY bite!!  If I am being honest though the infamous butter crust disappointed, I actually like Pizanos crust better, but overall Lou's is better.

Good Chicago style pizza with sports bar type feeling. I certainly appreciated the set up since the NBA final was on while we were  eating. Service is ok. Good price. Nothing fancy about this place, but it's a golden pizza, beer and watching TV.

Good deep dish pizza... but the Malnati salad was delicious!!  Our server recommended it and I was hesitant, but am really amazed how delicious it is.   Pretty good menu and beer list here.  The atmosphere is casual but nice.  It's a really big space with a bar and seating downstairs, and additional seating upstairs.
The crustless (meat base) pizza is the best pizza I've ever had. Not on the menu though; so make sure to ask for it!

Every time a friend visits me, I take him or her to this Lou's. Deep-dish is on the heavy side for me and I almost never eat it on my own, but tasting the impressive mix of tomato sauce, sausage and cheese is a perfect treat every once in a while. The pizza here is not as thick as at Giordano's, which I think is a positive since for the latter, I get the impression that I'm eating a block of cheese with various toppings interspersed. Not that I'm opposed to such a meal, but my stomach will hate me shortly after paying the bill.  I have to say that opinions on deep-dish among my acquaintances are as varied as the weather here. While I fail to see how combining a ton of cheese and meat and peppers with sauce and a crust can possibly be bad, certain friends avoid it unless they really have to eat it. I think they're just on a diet.

We had a few different deep dish pizzas when we were in Chicago and Lou's was good but we thought Pequod's was better.  This isn't an argument that you can ever convince anyone of though so I will leave it at that.  Our waiter here was amazing and so on top of it.  We got the The Malnati Chicago Classic and while I love sausage, I felt like it was too much and basically just a layer of sausage.  Again I still loved it hence the rating but I feel there are better. Definitely try out Lou's to see different types of deep dish in Chicago and see which one you like best.

We running out of time when in Chicago, but we took a cab to Lou Malnatis prior to our flight home.  Absolutely loved the pizza and worth the trip.  There are a few places in Nashville that say they have Chicago Deep Dish Pizza and they just aren't even close.

Horrible customer service. We walked in at 12am because a local referred them. They turned us away and said they just closed. We explained we were from out of town (Texas) and heard great things about them. They still turned us away!!! HORRIBLE customer service!!!!!!

The good: everything is super fresh and light. Tastes like what authentic pizza should taste like, made with simple ingredients and very light tasting. Barely any grease, more tomato juices. The penne was also very light. The bad: everything is very light tasting. Hahah I think I'm just accustomed to super cheesy greasy pizzas. I here Gino's is more cheesy but we didn't get to try that place. First time in Chicago and was very excited to try a deep dish.  All of their pizzas take a minimum 30 mins no matter if you order a standard or add extra toppings. Which wasn't really a big deal for me, I like knowing my pizza is super fresh but think it's worth a mention so you know. Got just a personal Lou Malnati classic deep dish which is fresh tomatoes and sausage. My wife ordered the Malnati penne which came out in about 12-15 mins. My wife really liked the food. I was just okay with everything. Service was fine.
Great Deep Dish! We ordered three large pizzas and a round of IPAs. Great Service! The pepperoni is standard but the meat lovers and veggie is exceptional. Good prices for downtown Chicago.

My wife and I were in town on our baseball bus tour and wanted to have some authentic Chicago pizza, so taking some advice from the Harry Caray servers, we chose Lou Malnati's. My wife ordered the thin crust.and I the deep dish and the pizzas were heavenly! Each order I'd prepared fresh so it was a 35 minute wait but it was worth it! Delicious Chicago pizza!

I am not a fan of deep dish (GASP! I know) BUT it's so good here and definite must-eat-at in Chicago. They have regular/thin crust too and it's awesome, AND they have great salads too! Also nice for delivery if the wait is too long! :)
Fun atmosphere, friendly service, & fantastic food! Perfect family pizzeria. Definitely worth the wait for the deep dish pizza to cook. The dessert cookie pizza is delicious too!
My favorite pizza in Chicago! I get deep-dish cheese every time. All options are good, but for me, just cheese allows me to really appreciate the greatness that is deep-dish Lou Malnati's pizza.

I don't know guys...  it was good but it wasn't great.  I've been here a couple of time now and while I like the pizza, it takes forever to get it.  The menu is narrow and fairly generic and I just have a hard time getting excited about it.  There are better pizza places in Chicago and if you're only in town for a quick trip and want good Chicago Deep Dish, I preferred Giordano's.
Enormous portions. We ordered the medium... It was enough for 3-4 people. The salad and combo platter appetizer were great. 10x better than Gino's

So i gave this place another shot because the manager was so kind to me and my part after my bad experience. we came back and the food was way better then last time. but it still took the servers a long time to always get back to us. if i ordered an appetizer it would take 25 min. if i ordered a water would take 10 min. i also ordered a cup of coffee and that also took 20 min. don't get me worn the server i has was awesome !! she was super friendly and nice but i just think that this place needs to hire more servers honestly. also orders some cake and that took about 15-20 min. good place but just needs some help in certain areas. but i would come back

My family was in Chicago for a mini Family Reunion. We simply asked a cab driver "WHERE'S THE BEST PIZZA" Of course he asked Deep Dish or Thin style.  And he sent us to Lou Malnati's. We had a Perfect Pizza Experience....Great Deep Dish, tasty appetizers( mom said she could've eaten just those...pesto bread chunks). And turns out it was sort of a family connection....in that my cousin John Lewis has gone to this favorite family place for many years. So cabbies know, family knows, we Seattle cousins now know. Total Yum!

A trip to Chicago must include at least 1 deep dish pizza, especially when its my first time in the city! After searching on yelp, Lou's seemed to have the most positive reviews out of all the contenders.  We arrived and got seated promptly. Our waitress was super friendly and help us decide on a half Lou's (vegetarian) and half Malnati classic (sausage). I've never had Chicago style deep dish so this was a great experience. I was expecting a thick bready-type crust and bottom, but instead, the deepness was filled with mostly cheese, sauce and toppings. I loved the sausage on the Malnati classic, it was like a huge sausage patty. The pizza was so good that I decided to buy a frozen one to take back to LA for my parents to try! And they loved it!

I awoke floating on a piece of plywood in a sea of mozzarella. The crust came later, deeper, and far more meaningful. The sauce was a top born of a bottom. Orwellian by nature, if such a thing is possible. Probably. Compost the most decent sized stuffing into a Michael Jackson glove of despair--you'll need it.

Sorry, Jon Stewart. This may be a "casserole" calling itself a pizza, but it's probably my favorite food in Chicago. There was a wait of about one hour on a Friday night even to place a carryout order (!), so we walked down Wells to The Pepper Canister for some friendly pints and Irish whiskey. I took my order, a personal pan Chicago Classic for $8.95--easily enough for two meals--back to the hotel. It was none the worse for wear, and in fact the second half was excellent the next day. When I'm back, I'll have to check out Gigio's and Rinaldi's. But I'l probably also make time for another Lou Malnati's location as well. This time I'll get there early enough to go inside and have a beer with the best meal in Chicago.

I must say my expectations were extremely high after seeing the reviews. I ordered delivery to my hotel. Since being in Chicago we had not tried thin crust pizza so gave it a go. The delivery wait was an hour which I felt was reasonable given prime time. Prices were also very reasonable. When I got the pizza I was immediately disappointed because I could tell my pizza wasn't hot. It was barely warm, but I was starving and soon found out it was still very good despite having cooled during delivery.
If you only try one deep dish pizza in Chicago, this should be it.  I mean, who puts an entire LAYER of sausage on a pizza?  These guys do.  And it's simply glorious.

We were looking for a classic Deep Dish pizza during our recent visit to Chicago and found Lou Malnati's which had several favorable reviews. We were seated quickly upon arrival and after a short wait our server arrived and gave us what appears to be the standard greeting of... "Our pizza's take about 40 minutes to cook should we get yours started.." We ordered the Chicago Classic and, due the 40 minute cook time, a spinach salad to share. The Salad was a a good sized salad served with a flavorful dressing not to strong.  The pizza, when served, was actually excellent. At the recommendation of the server we opted for the Chocolate Chip Cookie Pizza to end the meal.  The server told us this took about 15 minutes to prepare which was fine. (In their menu it says to expect about 10 minutes). After what seemed like forever, (30 minutes) the "Cookie Pizza" finally arrived and was horrible... Nothing more then a cold, stale cookie served with a scoop of ice cream on top (probably to hide the abysmal quality of the cookie). Why it took 30 minutes to prepare this horrible thing is still questionable to me,. Certainly NOT worth that type of wait.  If we were to ever go again I would stick with the pizza and salad and skip the cookie pizza... Dessert is definitely NOT a strong point here.  Service was average. It seemed like they did not have enough servers to handle the crowd level adequately.  As we mainly went for the pizza, which as I stated was excellent, I gave 3 stars. Otherwise, if I was basing on all of the other elements I probably would have judged it with only 2 stars.  It served our desire for a good pizza but next time in Chicago we will probably look elsewhere.
Great service really good pizza I had the classic. I will def visit here on my next trip back to Chicago. Pizza was amazing so was the cheddar jalapeño soup.

Lou Malnati's is one of the best pizza spots in chicago - if you know what to get. I find their standard pizzas to be mediocre at best, but if you go for their specialty pizzas - you can easily be blown away. "The Lou" is my favorite, and I would probably give them 5 stars for that pizza alone as it is my favorite pizza in all of Chicago that I have had.

As far as pizzas go, this place is my all-time favorite.  While vacationing in Chicago recently, my parents and I happened on this place while taking in the city's sights.   After my dad spotted this restaurant across the street while we were taking a rest break, I was able to quickly review it on Yelp and realize this was a terrific dinner choice for that day.  True to Yelp's assessment, we all thoroughly enjoyed our meal there.  We were seated upstairs near the front of the restaurant (with views of the buildings across the street).  Because they cook each pizza per order submitted, it took about forty minutes before our Malnatti Chicago Classic Deep Dish Pizza (lean sausage, some extra cheese, & vine-ripened tomato sauce on Buttercrust) was brought to us.  While only a medium sized pizza, it was enough for my parents and me to share (although my mom did order something else as well).  Having only ever had a Chicago deep dish pizza once before (actually at Domino's here in Charleston - was really good), I was pleasantly surprised by just how delicious a true blue Chicago deep dish really is.  Having since tried two other famous Chicago restaurant deep dish pizzas while there (Giordano's and also Gino's East), my favorite is Lou's.  I highly recommend Lou's if you ever have the opportunity.  Their Malnati Salad is incredible too.  It consists of Romaine lettuce, tomatoes, black olives, mushrooms, Volpi salami bits, and gorgonzola cheese with their homemade Sweet Vinaigrette (fantastic) and side of romano cheese.  Absolutely amazing experience.  For those willing to try their pizzas from afar, Lou's ships their pizzas (frozen) across the country.  I'm actually planning on having some shipped here for my family and me later this year.
Best pizza in chicago. Get the Lou. Thin crust is just as good as thick if you're not starving. Salads are great too-- house or malnati.

I ended up Lou Malnati's about 3 hours after arriving in Chicago and that's including the train ride from the airport and the two block walk from where we were staying. The two blocks being no accident. I was so excited to hit the door and dive into some deep dish for my first time in town. We were seated courteously and quickly upstairs and got drinks post haste. Cab and Bubbles. The service was fast, friendly and attentive. We then ordered a fabled large cheese pie when prompted, no starters or salad to get in the way. Our server said good call on that one. There was so much tasty gooey cheese and I hate to say it not enough sauce to balance it out. So it made it feel like there was too much cheese. As it being a deep dish, I am sure there is "too much" anyway, but whose to say? I really liked the crust of Lou's pizza. The cornmeal style stayed crunchy throughout the onslaught of Mozz and added a nice flavor. Next time I just have to say "extra sauce". Lesson learned.

Went on a Wednesday evening because I'd heard so much about it. Ordered a small The Lou to share with friends. The crust was delicious - crispy and buttery. But the pizza as a whole left me underwhelmed. I've never had deep dish before so take it with a grain of salt, but it was more similar to thick crust than what I thought deep dish would be. The pizza was bland and didn't have enough cheese into opinion.

Illuminati's pizza is delicious. Jay-Z and Beyoncé eat here weekly just because of it's name. That means you know it's good. I rolled up in my lambo and jumped out of my whip, tossed my coat & keys to Tatiana and tipped her a quick G ($1000). Swag. They know I'm a regular.  My most recent trip was with my aunt where we ordered a large Chicago style deep dish. My Aunt ate a slice and I ate the rest. You can see where that would be a bad idea... That night my stomach seized up and I tossed and turned on the floor in my sleeping bag as I sweat profusely. Nothing against their delicious pizza I'm just a f***up sometimes. Back to the experience. The wait is normally about two hours but for my prestigious a** the wait was about an hour 45. Finally we are seated and our server was quick and to the point. "I'll get you a deep dish pepperoni stat" he says and I'm like thank you Georgio and tipped him. You must be thinking at this point who is this dbag...? But don't think that, Georgio is a nice guy. The pizza arrived. Confetti flies in the air, fireworks sound off in my heart, I finally found her, my true love, my pizza. I could see the jealousy in my girlfriends eyes as I tore this pizza apart, only later to have my stomach and heart torn apart from the food sweats and heart burn. That's what happens when you cheat on your lover with pizza ladies and gentleman. Would I go back? Cheyeah I would you know how I roll. Maybe next time I'll pace myself and eat in moderation, but then again maybe not.  Btw my lambo had a knick in the door when I got back, Tatiana you're dead to me.

This was the best gluten free pizza we have ever had. My wife has Celiac disease and it hits her hard, if she has gluten. This pizza was not only gluten free, it was delicious! Don't be afraid of the deep dish if you don't have gluten allergies. The boys went nuts over it.

On my first night in Chicago, my friends and I decided to get some authentic Chicago deep dish pizza. We were lucky we were staying only a couple of blocks away so it was very convenient walking to Lou Malnati's.  After a very short wait, the hostess seated us in the back of the restaurant and we ordered right away. (We were just about to pre-order our pizza when we were called to get seated. If there's a wait when you're there, just go ahead and place your order as you wait for your table since it takes awhile to bake.) We decided to order the Malnati Chicago Classic deep dish pizza with Lou's lean sausage, some extra cheese and vine-ripened tomato sauce on Buttercrust. We were starving by now and thought the 3 of us could finish a large. (Note: a large is meant for 4 people).  Now the long wait begins... it took over 45 minutes to an hour for our pizza to arrive at our table. The waitress said it was due to the size and because they wanted to make sure the sausage was cooked thoroughly. Now, the sausage is not the usual small pieces you get at your regular pizza places but large, slices of sausage. I'm not usually a fan of sausage, but their blend of sausage and seasoning sure makes this kind pretty tasty. You really do get your bang for your buck here.  I've had deep dish pizza before in California but this was amazing. The crust was delicious and the toppings were so fresh and flavorful. BUT, you really can start getting full after a slice... and we made the mistake of ordering a large. We should have opted for a medium pizza that was meant for 3 people. While we were so full from 2 slices, we were determined to finish the pizza... this came at a price though. We probably didn't want to see another pizza for awhile after stuffing ourselves with this pizza.  Lou Malnati's does offer other options besides pizza on their menu, but why come if you're not going to have the pizza? This place will definitely be on my list of places to return to whenever I make it back to Chicago.

ANY time is a good time for pizza.  what i ate: - malnati salad: romaine lettuce, tomatoes, black olives, mushrooms, salami bits, gorgonzola cheese, sweet vinaigrette, romano cheese. honestly, this salad kind of blew my mind. it hit every flavor note and texture note you could think of. sweet, tangy, salty, crunchy, savory. it was really refreshing after walking around the city on the warm spring day.  - large sausage and pepperoni deep dish: yes yes yes! the cornmeal crust was amazingly crispy. the meat was meaty. i have to admit, i ended up eating 2 slices (oink oink!) and a few bites of the very last slice. no leftovers!  pros: - pizza! - large location. there was plenty of room upstairs and downstairs. we came in on a busy saturday afternoon during lunch time and were seated within 5 mins. - price was right cons: - service was slowish. he forgot my beer. he wasnt around when we needed the check. slow - small bathroom, at least downstairs. it's only a single stall. we all made the trek upstairs to the larger bathroom, but by larger i meant 2 stalls.  would i come again? sure
Better than others in Chicago but nothing like New York City pizza. The flavors were off --a tad too bland for my taste.
a girl named lauren used to work there she was baller

First time to Chicago. Following friend recommendations and Yelp reviews I chose Lou's for my dinner. Ordered over the phone with someone who seemed rather reluctant to help me order, eh, whatever no biggie. Had a pleasant walk from my hotel to the restaurant. Paid the cashier and had a drink from the cool bartender at the bar while I waited. Watch a medium sized ROACH walk around the bar top. Ew. Told the bartender before heading to the bathroom, dunno if he found it but it seemed he looked. Took the pizza, medium, cheese, plain, back to the hotel. Ate half. Was wholly unremarkable. Heavy, but I think that's to be expected. Crust tasted of baking soda. Overall, pretty eh and I'm not seeing what the big deal is. Hope they can sort out their roach problem.

Last night while in Chicago on business I decided to go on an excursion (all by my lonesome - after hiding from the typical colleague steakhouse dinner) into the inner city in search of authentic Chicago style deep dish pizza. Initially I thought I might head out to the place that was featured on Anthony Bordain's "No Reservations", but once I realized it was about 40 minutes outside of the city I quickly changed my mind. I settled on the Lou Malnati's pizzeria. They have several locations, however this location seemed to be the most popular and it also happened to be in a part of town with interesting bars and lounges within a few blocks (check my other reviews for some good recommendations). I arrived around 8 PM on a Saturday night and the place was packed. I gave them my name and was told it would be in approximately 30 minute wait for a table or I could just sit at the bar. They also recommended placing the order for my pizza ahead of time since the pies generally take around 30 minutes to prepare. They have a chart on the wall near where you check in illustrating the sizes of the different size options  ranging from personal to extra-large. I was famished and was concerned the "small" size (one step up from personal) would not be sufficient to satisfy my appetite. The lady at the check in desk was correct, the "small" sized "Malnati Chicago Classic" (  Lou's lean sausage, some extra cheese and vine-ripened tomato sauce on Buttercrust) pie shut me down like a pile of bricks.   As you can see in the photograph I made it about halfway through slice 4/4 and that was it for me. Perhaps I should not have ordered minestrone soup, without it I may have made it through my iPod. They also have a full bar on-site, a nice touch; I had a few glasses of red wine to go with my pie. Being from the Northeast I had reservations about the Chicago style deep dish pizza, but my meal here made me a believer. The ingredients were all of high quality In the crust itself was delicious.  I still prefer New York style pizza, however if I had a place like this near my home I am sure I would eat their from time to time. Five stars for a nothing-but-positive Chicago deep-dish pizza experience.  After I finished my pie, I jumped in an Uber and headed to my next destination, but that is another story!

You cannot go wrong with this famous Chicago Pizza spot!  We have been here twice.  I purposely planned to have lunch here at the end of our trip when I had no little dresses to fit into later that night and when we were slightly hungover.   The first time we ordered cheese sticks, were seemed like traditional frozen cheese sticks and a deep dish pizza with pepperoni.  It was amazing, not like anything I've ever had.  One or two slices per person is PLENTY! Second time my husband ordered breadsticks to start and we ordered the traditional deep dish, sausage.  It was so good!

I like this pizza place! The wait time for the pizza was 45 min. I had the Chicago famous and the shop's special and both were amazing! Had my first Chicago style deep dish pizza here and it was an awesome experience. Our waiter helped cut our pizza too, which was a bonus :)

Look. I'm giving this 4 stars but not because it was really good pizza.  It was good...something...but we really need to come up with a different word for what this is.  It might be in the pizza order, but it is not the same species as pizza.  That said, because we don't have a word for it yet, I will call it pizza.  But it isn't pizza. I don't get it Chicago, I really don't.  There isn't a comparison to be made between NY pizza (or, just pizza, for short) and Chicago deep dish.  How do you compare the two?  How can you possibly say one is better than the other?  It's like saying chocolate is better than football or unicorns are better than rainbows.  It's not comparable. Let me get on to the "pizza" for a moment - it is 4 star worthy food.  I would probably go 3.5 if I could, but I can't, and its definitely better than a 3.  Heck, it better be since this is the go-to for Chicago pizza...depending on who you ask.  Apparently, you can ask 20 people in Chicago for the best pizza and get 20 different answers, but that's not much different from NY.  Anyway, I got the Lou, or something like that.  It's their signature deep dish pizza with butter crust and a flavorful tomato sauce and cheese.  It's basically what you would expect a deep dish pizza to be, though I am not sure I would go with the butter crust again.  It was good, but a bit too heavy on the buttery goodness. My girlfriend and I sat on the patio and the service was good out there, though we failed to read anything that would have warned us the food takes 35-40 minutes or else we would have planned our day better and not gotten so annoyed by the wait.  Once the food came, I will admit I devoured it.  Again, it's not that it wasn't good, it's just that you walk in expecting to be floored and really struggle with the idea of NY v. Chicago pizza.  There is no struggle, there is no contest. So, again, its good, but its not pizza.  This is what you get if your pizza was bloated, or perhaps if your pizza was allergic to bees and got stung, or nuts and was served with sausage cooked in peanut oil.  It deserves its own name and its own category.  But please, for the love of all that is good and holy in the world, stop calling it pizza and stop comparing it to NY.

WOW, the pizzas and salads are so good!  Be prepared to wait about 35-45 minutes for your pizza to be ready - but it's worth the wait. I really loved the bright green Malnati Salad. I ended up buying a bottle of the salad dressing to bring home - it's a sweet vinaigrette. This was my first time having deep dish pizza and it didn't disappoint.  The crust was thick but not heavy feeling. It was perfect.

The BEST pizza I've ever had! I am so stoked that you can order online and have it shipped to your house too! Makes me very happy because I can get a little slice of Chicago in California whenever I please!

This place is as good as the other Lou's I've been at (e.g. Buffalo Grove) - so its good in consistency: salads, deep dish, thin, service, the sauce, appetizers. Not much more to say: all of these are the same in quality and quantity - good pizza, good service, good food. Deep dish Classic is great in its sauce, crust is nice and buttery, sausage is tasty. 'Nuff said. Plenty of parking in the premise's lot, and street parking is available too. Wait staff were kind and helpful, even with a 4 year old boy who's a bit fidgety; the waiter was playing nice with him, trying to include him into the ordering process and conversation. Definitely a nice touch to get in touch with his customers!

It's all about that BUTTER CRUST! While it's a little on the heavy side for me, it's still one of those deep dish pizzas you have to try in Chicago. I like their tomato sauce, it's quite flavorful. I feel like it's chunkier than Gio's? I can only eat one slice, so I try to make sure to enjoy each bite. Good thing it's not as cheesy as Gio's, because then I would probably be way too full and bloated. I know it sounds weird, but their salads are pretty freaking legit. Especially since the pizza is so heavy, it's nice to balance it out with some fresh, yummy salad! Not too much dressing, and not too heavy on the little bits of salami meat. Definitely try the salad!

Bottom line--I like Lou's more than I like the other top named Chicago deep dish restaurant.  Choosing the better pizza between the two is a lot like trying to chose between being catholic or protestant--subject to deeply held personal beliefs and open to violent argument. I found Lou's much more user-friendly and comfortable, and the calamari was a wonderful surprise.  My daughter and I split the Malnati Chicago Classic, with sausage, extra cheese and vine-ripened tomato sauce on butter crust. Oh my.  I'll definitely return.

No trip to Chicago should be completed without a visit to Lou Malnati's. If you're looking for delicious deep dish pizza, this is the place to go.  When I knew I was going to visit Chicago, the only thing I really wanted to do was get good deep dish pizza. I was Lou Malnati's was the place to go, so we went on my first night there. We got two orders of pizza, cheese and pepperoni. Both tasted like magic and happiness. I liked both a lot, but I have to say the pepperoni was better since I like my pizza with more than cheese. The crust was also buttery which made it all the better.

Fantastic Pizza.  Great taste on all levels, sauce, crust, meat, cheese all came together for a great mouth watering experience.  Call ahead if you can to order as yes, it does take awhile to cook a deep dish pizza.   I have eaten at three other landmark pizza establishments in Chicago and this one is my favorite.  the left overs the next day were so delicious.  thanks Lou for doing it right.

Relatively underwhelming.  45 minute wait quoted upon arrival so we took a spot at the bar.  Acceptable sauvignon blanc, some mozzarella sticks (decent) and calamari  (quite good) to tide us over. Never once did the hostess or bartender mention we should pre-order our pizza. We were sat at our table and our waitress asked if we'd pre-ordered. Huh?  If that's an option and suggestion, perhaps sharing that upon entering the queue would be appropriate.  Pizza finally arrived about 2 hours after we did (a good hour after we were sat) and...it was COLD! Hah.  Kind of funny.  The flavors were good, the crust was a bit tough but I gather that's a choice...the sausage had a nice flavor but was dry.   We were given a complementary cookie pizza for our troubles and it was completely melted upon arrival (ice cream on top). An underwhelming experience overall.

I wanted to go to some "Epic" place to celebrate the kiddo's birthday dinner. Since we were visiting Chicago and Lou Malnati's is a must try place for Chicago Deep Dish Pizza, we went there.  There was a 1.5 hour wait time even on a Thursday night, which we killed by ordering wine/drinks, coffee etc from the bar. You can also give your pizza orders in advance since it takes some time to cook the Pizza. We tried the Sausage Pizza and the Vegetarian Pizza. So far the best Chicago Style Pizza I've ever had. The butter crust makes a huge difference. I loved their cookie sundae as well - must try! The best part of going there was that we got a quiet corner to ourselves upstairs to cut the birthday cake we got from another bakery and celebrate in privacy.
Great Chicago deep dish! A must if you're visiting Chi-town. Long lines but well worth the wait. Unlike any deep dish I've ever experienced. Light buttery crust. I recommend plain old fashion cheese!

You know you have arrived at a tourist place when there are suitcases by the waiting area of the restaurant.  My friends and I went to Lou Malnati's on a Friday night and the place was packed. We waited about 25 minutes which was not bad at all. The upstairs seating was looked nicer and more comfortable than the seats downstairs. This place is huge.  We ordered a salad, a chicken sandwich, and the deep dish with the sausage. I really enjoyed the deep dish, although after eating I could tell it was really heavy. The buttery crust was really nice though. It was a good thing we ordered salad because it balanced out the heavy pizza. It was really good, but I think I can only have it when I am really hungry.
Pizzas good,  wait is atrocious,  and takes away from the experience.  Get delivery. Not enough seats in the bar.

First time experiencing deep dish pizza and it wall all worth it. Love the classic Lou pizza and the flat bread pizza has an amazing flavor. Wait time trends to be long, so make sure to pre-order while waiting to be seated.

The Malnati salad it was amazing, it was over a five star review. The salad came with the delicious sweet onion dressing that I could've eaten by the spoonful. The salad came out with salami Gorgonzola cheese tomato chunks mushrooms and olives. This was our first Chicago pizza experience, I thought the dough would be a little more deep dish if you will meaning I thought it would be a little thicker.  Based on the waitresses recommendation we got a half cheese half special, which it had a sausage base. My husband thought that the sausage was an overkill and pretty much thought he was eating just a layer of sausage on his pizza.   My half with just cheese was pretty decent, I was happy with it and the flavor that came with and the buttery crust.  This is a popular at landmark so I would recommend going here and trying it out and seeing how you feel about it Also there are many people waiting outside but when we walked in and asked for a table of two we had no wait. The pizzas take a 30 to 40 minutes to cook so be prepared for that.

If you're in Chicago, deep dish pizza is a must. & Lou's pizza is the absolute best. A friend & I were looking for Gazzola's pizza in the area yesterday, HIMYM fans will know about this place. What we didn't know is that it doesn't exist. We found the closest pizza place from our location & couldn't have been happier with what we found.  We shared the house pizza (Lou's) & are planning on going back again tomorrow.

If you like a ton of meat on your pie, then this is the place for you! We ordered pep and sausage, it had a ton/ whole layer of sausage. The crust was awesome and buttery and the sauce was amazing. Best part is, they deliver!

What an amazing experience! The waitress was extremely helpful about what to do around town, and what to order on the menu. The Malnati salad is the best salad I've EVER had. I would recommend it! I was sad I didn't get a large! I ordered their Malnati Chicago classic deep dish pizza medium, with onions. Overall, this place. If you want good service, good food, good atmosphere, then this is the place to go!!

We got the Lou. This is the first time I've had Lou's in about 15 years. I wanted to double check my latest opinion that Giordano's was better. Last time when I had Lou Malnati's the group ordered sausage and I wasn't a fan of the huge patty of sausage on the pizza. A bit too much for me. This time getting the Lou, which is all veggies I enjoyed it much more.  So, I think it comes down to this for me... Giordano's has thicker cheese and thicker and softer crust. If you like less cheese you'll probably prefer Lou's if you like lots of cheese you'll probably like Giordano's better. In my experience, Giordano's also has more sauce on their pizza...so if you love or hate sauce, that could make a difference too.
Really good deep dish but the service not so great.  My server was too busy chitchatting and dropped my slice cheese side down on the table.  Not cool.

Again the yelp rating fooled me. The deep dish pizza here is very average tasting. Garlic bread was horrible.  I  ordered lou and classic pizza were both disappointing. some part of the pizza was soggy. personal pizza the size was pretty big though.
Best Chicago pizza. That's all I have to say about that.
This was our first experience with deep dish pizza and it could not have been better! The crust was so buttery. I will be coming back next time I come to Chicago!

We couldn't visit Chicago--with some CA friends--without going to Lou Malnati's! Lunch time was a good time to go--not too crowded but still full of hungry hungry hippos. We started with the Malnati salad, which was WTF the best salad I've ever had. The dressing was perfect--didn't coat the salad too much, but enough to give it a nice flavor. Easily our favorite part of the salad were the salami bits--crunchy, not chewy. I could eat that salad all day, every day. The calamari was also great; not too much breading but enough to coat the calamari to give it some crunch.  Our pizzas of choice were the Malnati Chicago Classic and the Lou. First off, the Chicago Classic was easily the best sausage pizza I've ever had. Mainly because there was sausage in every. single. bite. We liked that it was an actual layer of sausage vs chunks spread all over the place. Good call. The Lou was delicious--nothing to write home about, but we weren't disappointed in it. We expected more from the buttercrust on both pizzas; it just didn't wow us. I'm a fan of deep dish, but our friends were more into New York style. But overall, it was a satisfying lunch for a bunch of first timers!

This was really good deep dish pizza. I have never had deep dish pizza before but this hit the spot. The cheese was really stretchy and the sausage was full of flavor. The pizza does take a while to cook so make sure you have plenty of time. The Sercice was only ok at the best however the service does not have much to do because they take your order downstairs.

I HAD to try deep dish while visiting Chicago and this place happened to be along my walk. It was a Saturday night and it was totally packed. We put our name in AND our order (because they take a long time to make) and then went to get a drink at a bar next door while we waited. They called when our table was ready and we went back to be seated. We were seated in a room of other tourists, apparently, because the Blackhawks were on every TV and scored a bunch of times and no one said a word..so it was clear we were all out of towners. Even though we had ordered the pizza when we put our name in for the table, it still took kinda a long time. We ordered some calamari to munch on in the mean time. It wasn't very good, tasted like typical bar food calamari and wasn't very hot either. It was serviced with cocktail sauce, as opposed to marinara sauce. We asked for marinara sauce, but it never came. The calamari got even colder so we finally just ate it with the cocktail sauce because our waitress was MIA (we also asked for water that took us a couple of times of reminding her before we got those). The pizza was good, but filling. I don't know how authentic it was, since we were clearly in a tourist trap. Definitely order the small if you're sharing just between two people. It's way more filling than it looks. We also got the deep dish brownie dessert, which was average. Overall, I liked the pizza but the apps weren't impressive and neither was the service. The place also lacked ambiance..good thing that butter crust was so darn good.
Absolutely the best Chicago style pizza I've ever had. There was a long wait, but well worth it. The crust is incredible, the sausage was delicious, and the cheese was as good as it gets.

I guess this means I'm officially a New York pizza guy. Lou Malnati's was right by our hotel and seems to be one of the places to get good Chicago deep dish pizza. We went for lunch on a weekday, and it wasn't very busy. There was no hostess, so we had to ask the bartender if we had to seat ourselves--he said no, there should be a hostess. Finally she came out and immediately seated us. She was actually very nice. We settled on each getting a lunch special--a personal pizza with a small salad. The special meant the pizzas only took about 15 minutes to make as opposed to the normal 35 minutes. Our salads came out, and they were exactly what you'd expect from a pizza place. Nothing special, but at least they were something to eat. The pizza eventually came out, and they only cut it one direction, so I had to wrestle with it to cut normal sized pieces. It was okay--the crust good, but some seemed underdone. It was very filling--no need for anything more than a personal. My dad's pepperoni was better than my plain. Service was fine, the waitress switched out pizzas around but that was no big deal. If you like Chicago style pizza, Lou Malnati's probably is the greatest thing since sliced bread. If not...eh.

This is where you go if you are an out of towner and want to try a Chicago deep dish pizza.  I went here because a friend suggested it and I was not disappointed. Very delicious pizza and very nice portion. The recommended sizes to person amount is pretty spot on. I was dining with one other person; we got the medium that feeds 2-3 people only because we wanted leftovers for the plane. It would have been the perfect amount for 3 people. Unfortunately they don't have a location directly in downtown so we had to travel a bit but it was worth it. Get the Lou Malnati's special with sausage and buttery crust!

Best deep dish pizza in Chicago on my opinion. Waiters are nice, draft beer is good, and the pizza are absolutely delicious. Portions are smaller than in other deep dish restaurants though. If you eat a lot or are very hungry, you might want to consider about taking starters. I shared a medium (3person) pizza with a friend and we finished it all easily. Update: I am going there regularly. The Lou's deep dish is my favorite. After some other deep dish restaurants in Chicago, Lou is still the best.

Ordered in for a working lunch. Unfortunately when you're still working by the time you actually get to sit down to eat your food is cold. But having said that, the salad was delish. They're dressing is what makes the difference.  It's sweet and tangy. I believe we had the thin crust pizza, cut into squares. Even cold it was good. Hopefully on my next trip to Chicago I can visit the restaurant and enjoy it fresh and hot.

It was my first time in Chicago so naturally I kept hearing that I just had to try deep dish pizza. Lou's was recommended as one of the best in town. I don't know what all the hype is about. I only had one piece. It did taste good but it is pretty hard to mess up pizza entirely. It is not something I will schedule into my visit next time I am in Chicago.  Personally, the crust was too hard and crunchy on the edges and I did not like how thick the layer of cheese was. It did have a good sauce though and the perfect amount of it. In my opinion it is worth a try. It's a local cuisine so why not go for it if you are feeling touristy. I think I just prefer other styles more.

It was our first intro to the deep dish pizza. We have decided to stick with the classic one. Absolutely fabulous - fresh ingredients, impeccable dough - melted in our mouth.  We have ordered medium size for two - took a couple pieces to go.  The place was packed, so they have offered us to place our order while we have still been waiting for a table. Great idea - the pizza have arrived almost at the same time as we have been seated. Beer selection was sufficient, but could be better if this is something you are interested in to wash down your awsome pizza.

Of all the Chicago-style pizza chains, Lou Malnati's is the best. The buttery crust and the fresh tomato sauce are great. Clutch toppings are spinach and sausage.  You can really taste how fresh the ingredients are and I can't stress that enough.  A bit pricey, but a great atmosphere for entertaining out-of-towners.
Want perfectly cooked and breaded calamari? Want great Chicago style pizza? Want great service? Come here. It's worth the wait. The best in Chicago.

As a Chicago native now living in California, I was really looking forward to some great deep dish pizza when visiting Chi Town recently. Lou Malnati's was underwhelming. Pizza was just OK. Great crust, cooked just right, but really pretty bland. The sausage seemed to have no real flavor, which is not what I expect in Chicago. Since there's no real "sauce" on a deep dish pizza, the other ingredients need to carry the day when it comes to flavor. Even on a pizza loaded up with bell peppers, onion, mushrooms, and sausage, I could only say, "meh".  Service was great, wait time was a tolerable 20 minutes on Saturday night, so no complaints other than bland pizza. But that's a pretty serious complaint at a Chicago Pizza institution, so I'll go elsewhere next time.
The deep dish pizzas were fine. The decor and service were good. I just prefer the NY style pizzas.

My dinner started off good... I was able to preorder my pizza and got seated fairly quickly. It went down hill from there. The service was some of the worst I've ever had.  I don't know if it was because I was alone or because I was a tourist.  I waited 10 minutes for someone  to ask me if I wanted a drink. I flagged someone down and asked who my waiter was and he said it was some other guy. I could not even order a freaking water. So finally my waiter came and I ordered a beer and a water. Another 10+ minutes. So i sat 20 to 25 minutes without even a glass of water.  The pizza was decent.  The crust was a little overcooked but it had a good flavor.  I just couldn't get over the poor service.

Visited Lou Malnati's Pizzeria during a business trip to Chicago.  Went on a Friday night and the place was packed!  It took ~ 35 minutes to be seated for 3 people.  But, in order to speed up efficiency, they allow you to preorder your pizza so that it will be ready for you once you are seated in your table.  For the 3 of us, we ordered the "Lou" at a medium size since it said that it would be good for 4 people.  Once we sat down, it unfortunately took longer for the pizza to be brought out, and we ended up waiting for ~20 minutes for our pizza once we were seated.   The pizza itself is so packed with stuff, it's ridiculous.  There's tons of cheese, tomatoes and tomato sauce.  The crust is impecable with a crunchy and buttery taste.  Just be warned though, after eating one slice, you might get food coma.  All 3 of us got food coma after eating 1-2 slices of the "Lou," and ended up having to call it a night.  But, the pizza itself was delicious.  Highly recommend it if you're visiting Chicago.

I don't give five stars often; so let the deep-dish pizza debate begin!  I'm a Lou Malnati's fan and have been for a long time. I've been coming to this location over the last year and a half.  It's now one of my favorites in town.  I love the neighborhood feel I get every time I come here, especially when any of the local sports teams are on TV.  The bartenders are always fun and friendly. The service has always been swift and friendly.  To me, Lou's has the best deep-dish in town! (I just pissed off a bunch of people...LOL!) That's right, I say it!  Lou's the Best!   The butter crust starts it over the top, then the savory sausage in every bite...pushes it over! I order one of two pizzas every time I'm in town, "The Malnati Chicago Classic" or a Thin Crust Sausage; both are absolutely the best around. I really can't say anything more.  This is one of the coolest places in town to have a pizza and watch Chicago game on TV.  Feels like home. Enough said!

Our first true Chicago style pizza was enjoyed here for dinner on a slow starting Monday night. We were seated upstairs at a nice big round comfortable table for our group of five out of owners. Our waitress filled us in on just how "dense" and filling their pizzas are despite their somewhat smaller diameter. We all were on the same mission to enjoy great pizza. My wife and I decided to split a small size Classic Lou Malnati's with Italian sausage. To start we all ordered local beers, the tortilla chips with three dips (for the veggie in our group) and cheese sticks for the one guy who thought he wouldn't get enough cheese with his pizza. The apps were fine and tasty along with the nice cold beers.  It wasn't long before our pizzas came out. My wife and I found the small size to be perfect for the two of us to split. The crust was crisp despite being quite thick, the extra thick layer of cheese was yummy without being gut filling, the sauce had a nice texture and taste to it and the sausages on top were lean and paired nicely overall with the pizza. Usually my wife has to sponge the extra grease off the top of her pizza with a napkin but not at all here.  We both loved the pizza and can't wait to return and try a different one.

I am absolutely disgusted by this pizza that I had delivered to me and my co-worker. I am not going to go in, but the picture is enough to see that the pizza is clearly burnt and felt like we were eating crackers with hard cheese and some sort of meat on it. I can't believe they are delivering pizzas like this from the great and mighty Lou Malnati's. You should be ashamed for this sort of quality. Will never order from this place or dine again. Just order from Pizano's.
Wow. Thank you Yelpers for the recommendation on the spinach cheese bread. Get it. Had a Lou's house salad and a Lou'd personal size as well. Great atmosphere and great food. Quality all around.
We've been on a Lou Malnati's kick lately. Always opt for the thin crust, well done and not cut for take out. The crispy crust just hits the spot every single time.
Amazing personal pies. The Lou and the Classic are amazing. Make the trip and wait for the food - bout 30-40 min for you really pizzas but so with it

I have gone to Lou Malnati's for their delicious deep dish pizza each of the two times I have visited Chicago. During both of my trips, I tried various other deep dish pizzas (Giordano's, Gino's, Pizzeria Uno), and I have to admit that Lou Malnati's has my favorite all-around deep dish pizza. They win be over with their delicious Buttercrust and perfect combination of cheese, sausage, and tomato sauce in their Malnati Chicago Classic deep dish pizza. Their trio of dips and pizza chips is a great starter if you're into hummus and artichoke-type dips.  I can't finish a meal without having dessert, so their Chocolate Chip Pizza was a perfect ending to my experience. Warm, fresh baked cookie topped with vanilla ice cream and a ton of whipped cream. Delish!
The Vegetarian Deep Dish was amazing! I went to a couple other places and had it and it was not nearly as good! Bartenders are super nice too!

This was my first trip to Lou Malnatis, and my first taste of true Chicago deep dish pizza. Our group ordered 2 medium deep dish 1 pepperoni and 1 called the Lou which was "spinach mix", tomatoes and mushrooms- we ordered no mushrooms. We also got a combination app which included mozzarella sticks, fried zucchini, cheddar cubes, and fried mushrooms, and we got one called the dips with pizza chips-3 different styles of dips 1-spinach dip, 1- hummus, and 1- garlic spread. Needless to say our party of 4 had plenty of leftovers.  The Good- everything I tasted was delicious, I had mozzarella sticks, cheddar cubes, and the pepperoni pizza. The fried items were hot, fresh and not greasy, and the marinara that came with was very good. My favorite though was the pizza. The crust was buttery and crispy-somewhere between a biscuit and pizza crust, the cheese was plentiful and had that nice stretchy factor, the pepperoni was tasty, a little spicy and the sauce was great-not too heavy, lightly seasoned and just the right amount. My dining partners really enjoyed everything. The location was perfect for us-not too far from parking. The not so good-now I will say, we arrived on a Saturday around 5:30, so there was a wait, we were told 35 mins- not terrible-especially considering the nice weather, it's a weekend in downtown Chicago and the NFL draft was in town. So being our first visit it gave a chance to look over the menu, and because deep dish takes quite a while to bake, they tell you to preorder your pizza with the cashier so it'll be ready close to when your seated. We did end up actually waiting about 45 mins- and with how packed it was we waited outside- not terrible as the weather was great-but we constantly felt in the way of pedestrians and other patrons waiting. Now when we got our call saying they had a table ready we had to go back inside and wait behind people who were waiting to get on the list- it's was very unorganized to say the least. Seating was very tight quarters and the noise level is astronomical, I couldn't even hear our server. Service was chaotic, took a long time to get refills and napkins. She was very nice though, and I don't hold her completely responsible, as it was super busy. Parking- the proximity of where we parked to the restaurant was not at all bad-it was the cost. $18.00 for 2 hours! Parking in downtown Chicago is a pain and crazy expensive, however this is not the restaurants fault.  Overall our experience was good, and we will go back. Just try to get there earlier, find cheaper parking and hope we get a better table.
This is easily the best pizza I've ever had. We got the "Lou" with pepperoni. Delicious.

I wanted to try this place so bad as I have heard that it's the best in town and I have to say that it is not what I expected.  My expectations may have been too high.  We were not happy with the service either, it was very busy and I'm sure that's the reason it was not up to par.  Every time we have tried to get into a Lou's (which is only 2 times) it's always been super busy which is obviously a great sign that the food is off the charts, but it just wasn't for us.  The wings were overcooked and we ordered a small deep dish pizza and I'm not normally one to complain about wait times but this one was pushing and hour and fifteen minutes which to us is a long time for a small.  The appetizer came out in 10 minutes which surprised us, but as I said before it was overcooked and the time between the 2 dishes was a little too much.  Maybe we should come back when we don't expect it to be as busy.
I'm not a huge fan of deep dish but this pizza was amazing! I eat pizza all over the US and stopped here on a business trip. The service was quick and the food was great.

I was pretty excited to try Chicago deep dish pizza for the first time, but the one i had from this place was worse than what I've had in California. The veggie special didn't come with sauce, and one of the three cheeses on top looked to be cheddar. Wish i could have a do over
Very good pizza. Had a party and ordered many even tried the veggie. not my thing but was very good. It was no meat lovers but good. Great Chicago pizza
We love our Lou's, but since this location doesn't take reservations, it can get extremely crowded with no place to wait without bumping into others. Try coming during off peak times.

This was the first restaurant we visited during our Chicago trip - we went in with high expectations of the "best chicago pizza" (due to yelp and friends' reccos) and unfortunately left less than satisfied. The pizza was above average, but the service ruined it for us. It was about 2:30pm on a Wednesday, and our intended quick bite turned into a 2.5 hour venture. Upon ordering we were told it would take 35-40 min, which was fine...but after an hour we were finally served a luke warm pizza - on top of that it wasn't what we had ordered. Asking for a side of ranch, our bill and water refills took 20 min each. I'm pretty understanding when it comes to popular spots but there were hardly any tables filled. Decent pizza, the slowest service... **updated 1 year later- back on a Wednesday coincidently, service was great and the food was amazing. Totally redeemed :)
awesome deep dish pizza liked it more than other popular pizzerias. Even thin crust pizzas are very good here. We take all of our visiting friends for a Chicago's popular deep dish pizza experience.

Wanted to love this place.  Sadly, both the food and service didn't meet expectations.  I went on a Monday night when the restaurant was half empty. Sat at the bar and ordered a personal pizza.   It came out one hour later.   Turns out my order ticket fell on the floor of the kitchen.  If the restaurant were busy, I may have been sympathetic.  But considering that the staff stood around talking to each other and complaining about customers' orders and neediness (not a good look), I would have expected prompt and efficient service.   When the pizza did arrive, it was nothing special.  Zachary's Pizza in the Bay kicks Lou Malnati's butt.  Could have been that my forgotten pizza was thrown together, but both the ingredients and construction were blah.   To his credit, the bartender was apologetic and comped my meal.  The one star is for him.   Go elsewhere or go when the place is busier and kitchen more attentive.
Absolutely phenomenal food and service. My server even made Barq's root beer sound like a delicious treat. Gotta love it.

Disclaimer: not a particular fan of deep dish pizza. That out of the way, Lou Malnati's is pretty good. Nice location in River North, a little bar combined with a modestly sized dining room complete with wood paneling and booths on the first floor, and make sure you show up early. We aimed for only a modestly early dinner and had only a few minutes' wait for our group, which was good because we were able to put our order in ahead of time. By the time we left-- the place was PACKED, with a massive wait. Service was pretty good, servers did a decent job presenting the pizza and serving it, even as the crowds began to hammer in. And the pizza... we had a cheese and two of the specials. Even though I normally don't care for plain cheese, due to the insanity that is a slice of deep dish, the simplicity actually helped. There's just a lot going on with a deep dish, and a more plain one seems to work. Crust is a bit plain, but considering how crazy thick/cheesy/intensive the rest is, that's a reasonable compromise. Probably have to skip the combinations and maybe try a pepperoni or sausage the next time to see how it compares. Or maybe order a few for delivery...

I would like to update my review based upon my recent experience at this location. I might have been a little hangry when I wrote my last review, so I decided to give this location another try.  To avoid the long wait times for dinner during the weekend, we decided to order to go. We order the Malnati Chicago Classic, The Lou and the Malnati Salad. I don't know if we just ordered on a "good day," but the Classic was cooked perfectly with the right amount of sauce. It wasn't dry at all. I actually prefer the Lou over the Classic because it's not has heavy and hardy as the Classic. I would also recommend getting the Malnati Salad. Their home made sweet vinaigrette is extremely addicting and makes you crave more salad.  TIP: Order to go! Don't get hangry like I did the last time I was here. You're not you when you're hungry.

It was our first time in Chicago and we had to try the deep dish pizza. We waited for an hour on a Saturday evening and pre-ordered our pizzas. We ordered the personal size Malnati Chicago Classic (for the husband) and the small "Lou" pizza (for us to share).  My husband really liked the Malnati since there was a lot of sausage pressed in the pizza. He said that the sausage did not have fat in it either.  I liked the Lou as it was a vegetarian pizza with spinach, mushroom, and tomatoes. The pizza was heavy on the cheese with mozzarella, romano, and cheddar. The deep dish crust was thinner than I expected, but the overall flavors were delicious.  Service could have been better since it took a while for our waitress to welcome us when we sat down at our table.  I wish the restaurant had more bathrooms. There was one women stall for the first level of the restaurant.

We loved the pizza!! We needed a place that had Chicago style pizza but also a gluten free option and both pizza's were great! I am gluten free and let me just say their gluten free pizza is the BEST I have ever had!! So good!! Highly recommend!

Being a huge fan of NYC style pizza, I was skeptical about Chicago deep dish. This place was delicious. The pizza was perfect! We ordered the calamari as an appetizer and it was great as well. The marinara was spicy and very tasty. The only downside is the long wait time.

We were in town and had to try Lou's as it is known to be the best pizza in Chicago. We went in on a Thursday evening, right at dinner time, the wait was quoted at 45-60 minutes. We were told we should preorder our pizza to cut down on the wait once we were seated.We (family of 5) ordered a large half sausage half pepperoni with the butter crust. We waited the quoted time and once we were seated we ordered drinks and calamari to start off. Our waitress was prompt and courteous.  OMG...this pizza was so so good. I am not really a deep dish pizza fan because I hate when crust gets soggy or even worse, greasy. Lou Malnati's crust was neither, in fact it was crispy and delicious. The pizza sauce is incredibly light and fresh. We all loved the pizza and were stuffed when we left...not even room left to share dessert. In fact we had one slice on pizza leftover. This pizza was worth every single calorie. We tried Pequod's Pizza as well and thought that Lou's was better. I would highly recommend Lou's for great service and awesome pizza.

This has got to be the best place for Chicago style pizza. It is both affordable and good. Be sure you go well in advance of when you want to eat as there was an hour wait for us. We had no issues with this as they had been highly reccomended and we were on vacation so there was no issue waiting!

I'm not an expert on Chicago deep dish, but my personal pizza was excellent. Added the spinach mix to the Chicago classic, which added in a little basil.  Nice combo. Crust was nice and crunchy.  Good ambiance and good vibe.  I would definitely come back here.

Chicago deep dish pizza...  oh yea... My first Chicago pizza, awesome. I don't know what this place does but the sausage in their house made sausage is absolutely amazing.   Pizza that is crisp and gooey at the same time with classic flavor profile from the tomatoes and cheese.  It's difficult to write just these few words without salivating... The place is crowded and takes a bit of a wait to get in, it's worth the wait.

I don't like deep dish. I  don't like sausage. I'm also from California. But when I travel to Chicago, you can bet I'll be at Lou Malnati's for some sausage deep dish pizza! Just thinking about it is making me hungry!
Food is very good.  Busy and loud, just the way I like it!  Eat at the bar... The service is great there!!

My impression of the pizza here was "meh." I ordered their "signature" sausage with their butter crust and was pretty underwhelmed. I think the pizza here is on par with giordanos but a step or two below pequods or kaisers (my place of choice for deep dish; the latter is wayyy up north in Gurnee but man it's delish). I wouldn't really come here again unless someone paid for me (in which case I would probably suggest going to pequods).  I saw a good tour roll through when I was eating lunch and that looked fun though.

I've never heard of this place and it's a shame because I'm obsessed with pizza and I live in Chicago! Once I found out about it we had to go. With tons of reviews, why shouldn't we. Pizza is awesome, fresh sauce and believe me you can tell. The right amount of cheese and the crust was amazing. Not many deep dish places you go to and you actually enjoy the crust, but this place has it going on. The wait is a bit long but expected when it comes to deep dish. I didn't like the shoes and skateboards on the wall, kind of a dirty thing to have in a restaurant. Other than that it would've been 5 stars for me.

Ok, I chose this place because of all the yelp reviews but I don't get why it's so highly rated. The pizza was ok but not 4 or 5 stars good. I went here twice on a recent trip to Chicago. The first time I got the classic with sausage tomatoes and the butter crust. I was super underwhelmed. The crust had hardly any flavor. The sauce and the sausage were flavorful but overall I just thought it was kinda boring and not at all exceptional.  Since I was sure the first experience was a fluke, I ate there again but got their vegetarian special--can't remember the name. This was better than the traditional. I thought it had a better and more interesting flavor. The spinach/garlic flavor was nice against the robust sauce, but the crust was still bland.  Overall, the pizza was ok, but I would never go out of my way to eat here again. Two times was plenty.

A little off the beaten path, but a fantastic pizza.  We got the Lou!, which is a deep dish spinach mushroom pizza with tomato slices perfectly roasted on top.  We spit it between four people, and at 2 pieces each it was perfect. We preordered our pizza while waiting in line, definitely reccommended if you are in a time crunch.  We were on our way to the train station, and this saved us at least 20 minutes of waiting at the table.  Service was great, and the kids even loved their meals of burgers, spaghetti, and chicken.  A definite winner!  I might even try ordering one to be shipped to Michigan someday.

I live in Chicago for many years, with a habit of dining out, at least 2 to 3 times a week.  In regards to the food, price, service, management and overall experience Lou Malnati's gets nothing less than 5 stars in each of these categories! Delicious food, great portions at a fair price, and an amazing service and management! You can't go wrong by spending your time and money there. This is a restaurant that really appreciates their customers. Very traditional place with great food and solid reputation that you can only construct with consistency and generous and caring customer service! My husband and I went there a few times and we were never disappointed. In one occasion our order delayed to come out, and within seconds the manager, by his own initiative, came to our table very apologetic explaining the reason for the delay. We were very pleased with his concern and initiative.  But the customer appreciation did not stop there: When we asked for the bill, the waiter informed us it was fully on the house. We did not saw this coming as during the entire time we were there the server was consistently asking if we would like to have more appetizers and drinks while waiting for the dinner. We expressed that we were very satisfied with the experience and wanted to pay as we were already very pleased with all the consideration, but the manager insisted that it was their way to say thank you for the time we spent there. Amazing!
AMAZING pizza! And the best minestrone I've ever had! This is a must have while you're in Chicago!! Don't leave town without checking this place out! And get the butter crust!!!!!

We received a gift from our Chicago daughter and son-in-law of two Malnati's cheese and sausage pizzas FedXed with dry ice. They arrived perfectly; having an average ambient temperature en route of 10 degrees in February probably helped. I don't think I've ever had a real deep dish pizza before. Pizzeria Uno doesn't count, and that was years ago. I followed the exact baking directions and the results were fabulous. Impressed by the real pie-like crust and the distinct layers of sausage and cheese. No opportunity to skimp on ingredients when they are stacked. I'm a fan, but I won't try to get deep dish here in Rochester because I'm sure to be disappointed. So frequent visits to Chicago are in the future.
Awesome Chicago style pizza. I ordered the personal size Lou. Very yummy! The crust is very light! Nice selection of local beers - which always goes really well with pizza!

This is it. You want deep dish, you go to Malnati's. As a semi-native (I left the Midwest young, but visited often), Lou Malnati's was always my #1. They ferment their dough for a bit so it takes on a sourdough flavor, which I love! I personally always go for the classic, which has a layer of sausage along with the hearty helping of cheese and sauce. The Lou is great too with cheddar, tomatoes slices, sauce and more mozz. But really? Just order the classic. You'll be satisfied.  I've gotten takeout here and also have eaten in. It's often packed so be prepared for a wait. I came with my boyfriend one year and we chose to just sit at the bar, which only adds to the experience. Pizza must be enjoyed with a beer.  Either way this place is history. You have to go and try it. One must learn to love deep dish pizza. It also should be eaten with a fork and knife. That's just how it is.
This is my favorite pizza place in Chicago. I was never a big fan of deep dish until I found The Lou!

Either I'm a REAAALLLY picky eater and or I'm just hard to please. I was visiting Chicago for 3 days and I HAD to try this place since it's one of the top & most rated deep dish pizza place. I LOVE deep dish (although I haven't tried that many places) because I love LOTS and LOTS of sauce. Expecting my pizza to be filled with extra layers of sauce, I was a bit disappointed to bite into my first slice and found out it's just all bread & cheese with little sauce... If you're a cheese lover, this place is the place for you. If you're a sauce person like me, the pizza will be overwhelmingly cheesy. It fills you up or you get sick of it after once slice. Regardless, I'm so glad to have tried this place.

Being a New York/Jersey native, I'm used to that classic style thin crust pizza. If there's one thing that always brings a smile to my face, it's a slice of delicious pizza. So when I heard about deep dish pizza, I kind of cringed at the thought of mountains of bread and cheese on a pizza. Until I came to Lou Malnati's. Grabbed a seat at the bar and got the run down from the bartender on how they concoct this child size pizza. You can either have a pre-made pizza which is ready in about 10 minutes, or have a pizza made from scratch. I went for a small pepperoni deep dish made from scratch, which takes 35 minutes to make...  What came out after 35 minutes changed my view on pizza forever. From the first slice, which is cut and served to you by the bartender, I was taken to a happy place. The best part of this pizza is hands down, the sauce. There's an abundance of it and it taste as if someone spent hours putting it together. It's about as perfect of pizza sauce as you can get. There is a massive amount of cheese and bread, causing most human beings not to be able to finish a small pie. I was able to get through three out of the four slices. But those three slices were absolute perfection. Everything mixed perfectly. And just when you think it can't any better, you get to the crust, which is crispy buttery goodness that is seriously almost as good as the pizza. I'm not a crust guy at all, but this crust is amazing. Not much else to say here. I now understand the hype around deep dish pizza, and I've seen the light. I also understand why Chicago locals vote Lou Malnati's as the best deep dish pizza in the city, because frankly, I can't imagine it getting much better than this.

I've never had deep dish pizza, so consider me extremely biased. Honestly, I'm not the biggest fan of pizza in general,but this was so delicious! If it's just you, get the individual- the small is a lot for just one person!
Outstanding pizza and service. Pizza was hot and delicious! Best deep dish in Chicago! Highly recommend

Yum! The Malnati's pizza with the sausage patty and butter crust is a tasty pizza. Wasn't as impressed with the plain old pepperoni pizza. Fried cheese cubes are amazing. Try to eat them while they're warm.

This was my first Chicago style deep dish pizza experience and it wasn't great. We waited over half an hour for a table and then a further 35 minutes for a warm, not hot at all, pizza to arrive. We orderd a salad too and had to ask them for it again as they clearly forgot. I had a dirty knife too. I think I'm just being fussy. The 'pie' was nice. I don't think it's for me - I prefer NYC style, but it was nice. The BBQ salad was really nice.
If you want to try Chicago deep dish pizza, then this is the place to go! Service was friendly and fast.

Try to avoid visits during peak hours. The place is packed and there is a decrease in quality. Pizza was good, but cold. We did not want to wait further for someone to reheat the pizza. Dessert took 20 minutes to serve.

I was in the mood for some authentic Chicago deep dish pizza and I found this place. Overall a good experience although I personally found the pizza lacking in flavor. It was freshly made and took 30 min to make (which is typical for a real deep dish). But it tasted like bland cheese, tomatoes and sausage. I just though a little salt n pepper or other seasonings were absent. The atmosphere was nice but I doubt I'll go back. If you wait 30 min for pizza it better be the best pizza you've ever had.

After having the other two well known deep dish establishments, ventured here for some comparison tasting. I'll say Lou's is neck and neck for first place in my book. Ordered a small 1/2 and 1/2 deep dish, as recommended by our waitress so we could sample, and also a personal to taste another. This was plenty of food for two people. Also had an order of wings, buffalo style, and was very happy with the flavor and wing size (heavy on the drumsticks).  Heads up they don't take reservations and are very busy. As a table of two we got lucky and were sat instantly (last table). You can order why you wait, which would be wise considering the deep dish takes 45 minutes.  Highly recommend to check out Lou's if you are in the area.

We were seated IMMEDIATELY. Our server greeted us promptly and brought out drinks quickly. The appetizer (delicious bruschetta) took about 8 minutes, and the pizza (Lou Malnatti's Classic, also delicious) took about 35 minutes, but our server let us know how long it would take in advance and checked on us regularly. The music was lively but not too loud, and the ambience is bright, warm, clean and very relaxing.
