Fantastic pizza choices, terrible size choices. We severely underestimated the size of these things. They were so thick that we barely finished half of each one. The pizza was out of this world though- buttery thick deliciousness- full flavored sausage and the sauce was to die for.  We had so much left over and it was our last meal here, we decided to box up the rest, stuff it in our backpacks, somehow make it through airport security, and smuggle authentic Chicago deep dish pizza to Dallas. We shared it with our family and friends back home and they were in love with the taste as well. Overall great pizza, fantastic wings, and a phenomenal atmosphere with excellent service. Be prepared to wait like 30-45 for your pizza to get ready, but man when it gets there- totally worth it. If that feels like a long wait, I would highly encourage you to order the wings.

I want to make 3 points and 3 points only. 1. The Buffa-Lou wings. UNREAL. So good. They should call this place Lou Malnati's Chicken Wingeria. 2. That Malnati salad. ARE YOU FREAKING KIDDING ME?! So effing good. 4 of us scraped that family size portion and practically licked the bowl clean. 3. We "pre-ordered" our pizza which we were told was going to take 45 mintues to prepare. We waited nearly an hour to be seated. We then wait probably another hour for this pizza. Said pizza was not anywhere on the realm of deliciousness as the wings and salad.  What's wrong with this picture?! I just don't get it.

Great atmosphere, great beers on tap and in the bottle and an awesome introduction to Chicago style pizza. Only mistake I made was issuing a personal size which is not served in the skillet. Order the small size if you are looking for a small portion. Even if you don't finish, it's worth having it served in the skillet.  I ordered the Chicago Classic which has sausage and tomatoes pilled on top of a deep dish crust. Sitting at their bar watching the Blackhawks, drinking a local IPA and grubbing on great pizza made me want to live in Chicago.
As a NYer trying 'Chicago Pizza' for the first time I was skeptical...but this deep dish pizza is the best I've ever had.  The Buttercrisp crust is everything.

Visiting from MN!  We were recommended to go here by many people.  It was a short walk from our hotel.  We ordered a small "The Malnati Chicago Classic".  It was plenty for my wife and I. The crust was definitely the best part of the pizza.  I've definitely had better pizza before, but overall it was a good pizza and we had great time.  It was very reasonably priced.

This was such a disappointing experience. A trip to chicago requires deep dish pizza. All that ooey-gooey cheesy goodness!  It's the stuff dreams are made of! Amiright!?  When your salivating pizza desires are crushed with mediocre pizza, it can nearly send you into a depressing downward spiral. That might be a bit dramatic, but only slightly.  Let's start with the crust. I feel like Chicago pizza crust has hopes and dreams of stardom, but our crust somehow settled for middle management in a polo shirt.  Our pizza lacked saucy goodness that demands you eat it with a fork and knife. If asked I'll deny this, but I actually picked it up in my hand and ate it like a regular piece of pizza. Gasp!!!  This is merely speculation, but I am pretty sure our pizza was frozen. We ordered a sausage, pepperoni, onion, and green pepper pie. Our server said it would take extra time to cook with the extras on it. We didn't care. (We're wild and crazy) When our pizza arrived the pepperoni, onion, and peppers were cooked on top and the sausage inside. The sausage itself was one thin patty and the diameter of the pizza. It was weird, to say the least.  Such a let down. If you are looking for good pizza, you can do so much better. Skip the touristy chains and go for the real deal!!!

Lou personal and Malnati personal, ordered!  I thought that the Malnati was better with the sausages.  The Lou with the spinach and mushrooms, made it relatively moist for the pie deep dish.  It watered down the tomato sauce of the pizza. I do like their buttery, thin and flaky crust! Service was top notch.  Our server came around plenty of times to see if everything was okay.

Sat at the bar and had a personal size Lou's Classic and a Goose Island Green Line. The pizza itself was good, but by the time it had arrived, the cheese had already started to settle and it wasn't as ooey gooey as I would've liked. It was also a tad small, but the next size up would've been too much. Great bartender!

I actually ordered a pizza a few months ago and had it delivered to my house in California. Needless to say, it wasn't the best pizza I've ever had.  I decided I need to try it out from the source, the place was slammed on a Friday night but we got seated in about 20 minutes.  We ordered the original (sausage deepdish)  The pizza was AMAZING, the sauce was perfect, the cheese was plentiful and the sausage was super flavorful. If you are in Chicago, this place is a no-brainer

Went here this past October to carb up before my marathon. Lou's came highly recommended from my airbnb host. When you first get here it looks like a mess. People just standing around everywhere blocking the entry way. Here's what you need to do. Locate the hostess to the left of the counter in front of you. Put your name down and the number of your party.  Next, stand in line to place your order with the cashiers (soft drinks, water & second round of beers will be ordered from your table server). They encourage you to do this since they are very busy and by time (20mins or so) your table is ready, so will your food. As you are waiting, order a beer, they will also provide you with a fresh baked thin crust pizza as free apps. Probably to suppress the appetites of a happy mob before they morph into an angry one :) The large pizzas are big. For a party of 4 I would recommend 3 pizzas. That's more than enough to feed the table. The Malnati Classic pizza had great sausage, but the tasted was a bit smothered by the mass amounts of cheese. Nonetheless, Lou's is a must try if you're visiting Chicago.

hm. chicago deep dish was not what i expected. i thought it would be sorta like "mountain pie" from beau jo's in colorado, but the crust was thin and it was wayyy more cheese than anything else... like an overwhelming, nauseating amount. can't complain about the value though because their pizzas are pretty cheap, but i much prefer ny style (grimaldi's ftw)!

We visited this location on a recent trip to Chicago.  When we walked in we were seated immediately.  Within 15 minutes of our arrival the wait for a table was 1 hour.  I would say that the hostess is without much personality and really didn't care whether people had to wait an hour or more.  BUT our server, ANNA, from Moldava, WAS INCREDIBLE.  She greeted us with a smile that never left her face the entire time she was working.  She was hustling the entire time we were there.  We ordered a salad and their signature pizza.  The pizza was perfect.  We bought a bottle of the salad dressing which was a "sweet vinaigrette" and just wonderful.  I have to say that I would go back over and over again.

First time in Chicago, heard about their reputation, tried out their veggie deep dish, they had a solid 1.5 hour wait on Friday night, and took another 20-30 mins to get the pizza  -- and it was delicious! Juice, cheesy, flavorful deep dish. The cheese and sauce both tasted very good. I ordered small but it was more than enough for 2-3 meals because their pizza is dense and heavy -- great value for money in my opinion.  Will definitely go back next time I'm in Chicago!

Visiting Chicago for the first time, I would be crazy if I didn't try the famous deep dish pizza. Three of us ordered a large house salad to share (a comically large portion size) and a deep dish sausage special. The salad wasn't anything special, although there was enough to feed about 15 people, but the pizza was everything I thought it would be. Very greasy, dense, and impossible to eat with your hands. My only complaint is that the pizza becomes less appetizing once it cools down, so hurry up and eat it as quickly as you can!

Was in Chicago for the first time and need to try some authentic deep dish pizza. This place was exactly what we wanted. They allow you to preorder while you wait for your table. Service was great, pizza was amazing, price was even better.
First visit to Lou Malnati's, but I'll definitely be back the next time I am in Chicago. Excellent deep dish pizza. Good service. Draft beer selection was just OK.

Yup, I think this is my favorite Chicago pizza spot.  Came here for lunch and they have a great deal, personal pizza with a salad, can be in and out of there in less than thirty minutes if you want for under $10.  And yes, you leave full with that $10 meal....which makes me think about how unhealthy that pizza is, but that's a different conversation...ha.
Had to think of John Stewart the whole time I was eating my deep dish pizza.

Our lackluster experience with Lou Malnati's started the second we put our name with the hostess.  She was not friendly when we put our name in and did not want to answer any of the questions we had.   We were told we would have about a 45 minute wait and would get a text when our table was ready.  We went to Bull and Bear next door for a drink and about 25 minutes later we got a text that our table was ready at Lou's.   When we checked in with the hostess, she told us to sit on the bench behind the hostess area.  We waited about another 15 minutes (figuring this was part of the 45 minute wait).  When my husband asked the hostess how much longer - she said were were supposed to "tell the lady" we were here for our table.  We had no idea what lady she was talking about and finally someone else helped us and got us a table.  After being seated, we ordered drinks and waited for our pizza that we had per-ordered.  When we got our pizza everything from the crust to the sausage on top was flavorless.  We had heard such good things about deep dish pizza and Chicago but this pie did not hold up to the hype.

Horrible! I was expecting greater things from 'Chicago's best pizza', and my god! Did it disappoint! I took my out-of-town friend here to show him what the big fuss about Lou Malnati's was. First we got an appetizer of Garlic bread. I would expect some fantastic dish from this place, but what comes out? COLD pieces of Garlic bread which tastes exactly like it came from the frozen section in any supermarket. When we complained that it was so cold, the server doesn't even ask if we would like to replace it. All she says is 'I can toss it into the oven and reheat it for you". I was like 'Whhhaattt?' Which restaurant does that?And doesn't she know that bread loses it's moisture and gets more crisp if re-baked! Frustrating!. We then got a veggie deep dish pizza with mushrooms, onion, olives and spinach. The pizza takes over 40 minutes to come and when it does, it's like this big goo of marinara sauce over a buttery crust. The crust had no salt, the sauce was like fresh tomatoes with no seasoning and we couldn't even taste any of the vegetables. I will definitely not be there again. I rather have amazing pizza for half the price and various other local pizzerias in town.

The pizza was a perfectly crafted. Golden buttery crust was tasty but made the pie greasy. The meat and sauce were bland but tasty. It was a very good deep dish but the 35 minute wait in an empty restaurant was not good. The service was also a bit plain as well. Come if you have time
Being from SF I've never had authentic Chicago style pizza...this was the best pizza I've ever had!! Definitely beats Patxis.
Not a pizza expert but this place is pretty good.

I was in Chicago for the weekend, and my girlfriend and I decided that we since we both loved pizza is would be a crime to not get some Chicago style pizza while we were in town.  The restaurant itself is very nice.  The décor is fairly modern, though sparsely decorated.  We were seated quickly though we did have to wait several minutes for our waiter to get to us.  He did a drive by, and said he would be with us soon during our wait though.  They were busy at the time, so it wasn't a big deal.   Upon arriving at our table he gave us a quick rundown, and informed us that *****all of the pizzas take around 45 minutes to cook*****.   I don't think that's a problem, but it is certainly something you want to take into consideration.  We heard other servers ask if their patrons had called ahead, so this is probably a regular practice to avoid the extended cooking time.  We ordered a Malnati Salad, Three-Cheese Bread, and The Malnati Chicago Classic. After about 20 minutes we got the cheese bread, and the salad.  I am not a salad person, so I can't really comment on the taste, but I did have a bite.  the salami bits are very crunchy, and add a flavor I didn't enjoy.  I would have enjoyed the salad without that addition.  The cheese bread is very good.  There is a good blend of cheese, with a decent flavor of garlic.  The edges of the loaf were fairly crispy with the portion under the cheese being relatively chewy but not undercooked. True to their word around 45 minutes after our order was placed our pizza arrived.  I have to say after eating this pizza I would not recommend it to anyone.  The pizza is made in layers.  Starting from the crust, followed by cheese, then a layer of sausage (I'll get to that in a minute) and then the sauce.  The crust is extremely delicious, and they use a high quality cheese.  The sausage on the other hand was pretty much like a gigantic sausage patty that covered the entire pizza.  It was fairly tough to cut through, though it wasn't overly chewy.  All in all it detracted more from the pizza than it added.  Luckily because it was a continuous piece of meat it was extremely easy to slide it off the pizza.  The only drawback was that because the sauce was on top of the sausage I had to scrape it off and add it back to the pizza.  Once I performed this minor surgery it was probably one of the best pizzas I had ever eaten.   I would probably recommend Lou Malnati's to a friend, but I would certainly not suggest the sausage patty pizza.
Staff is very friendly! Came in for lunch and ordered the deep dish cheese and pepperoni. Great, fresh pizza! Highly recommend! Also try the cookie desert :)

Omg no.  Maybe I'm just not a big fan of deep dish pizza but I don't understand the appeal here at all.  I was visiting Chicago for the first time and was urged by numerous acquaintances (I am reluctant to call them friends now) to visit this place for deep dish pizza.  We came here on a Sunday afternoon, and had no wait.  Ordered the Malnati Salad to start, and that was fine.  No qualms there - it was your standard chain restaurant salad. Then the pizza came.  We ordered the Malnati Chicago Classic, which came at the recommendation of our server.  It was essentially pizza crust, topped with a THICK layer of cheese, thin layer of tomato sauce, then a layer of meat.  The pizza was so dry and hardened quickly as it cooled (especially the cheese), making it difficult to cut into a mere 3 minutes after it arrived.  It was so bland too, all I tasted was the calories.  I was brought up to not waste food but after one slice I couldn't bring myself to finish another.  Service was fine and our waitress was actually quite sweet.  Half star for the salad, and another half star for her.  I hope maybe we just had a bum pie, but going forwards, I will be sticking to my New York or Italian style pizza.

Really hit the spot. Got a wheat beer on tap and some appetizers to share with friends. Creative twists and good presentation. Had "the Lou" and likely will order it again next time I visit. Really enjoyed the food. Loud jovial atmosphere.

Had to try Chicago deep dish again. The hostess was friendly. I sat at the bar, which was great. It was a busy night, and the place was hoping with energy around different sporting events. I liked watching the bartender serve the pizzas in worn, hot skillets with tongs and a serving spatula. The bartender was very friendly and charming. I ordered the 9" pizza because I'm a hungry girl. The single probably would have been sufficient. They pride themselves on Wisconsin mozzarella and California tomatoes for the sauce. There was a nice sweetness to both, and the crust was crisp on the bottom yet doughy. I thought the crust could have been more buttery and lacked salt. They put the cheese on top of the crust, what we call an "upside down slice" in New York. That is followed by lean sausage, and then tomato sauce on top. It was tasty. I tried two craft beers: a bitter, yet sweet Anti-Hero Revolution IPA and the easily drinkable Goose Island Greenline Pale Ale.
We had the signature deep dish pizza and bruschetta.   Pizza was perfect with nice tomato flavors and great sausage and crust.  Only improvement I would look for is more garlic and oil on bruschetta.

Excellent deep dish pizza.  Recommend the spinach stuffed bread for an appetizer.  Pizza takes a bit to make but it's only to be expected from the size.  Their portion recommendations are definitely good - a small easily fed two people.

Grew up on Pizzeria Uno via Philly; however, always wanted to go to Chicago and sample the best there is. Lou's is definitely it! Waited 30 minutes on a Fri night at 6pm, then waited another 30 mins once I ordered. Well worth the wait!! Their deep dish pizza with sausage and the butter crust is the absolute bomb!!! Can't wait to return!!!

Wow blown away at how good the pizza is crust is awesome as well.. I order at least two a week consistent excellent yes. My favorite duo dont deliver giordianos is good too, falcos and homerun are good.

#HadToDoIt while on a trip to Chicago. I mean, what kind of self respecting person would I be if I didn't try the famous deep dish Pizza in Chicago? As luck would have it, we stopped by this location shortly after it opened for business and were seated immediately. Upon realizing that it would take 30 minutes for deep dish to cook, we also ordered their Bruschetta to tide over our hunger whilst waiting.  During the wait the place got PACKED! The bruschetta was delicious and were quite HUGE for an appetizer. There were 8 pieces and you could count that as an appetizer for a group of 4. Well, we ate the whole damn platter.  Alas "The Malnati Chicago Classic" came out with its famous buttercrust. Yes, BUTTERCRUST. Definitely worth the calories! The sausage was flavorful as well as the sauce. I couldn't finish my share of the pizza but of course had to eat all the crust :) Definitely worth a try. I have to say I'm thankful I don't live in Chicago so I don't have to be tempted to eat deep dish all the time.

Simple and delicious. Had the sausage special pizza and a side salad with gorgonzola dressing. Service was good and the place had an authenticity. This is what I imagined Chicago deep dish to be. Plus it was full of locals - always a good sign!

This was the first place Boyfriend and I ate at after landing in Chicago and checking into our hotel. We wanted to get a classic, Chicago-style deep-dish pizza. And we'd heard great things about this chain, so we figured why not! Very decent for the price, and we loved that we could leave our name AND our order and explore the surrounding area because they would call us once a table was open! And since we placed our order ahead of time, it was ready about 10 minutes after we sat down. Very spiffy, especially since we showed up on the later end of peak dinner hours. In all honesty, I thought that Zachary's out here in Rockridge tasted better, but if you've never had any sort of deep dish before, this is a great place to get introduced. We ordered the Malnati's Chicago Classic -- a tad on the greasy and cheesy side, but still delicious and absolutely filling. Our waiter gave us some crap for being "techies" when we told him we were from San Francisco, but we get that stereotype a lot (even though we're not) so we just laughed and shrugged it off. It's a pretty neat spot and a Chicago staple (depending on who you talk to, I suppose), so I personally thought it was worth the wait to experience!

Lou's is the best deep dish. The fact that this is a family restaurant makes it even more enjoyable. The staff is always friendly and carry out is always run very smoothly. I also enjoy their thin crust but you cannot beat their sweet onion dressing. It is the best!!

Great deep dish? Check.  Does it stack up against the main location? Def not.  It's a cozy little spot and the pizza is good. If you are visiting Chicago, this is not the location I would go to. This is more where you go in a situation where you are too lazy to go closer to Millenium Mile and experience the real thing.
I ordered the Malnatti's Classic and loved it!   I am a NYC native and resident.  But love Malnatti's deep dish better than NYC style pizza.  I love the buttercrust.
Great experience eating pizza in Chicago. Walking distance from Michigan Avenue. Arrive early, as this place fills up fast.
The ONLY place to order pizza. The thin crust pizza is as good as it gets!
the BEST BEST BEST pizza in Chicago, hands down!  Went twice on our last weekend to Chicago.  May even try having it shipped to me to see how that compares....

What can I say about Lou Malnati's that hasn't been said before?  The pizza was good.  It was the first thing I ate after I landed in Chicago.  We barely beat the lunch rush as we arrived right at noon on a Friday.  We were seated immediately and the service was really nice.  Our waitress was attentive.  Food was okay.  I couldn't really finish my pizza and I ALWAYS finish my pizza.  Something was just lacking in flavor, I can't really put my finger on it.  There was also a LOT of cheese.  Like, too much cheese.  How do you mess that up?  How do you have too much cheese? How do you have so much cheese that someone ends up complaining about it?  That's when you know you have too much cheese. Also, this is kind of random, but I noticed that the restaurant was just really dusty.  I was admiring some of the pictures and other knick knacks on the walls... only to notice a good layer of dust and cobwebs.  Kind of disgusting as they're hanging directly over our tables of food. There are a lot of deep dish pizza options in Chicago.  If you miss out on Lou Malnati's, don't beat yourself up over it.  I'm sure you'll find another great place.
Of the chain deep-dish options in Chicago, I favor Lou Malnati's.   It was a perfect spot to add on calories lost during the Chicago Marathon.

I was in town for one night running the marathon and before I left town had to have the best Chicago pizza.  Thanks to Yelp and other research sites I settled on Malnati's but it was close as all the pizza options are highly reviewed. I walked into Malnati's after the marathon and found a seat at the Bar and Lamar helped me choose the best pizza on the menu.  Since it was just me I wasn't sure if the personal size pizza would do deep dish justice and Lamar guided me to go with a small size to get a true feeling for the pie, plus I could have left overs and make all the passengers on my flight jealous. I went for the Chicago Classic with sausage pieces instead of the whole patty.  Lamar was very engaging at the bar while I waited for my pizza.  I learned that at Malnati's there is a 1 to 3 hour wait every day Monday through Sunday.  I had arrived around 12:30 and the place was about quarter full but 30 minutes later the place was packed and the bar was hopping with marathoners and spectators.  I think if a place has a 1 to 3 hour wait every day it tells you a lot. The pizza arrived and finally I had my chance to have my first Chicago deep dish pizza.  Did i make the right choice?  Would it hit the spot and drive me crazy to want to come back to Chicago for the pizza alone. It was spectacular.  The tomatoes are the hero of this pie, not to say that all the other parts aren't pure perfection because they are.  The tomatoes taste like they were fresh picked, so pungent, such bright flavor, really, really special.  The cheese was creamy with just the right amount in each bite.  The sausage was soft but firm and flavorful but not overpowering.  And the crust was fantastic.  Crispy at the bottom and doughy and crunchy around the edge.   This pizza reaches a perfect balance that's hard to match.  All components work together to create a masterpiece, using each of their unique food assets to create a sum that far exceeds the amazingness of the parts.  You can taste how they've been doing this right for a long, long time and why it will always work. So if you are visiting Chicago and have one shot at the finest Chicago pizza, you got to go to Lou's. Thanks for the great service Lamar!  Your stories of snowmobiling up in Minnesota sound amazing and hope to get there someday.

After trying deep dish pizza from numerous restaurants in Chicago and even in SoCal, the best is still Lou Malnati's Pizzeria. I had been to this location back in 2012 and loved the bustling atmosphere. We started with the Calamari Fritti. The batter was a little heavy (would be great on fried chicken), but crispy. The calamari was cooked perfectly and not rubbery. The marinara sauce added a sweet, tanginess to balance with the salty, spicy batter. We ordered a Pepperoni Deep Dish Pizza with olives and butter crust. The crust was crispy and buttery. The pizza was full of gooey mozzarella cheese. The sauce was mild, but brought all of the ingredients together. The pepperoni and olive combination is onolicious! Their pepperoni is more like salami versus the pepperoni that you would traditionally get on a regular pizza. The taste hasn't change since my first Lou Malnati's Deep Dish Pizza in 2007. You can taste every ingredient. It's truly amazing! We ended our meal with the Tiramisu. It had great espresso flavor. The mascarpone was creamy and light. I loved the touch of chocolate sauce and chocolate chips!

This is pretty good pizza, I had the all veggie deep dish pizza. I think my expectations might have been a little too high. But their chicken wings were surprisingly good, they had some of the best buffalo sauce I have ever tasted. Plenty of seating, not an issue getting a table.

We came during the heart of lunch hour (12:15PM arrival). Even though we called 10 min earlier to tell them we were coming and they said they had no wait and room available, they needed some time to "find a place to seat" us. Summary: Pros:  Bar-B-Lou wings House salad Cons: Too much cheese, no marinara sauce pizza Party of 5 seated at table for 4 Appetizers: Large house salad and Bar-B-Lou wings. This was the highlight of our meal. Wings were flavorful and good portion to share in our party of 5. The large house salad was good starter and very generous portion. Pizza: I don't recall the name but we had the deep dish pizza with pepperoni, sausage, and mushrooms. The pizza's layer of cheese was so thick that some of our toppings were drowned/buried in it. In addition, the pizza had almost no marinara sauce and was too dry. I literally was drinking an entire glass of soda with each slice. When we requested extra sauce, it was served to us in a half empty container and we were charged $1 without being informed of such. Service: I can't ding them for this. It's Chicago and the lunch time rush. He did his best to keep serving us but the operation as a whole dedicated a little more attention to the local employees trying to make it back from lunch within the hour.

Deep dish pizza.. Obviously a must in Chicago. We got the small sausage pizza. Good enough for 2 people especially since there's a thick layer of cheese.  The bread was nice, crunchy and yummy.. The sauce.. Yummy!  I really liked how every bite had an even layer of sausage.

Good food for a great price! I wanted to know what all the hype over deep dish pizza was about and this place proved it. Sure, it took longer than an average pizza but well worth the wait! We got 2 personal sized pizzas (one Lou, which is the vegetable one, and the Malnatis Chicago Classic, which featured sausage) and both were perfect. Very simple stuff, but simply delicious and filling. Beer was good too! They have local craft beer specials!

This place was recommended as one of the best pizza places in Chicago. Location was a little hard to find, but may have been due to construction in the area. It had a chain type of vibe to it. My friend ordered a regular pizza and wasn't too impressed. I ordered a gluten free pizza. It was pretty sandy tasting. Not the greatest GF pizza I've had, but I appreciated that they at least carried the option. Small bathroom, had to wait in line forever. Bartender was nice and friendly.

Had this last month when i visited Chicago and I absolutely loved it.  The small sized one was enough for the two of us but i also had the cookie they bake in the deep dish pan and it was amazing.  I will be going here again the next time I'm in town.
The bottom crust was so thick - I now know why they call them pizza PIES. Difficult to enjoy a slice of pizza when all you can think about is how much it's like a pie...

The servers seemed overwhelmed here, but they were very hospitable and friendly. They kept on apologizing for the wait, and they recommended dishes for us. We came here on a Sunday right before kickoff of the Bears/Packers game, so we came at the perfect time. Things got packed soon after we were quickly seated.  Lou Malnati's is a brand that you always hear about when you hear of Chicago pizza. They were on Pizza Wars, Throwdown with Bobby Flay, etc.... They do offer a thin crust, but you're in Chicago; how dare you order a non-traditional Chicago deep dish pizza? We ordered a small Malnati Chicago Classic. Made with Lou's lean sausage, some extra cheese and vine-ripened tomato sauce on Buttercrust.™ It's authentic Chicago! It perfectly serves 2 ppl as it is is a small pan pizza with 4 slices. The cooking time is approximately 30-45 minutes, so as we waited we shared a small order of the Malnati Salad. The Malnati salad was slightly overdressed. It was a tad on the salty side but that's probably due to the cheese. This can feed 3-4 ppl i think (not just 2). We def ate our share of salad and couldn't even finish the bowl as we had to save our stomachs for the star of the show. The pizza finally arrived, and the waiter served us each a slice. The pizza was piping hot. You can see the crust was golden and buttery and glistening underneath the lights. The tomato sauce was sweet with the cheese salty. The sausage was plentiful. The pizza is a stick to the ribs dish, and it is hearty. You can't eat it with your hands or fold it in half like a New York slice. You need to use a fork and knife -___-. Aghast! a fork and knife...but i guess when in rome, do what the romans do. The pizza was yummy. Usually i'm not a fan of deep dish pizza because it is too heavy and crusty, but this was yummy.
Our first meal in Chicago and it was a great introduction.  Busy, bustling atmosphere even on a Sunday night, friendly helpful bar and wait staff and best of all - excellent deep dish pizza.
Most deep dish pizza any where 40min to cook. Salad good Pizza good. EH!!! A bit bland for me

I haven't even eaten here yet. I just got seated but my pizza is already coming since I ordered when I checked in with the hostess. Crazy popular and busy place but they manage it outstanding!!!  Best pre service operation I have ever been to. I'm pretty positive the pizza will be good to. Kudos to the hostess and the bar tender who kept me happy while I waited for a table!

The Lou's keep us waiting for more than one hour and they gave us one dish that started to get cold...But the taste is really nice in a Pizza's standard. Okay I've checked this on my Chicago Visiting List and I might not go there in one month...

I'm in Chicago on a business trip and sick of hotel food. My group and I decided to head into the city for some traditional deep dish pizza. We got a recommendation to visit Lous and boy am I glad we did. The food was amazing and plentiful and the service was... Blehhh:p just kidding. Jason was bustin our chops all night long but we loved it.

I live in Oak Park and this Lou's is sooooooo much better than the Oak Park Lou's. The pizza tastes better and this location doesn't skimp on the toppings. Justin was our bartender and he was great. Perfect combination of not too chatty and attentive. I will continue to drive to the city to eat here vs. the one in Oak Park.

My past experience with deep dish pizza has been a ton of crust topped with a little meat and cheese.  Lou Malnati's squashed that notion.  I ordered the classic pizza with light sauce.  The crust was thin and crispy topped with a thick layer of cheese (1/4 to 1/2 inch), a solid layer of sausage, and great tasting sauce.  Only downside was the hour and 15 minute wait.

Even if you don't like deep dish - try it here!  Being from the East Coast, I didn't have much to compare deep dish pizza too, but I can tell you that THIS pizza was nothing like deep dish that I've ever had.  I thought the pizza would be all crust and it was the farthest from that. The crust was crispy, the sauce was perfect and not too sweet, and there was the perfect amount of cheese.  If you're in Chicago, you've GOT to try the pizza at Malnati's. They will ship their pizza as well, so we have great Christmas gifts for this year!

You cannot go wrong with this deep dish pizza. My opinion of what makes this so good, is that they are not trying to get all 5 star chef on you and add all kinds of ingredients, but they stick to the basics. Firstly, the crust is so wonderful, that if you are a bread person, you can just eat on that by itself.  The cheese is and sauce are so simple, and that is what to me, wakes your mouth up and you begin to wonder, how did you go your whole life not eating this. There is always a wait, but that is to be expected. I personally think it is worth the wait. When we use to drive there after a 9 hour drive, we were always willing to wait, even after we were already tired.  In all of my 12 years of visiting this place, it never disappoints. You can't hold it against them for the wait time, and customer service wise, all I expect is the basics of taking my order and filling my drink at my clean table.

My boyfriend and I came to Chicago and knew we couldn't leave without eating Chicago's deep dish pizza, so we decided to try this place because it got good reviews. I probably would have given this place a 4-star rating, but there was just one thing that held me back! And that was how much cheese was on the original Malnati Chicago Classic pizza. The cheese on the pizza was so overwhelming. If the pizza had just the normal amount of cheese, it would be amazing! Other than that, this place is great. The wait wasn't too long. We got a seat at the bar and started appetizers there. A short time later, we were called and got seated. You can preorder your food before you sit, so you don't have to wait double the amount of time for your food. Overall, I would most likely come back and try a different pizza, but would recommend it to anyone who comes to Chicago.

The reason why I'm giving it a 3 is because the instant we got there our hostess was texting on her phone and was extremely rude to us.  Once we actually sat down our waitress was fantastic we had to Malnati's salad. Which was a huge serving and could feed more than 3 people. The wait for our pizza was a bit long but it was so worth the wait!

Visited Chicago for a week and decided to try as many deep dishes as possible.  Without naming our other choice destinations, Lou was the best in our opinion.  The crust was just somehow different and stayed crunchy despite the heavy toppings.  The flavor was also better.  Yes, the wait was long but can't rush deep dish.  Did I mention place was packed at 2:30pm?
The best deep dish. A plate of sausage on the pie is something you need to experience. Be prepared to wait or get it to go!

The pizza was absolutely amazing!  Got the deep dish classic with sausage.  The butter crust could not have been cooked more perfect.  Crispy, buttery goodness.  The toppings were good. Every bite had sausage in it.  The tomato sauce on top seemed fresh made.  It was great.  The only thing that could've been better would be more cheese and thicker toppings. It was definitely tastebud blowing goodness though.  Absolutely must try this pizza. As for the restaurant itself, it was very small and overly crowded. Not enough seating. Had an hour wait so we just ordered for pick up instead. They said an hour. Pizza wasn't ready. They said hold on, let me see where it's at and then never came back to tell me. It was fifteen more minutes then they brought our pizza. It was totally worth the wait though.

Amazing pizza! I had tried deep dish before and didn't particularly like it, but loved it at Lou's. Will def come back. Only reason I don't give it 5 stars is it took almost an hour to get our food, which I thought was a bit excessive.

What can I say! The deep dish here is way better than New York style pizza. The location was very convenient, only a couple of blocks away from the hotel I was staying at. Upon arrival, there were plenty of tourists doing the same thing we were doing which was waiting patiently  to try the deep dish pizza Since it was dinner time, there was a wait time of 45 minutes but our waiter advised us to order before getting our table because the pizza would take thirty minutes to bake. Def a heads up in my book. Though the wait was not to shabby my group of three was seated within 15 minutes of wait time. We ordered the infamous stuffed spinach bread  and a medium deep dish. The stuffed spinach bread was baked golden to perfection with ooey goey mozzarella in every bite. As for the deep dish, words can't describe how amazing it tasted. The crust was crunchy but not to hard to bite into, everything else in the inside was soft and marinated perfectly. Even though i was a bit full from lunch, I wanted to have seconds.  Overall, the service, atmosphere and food was up there , so def a 5 in my book.

Definitely a great spot for some Chicago deep dish pizza! The cheese just melts in your mouth. And the crust that they're famous for was mouth-watering. We also got their buffalo wings--they weren't the best I've ever had, but they were still really good. We ordered ahead for carry-out, knowing the wait would be about 45 minutes. I guess that's the standard for pizza around here? When we got there to pick up the pizza and wings, it was packed! Even though out pizza was already ready, we still had to wait a bit because of all the customers that were in line and waiting. Overall, I had a good experience with their pizza. I'm glad we didn't have to wait there because that was a serious crowd! But I see why this place is so popular and why it was recommended to us.

Best deep dish pizza in the city, definitely worth the wait. Crust is the right thickness. No need to get appetizers as the pizza is substantial enough. Be ready for a food coma so wouldn't recommend if you want to go out afterwards. This restaurant is a Chicago classic.

The place was packed. My husband and I got at the restaurant at about 6 on a Friday and they said an hour and fifteen minute wait. We were luck to score two seats at the bar and decided to eat there.  The service was fantastic. The bartenders were attentive and friendly. Our food arrived and we got the speciality salad and shared their speciality pizza. The food was delicious. Why the bad review? After my fourth bite of pizza a bug started crawling over everything on our side of the bar, including my phone and plate. It looked like a smaller cockroach-not sure exactly what it was... I instantly lost my appetite. Will not return. Will not recommend...especially with like 30 people always constantly in the entrance area does not make for a great atmosphere. It did not stop my husband from eating his meal, but I couldn't touch another bite...all I kept thinking was what crawls all over the plate and cook prep areas at night?!? So grossed out!!!

I can see why we had to wait almost 1 1/2 hours to be seated. Thankfully, you can place your order when you enter your name into the system. They take your cell phone and text you when your table is available. The only downside was that it was still going to take a half hour to get the pizza. So we ordered the caprese salad. Very yummy and it hit the spot. The pizza was delicious.

SO GOOD! The spinach, the Lou's original, the meat lover. I am a fan all around and there national delivery has become our go to gift. Love this place and have to say, I am now a huge fan of Chi town deep dish.

After a long day of walking and shopping, we stopped by Lou Malnati's for a deep dish pizza. I ordered a custom one with the Butter Crust deep dish. Be patient because it does take time to make the pizza, I enjoyed people watching as I waited. The pizza came out and it was delicious! I really liked the butter crust, you have to get that! It was a very enjoyable dinner with great service and a nice patio to sit and watch Chicago go by!

First time to Chicago and had to have Chicago style pizza. Tried the other place, but loved Lou malnati's pizza. Crust is so flaky and sausage pieces in every bite. You need a fork and knife! One slice was plenty. Be ready to wait, lines are long and baking time is about 35 minutes

We were served lukewarm pizza (cheese deep dish) after a 45min wait.  The people around us got steaming hot pizza - we were just unlucky.  The waiter offered to reheat the pizza, but I just felt they tried to serve someone else's old pizza. We returned the pizza and had the item removed from our bill. We had buffalo wings and mozzarella sticks as appetizers, and they were ok.

Fabulous dinner!!  Highly recommend!!! Our Bartender/Server, David was superb!! He recommended the perfect first try Chicago piazza and toppings. Deep dish Chicago w/Carbanero(?) The wine (Cab)  was great and beer recommendations were perfect to go with the pizza!!:-) Our BEST dinner so far on our trip to Chicago!!! We had a 30 min wait for seating but "swooped" onto two seats at the bar!!! Score:-)
Best deep dish pizza must to have butter crust, HANDS DOWN. Also have decent wings and usual beer collection.

I waited 45 minutes for this "best deep dish in Chicago" pizza, and was very disappointed. We got "The Lou" Deep dish. The crust had no flavor and neither did the tomatoes. And the was so little spinach I forgot that it came on the pizza. There was a lot of cheese on the pizza, but that was also flavorless.  We sat at the bar, the bartender was nice enough, but they were all out of their tap beers except Miller Lite, at 8pm on a Wednesday! Hopefully I can find better Chicago pizza to brag about back home.

I'll try to be as partial as possible, coming from the New Haven area and being very familiar with NYC pizza.  I can appreciate deep dish, and I would say this is the best I've had. That said (bring on the hate messages) I would have a tough time discerning much of a difference between this pizza and my local Pizzeria Uno chain. The bottom was a bit less soggy, and the crust was a bit flakier, but that's it. It was not a drastic difference to either of our tastes.  Service was fine, but we were a little letdown by the feel of this place. Didn't have that established, old school pizza place feel - felt more like a newer chain. The pizza wasn't an event, so I guess we should have gone somewhere with more history. Beer selection was underwhelming, but that's expected.  The order also took a very, very long time (almost a full hour) and it was far from busy.  So, I'm not sure I'm my underwhelmed reaction is because it pales in comparison to NYC/New Haven pizza, or maybe I'm just underwhelmed by the concept of deep dish in general.
Very kid friendly. Food was great and server was very understanding. She must have kids

My first order of business when landing in Chicago was to eat a Deep Dish Pizza.  I was given the tough decision of choosing which place to try a deep dish in a city where everything is the "Best Deep Dish in Chicago!" and decided on Lou Malnati's based off of the overwhelming amount of positive reviews. I was not disappointed! For a starving group of 6, we were seated within minutes (around 4PM on a Wednesday) and decided to get two of their most popular deep dishes, the Chicago Classic and the Lou. I will warn you, the large is LARGE. We had originally ordered both of those pizzas in a Large but after taking a look at the neighboring table's humongous pizza, we decided to change the Lou to a medium. In hindsight, we should've just ordered both as a medium but the leftovers do make a good midnight snack.  They warned us that it takes about 45 minutes to make; big SIGH as we were so hungry after our long flight, but it is well worth the wait! The crust that they use is delicious and has a sweet flavor to it and both the pizzas hit the spot, but after eating just 1 slice of the Chicago Classic, I couldn't finish the second Lou slice. Definitely would recommend the pizza here and was one of the best meals I had in Chicago!

Deep dish pizza was on my mind before I even hopped on the plane from Vegas to Chicago. Just like in New York, Chicago is no exception when it comes to pizza joints battling out to claim themselves as the best pizzeria for deep dish. Fortunately, based on the helpful suggestions of several locals, my friends and I chose Lou Malnati's as our culinary introduction to Chicago.  We came here on a Sunday evening when the pizzeria was bustling, and we placed an order in advance for "The Malnati Chicago Classic." A half-hour later, we were seated upstairs in a windowless dining room along with 30 or so other diners. It's not the best ambiance, but the service and the food make up for it. I was expecting our pizza to be ready by the time we were seated, but we had to wait an additional 20-25 minutes -- what was the point of placing an order? To prevent ourselves from becoming hangry, we requested a few appetizers.  Caesar Salad with Chicken: Tomatoes on a Caesar Salad? Odd, but judgments aside, this was a good salad to start off dinner.  Calamari Fritti: Fried deliciousness, and not at all chewy! It was a hit at our table.  The Malnati Chicago Classic: Worth the wait! The sauce was perfect and didn't have that prominent acidic flavor. Not being a fan of sausage toppings on my pizza, I digged the sausage on ours. The cheese was nice and stringy, and the garlic Buttercrust was perfect and not hard to bite into.   Service: As busy as the evening was, our server did an awesome job.  Overall: Having been a first-time visitor to Chicago, Lou Malnati's made a lasting impression. From a tourist's perspective, it's definitely a pizzeria that I'd recommend to others who are staying within the area. You can't go wrong.

First thing they tell you before you order is that their pizza's take 40 minutes to make.  If you're going to beat the busy times and get there early, call ahead and say that you'll be there soon and that you'd like to place your order.  We arrived and got our food about 20 minutes before everyone else in our section who got seated the same time we did. Got the Classic, which says it has extra cheese but omg was it a lot of cheese.  Another reviewer said it best, the first few bites were great, but after awhile the cheese cools down and becomes kinda rubbery.  Combine that with a thin layer of sauce and a slightly-still-doughy bottom crust, and eating became more of a chore.  The outer crust was buttery and good enough to eat. Had been here a couple years ago, forgot which pizza I had, but I remember it was a much better experience taste-wise, so was excited to go back.  Sad, was expecting a 4-star experience.

One of the best deep dish in Chicago. We got there being told we had an hour and a half wait, and decided we'd drink while waiting. Exactly hour and a half later, we got our table and the waiter, Greg, so rudely asked what we wanted to drink. When we told him we had our tab open at the bar he told us 'you can't do that. you have to close that and order from me.' I knew then, as a former waitress/bartender, he clearly knew he would be missing out on tip so he said that. Complete asshole. This was the icing on the cake: when our friend went up to get drinks from his tab, he saw us bring them to the table and said I need to see your I.d. So my husband, being  deployed next week, should him his military i.d. and he said we don't allow military I.d. Are you kidding me?  Long story short, Greg should be fired. Service was awful.

EXCELLENT DEEP DISH! The setup was somewhat awkward when we walked in. It was a busy Friday night so we had to give our name to the hostess (who was not clearly identified) and then place our order at the counter before being seated. I realize this is necessary because deep dish pizza takes a while to cook and it's pointless to hold up a table with a long wait time. I just wish the system was directed better. We were seated within 40 minutes and served our pizza within 15 minutes of being seated. This place is touristy, but it's so yummy and a must when in Chicago! Order a small sausage deep dish for 2, but if VERY hungry order a medium! Great spot!

If you never had deep dish pizza, this is the spot to come to for authentic Chicago pizza.  The wait time can be long, average 1-2hrs, but it is worth it for a taste of Chicago!  During your wait time, take a look at their menu and place your pizza order as soon as you can, well before you think you will be seated.  The pizza takes 30 minutes to make, so they will time it such that right when you get a table your pizza will be almost ready.  At this point you will be starving from waiting over an hour and looking at everyone else eating delicious pies. The 4 of us ordered a large and split half and half between the Lou and Chicago Classic.  The pizza came out piping hot and oozing with cheese and sauce.  I personally liked the Lou more than the Classic, because it is veggie based.  he classic sausage was too thick and tasted funky to me, too porky flavored.   They really load on the toppings, cheese, more cheese, and sauce.  The sauce is actually really tasty.  If you like cheese and sauce, you will love deep dish!  I am not a huge fan of the thick crust, but i did like the edge crust for its crispiness.  The thick crust does help to absorb all the flavor, sauce, and cheese, but you get filled up quick.  This pizza is hearty and requires the use of fork and knife to eat!  And large is was more than enough for 4 of us.   There's only one way to do Chicago right, have a deep dish at Lou's before you go, there's nothing else as comforting and satisfying.
Best of the deep dish so far Love the Chicago special with the butter crust!

Deep dish pizza is one of those things you HAVE to try when you're in Chicago! I heard this is the best deep dish place in the city so we decided to try it! My husband and I came here for lunch and got super lucky by getting seated right away!! Literally 5 minutes after we got seated, a crazyyy rush of people came in and their wait time was about 45 min to an hour. We shared a small Malnati's Chicago Classic pizza which comes with lean sausage, tomatoes and cheese. We also added garlic for an additional charge.  It takes about 30-40 minutes for them to make your pizza since each one is made fresh. I can't imagine having to wait that long to get seated, and then waiting that long AGAIN for your food. Geez, I'd be HANGRY! I think they might have some option to pre-order your pizza though? This is definitely a fork and knife kind of pizza. My husband really enjoyed the pizza (he is a total pizza fan) but I, on the other hand didn't really like it too much. The cheese, once 10 minutes or so passed, had a super rubbery texture and it was hard to chew. The crust/dough was also not good at all! Way too hard and flavorless. The pizza is also VERY filling since it's so thick. The small is definitely more than enough for 2 people to share. Overall, this pizza was just A-OK in my opinion. Not something I would crave or want again, but you have to try it at least once if you're in Chicago!

This was my second visit to this location. There was a wait this Thursday night, so we saddled up to the intimate bar & asked a local ( always a good sign;) to scoot down one seat, which he did & we proceeded to get our pizza on.  It's worth nothing that although the Yankee Baseball legend passed some 40 odd years ago, this restaurant (& the other 3 locations) remain family owned and operated  & it shows. This pizza really is an excellent version of Chicago style deep dish pizza. We ordered the Classic-sausage & cheese pizza with a 312 Pale Ale & also the Wheat beer. My preference was the ale, my friend preferred the wheat, BUT we both loved the pizza! If you want an authentic Chicago deep dish experience, you won't go wrong here.

Really wanted to try deep dish pizza, kind of disappointed actually. It's definitely a touristy thing, I prefer regular pizza any day. It was good, not great. The wait took forever, closer to an hour than 35 minutes that they said.....nice and friendly staff.

On my first trip to Chicago, Lou Malnati's was at the top of my list of restaurants to try. I love deep-dish pizzas and the hype behind Lou Malnati's is incredible. After a long one hour wait, I'd have to say that Lou Malnati's is... just okay. I've had numerous deep dish pizzas in California and honestly, I don't really see the big deal with Lou Malnati's. I can name a few in California that are far superior in taste and quality (Little Star Pizza or Zachary's in the Bay Area; Masa of Echo Park in LA) -- Lou Malnati's "butter" crust actually tasted pretty bland to me. I'm not saying it was bad by any means -- I did enjoy the pizzas (got both styles), but they just weren't memorable, especially for Chicago being the deep-dish capital of the world.
Best deep dish period. The service was great and everthing we had from the Malnati Salad to the spinach bread to the Malnati special pizza to the choclate chip cookie deep dish were all excellent.

First timer to this or any other LM pizza place. Went on a Sunday night around 5:00 and the wait was about 45 minutes. Not as bad as we expected for a party of 6.  Had a beer while waiting and would have had more , but the bartender was too preoccupied with a couple of young ladies who got all his attention, hence 4 stars instead of 5. Can't blame him I guess.......hmmmmm, serve cuties sharing a tiny pizza at the bar , or a 50 something ordinary guy with a wad of cash and party of 6 thirsty and hungry people.  Just Sayin!!! Once seated, Matt was our server and helped make our LM experience a great one.  Don't lose this guy, he's worth the extra tip for doing his job and seemingly enjoying it and we appreciated it.  The rest of the staff seemed great too. Now , the pizza..........got 2 of the large classics for 6 people and took 1/2 of one home.  Great pizza from crust to sauce. Fresh, cheesy, great sausage and buttery crust just as advertised. We are pretty much thin crust pizza eaters, but when in Rome............ This pizza was worth the trip and the short wait, and compared to eating out in other restaurants in the city ,it is IMO one of Chicago's best bang for the buck experiences. Just do it if you haven't already.  It's a great Chicago experience. Earlier is better as far as wait time, but they really do a great job. Thanks again Matt!!! Slammer!!!

One of the worst pick up setups in River north. Hostesses forget you are there. Do not acknowledge you even when this business is slow.Front desk will only help you if you are obnoxious.People frequently cut in line at the front desk.To top the whole experience off food is not ready when you call 45 minutes before to pickup.They try and get you to pay so you can wait for food you previously ordered. Really inconvenient if you are on your lunch break. This is in correlation to numerous visits.  I am completely done with this place.Do not go here unless you have an hour to kill even if you order your food beforehand.

Lou Malnati's has the potential to be good, but the River North location did not impresss. After hearing of the place from multiple friends, we decided to try Lou's to see what the buzz was about.  Wait time wasn't bad, but this may have had to do with the holiday and coming earlier in the evening (around 6pm). To be honest, I'm not sure what to think of the interior and decor -- not sure if they are going for old school italian, sports bar or dirty. Having lived in NYC, we decided to try both the deep dish and the thin crust. The deep dish was NOT worth the 45 minute wait -- I'm not sure if the pizza had sat out for a while, but it tasted like they had baked the crust, sauce and cheese separately. Although fresh, the pizza looked like it came out of a refrigerator.  The thin crust was actually much better, but not really what we had come for. Be sure to add meat / veggies to give it some flavor! Overall, forgetful experience, will continue to search this city for some good deep dish!

I found this place while searching for Chicago deep dish pizza. We arrived just after 7 pm and were seated immediately. We were able to quickly place the order for a Classic pizza (which takes about 30-40 min to bake). We also ordered a house salad, which the waiter made sure would be big enough for two to share. It was my first time eating a Chicago style deep dish pizza. It seemed more like a pie to me, rather than a pizza, but was very tasty nonetheless (especially the buttery crust). The salad was also nice. The service was very quick and the waiter was very friendly. When he arrived with the check he realized that he had forgotten to charge for the salad, but told us it was on the house. We gave a very generous tip. Overall a good pizza experience with good service.

Because it seemed like one of the most authentic pies, I tried The Malnati Chicago Classic. With a menu description of "Made with Lou's lean sausage, some extra cheese and vine-ripened tomato sauce on Buttercrust. It's authentic Chicago!" I felt like that was exactly what I was looking for. The Buttercrust was wonderful. Every pizza should be on some type of buttery crust. Actually, I've decided everything should include butter. It brings happiness. Wu Tang and butter are for the children! The sauce was also delicious. It had a spicy element to it, but the primary aspect was a deep, robust tomato - exactly what you want from a great tomato sauce. My only problem with my Malnati Chicago Classic was the sausage. You have the option of getting the sausage crumbled (common with most sausage on pizza) or a sausage patty on the pizza. I decided to try the sausage patty, and it ended up being my only mistake with this meal. For whatever reason, the texture wasn't nearly as good on the sausage as it typically is when you get sausage crumbled on a pizza. This was only thing that keep my pizza from being the complete package. There's a reason Lou Malnati's has been successful in Chicago for the past 40 years. The sauce and crust are always the key to making any great pizza, and Lou's has both of these covered.
Decent but over rated.  Loooooong wait, at least 30 minutes, our medium took 50 minutes.... Painful.

I've eaten deep dish before in California when I was little, but I wanted to try the real deal in the windy city.  So we came to check this place out on a Monday for lunch. It was packed with tourists and locals, which I guess was a good sign.  We could pre-order our pizzas at the counter while waiting for our table, and that greatly reduced the wait time once we were seated.  Brilliant!   They also had an interesting concept here where they'll send you a text message when your table is ready, instead of handing out pagers.  I've never seen that before. My bf recommended getting the lunch special with a small personal deep dish pizza, a side salad or cup of soup, and a drink for under $10. When we sat down, we told our server we were both getting the lunch specials, but apparently the pre-order ticket didn't reflect that (even though we had told the woman at the counter).  But it wasn't an issue and our server was able to change the order immediately.   I got the cheese and sausage pizza with minestrone soup and pink lemonade.  I liked how the soup was chock full of meat and veggies, but I wouldn't say that the taste totally blew me away.  The lemonade was nice and refreshing. When our pizzas came out, I was a bit disappointed by the little disc on my plate.  I had imagined a large pie, immensely thick and piled high with dense toppings.  However, I guess my vision wasn't really realistic with a mini personal pizza.  :/ Well, that "little disc" turned out to be quite delicious!  I loved their signature Buttercrust™--so buttery and tasty!!  That was probably the most delicious crust I've ever eaten in my life.  And the sausage was a gigantic layer that covered the entire surface of my pizza--not little chunks sprinkled throughout. The meal was actually the perfect amount of food, so I'm glad we got the lunch special.  Plus, this restaurant had a sports theme with memorabilia decorating the walls, and our booth had Magic Johnson's jersey framed above us.  It's like that spot was meant just for me--L.A. girl!  Go Lakers!  Haha.  The perfect setting for some yummy food.  :)
Pizza was pretty good but waiting for a hour and half to receive pizza made it not worth it. Would not go back I have ate at other pizza places in town with same quality pizza with less wait time.

This was our first real deep dish pizza experience. We had the stuffed spinach bread - chewy and cheesy, the "Lou" and the Malnati Chicago Classic™. Overall, the bread was awesome but the pizza was OK. I was not a fan with the crust (very hard) and preferred the New York style thin crust. Later, I found out that you were not supposed to order the personal size.  Staff were very nice. Since we came during the off-peak, we were able to be seated very quickly.

Deep Dish Mecca! Love that they have the personal pizza in deep dish and love the bruschetta. Oh and the butter crust is like no other. The half and half pizza option is great - it's not available in the personal pizza's, but I think it's available in the bigger sizes. Be prepared to wait an hour or sometimes even more  - there's a beeline of people out there waiting to get their claws on some Lou Malnati's deep dish! Is the wait worth it? YES!

There is a big difference between New York pizza and Chicago pizza.  Being a New Yorker, a pizza is a to go food, something you fold, thin crust, good proportion of tomato sauce and cheese.  So when I had to try a deep dish, I wanted to try one of the best and this comes highly recommended.  My friend and I called ahead to see how long the wait was, which was 45 mins, we decided to just order take out and eat it at the Navy Pier.  (Shouldn't there be a rule, we don't have to wait for pizza? Just saying!). Upon arriving, the line was out the door for a table.  There method of trying to control the length you sit, order your pizza while you wait for the table and pay at the counter.  It takes a long time to cook these massive pizzas and thankfully we ordered out and called ahead.  The pizza came in a convenient box, and we shared a tiny 6 inch pizza.  The pizza didn't make it to navy pier... I wanted to just eat it now!  Excuse me cab driver, do you mind if I eat this in your backseat?  It was tasty.  Thick crust with tons of cheese in every bite.  The sauce wasn't the greatest but I can see the attraction.  The pizza is good but I like my thin crust.  If I had to wait for a table, I would've been upset.  Wish the sauce was more flavorful and the cheese wasn't so overwhelming.  And there you have it, my first experience of deep dish pizza was in the back seat of a cab... And I don't regret that choice at all.

Great service, helped us out of towners decide which quintessential Chicago pizza to order and had it ready for us when we picked it up. Pizza was delicious, though heavy. Not the type of pizza I could eat every other weekend but was definitely a must try when visiting Chicago.

I thought I had died and gone to heaven. The Chicago Classic with the butter crust was the best pizza I have ever had. Period. No wonder they ship all over the country. I am def going to try this service as now I cannot live without it. The sauce is not too sweet and not overly saucy. Also the amount of cheese was just right. I do not like too much cheese on my pizza. We did try Giordanos' and yes, that was good too but it's the Lou's BUTTER CRUST that has me wanting more. We started off with the spinach and strawberry salad to get some "greens" in before the slice. Yes, very fresh and flavorful. We all only had one slice as it is filling.  We had some left over to take back to our condo in Chicago and it was in the fridge for a day and one of our friends who had just come back from Giordanos' said the same thing that Lou's is better. It's the crust.......You can also get their wonderful pizza on  goldbely.com  or directly on their website and they will ship.   Service was spot on and friendly.

This was the best pizza by far that we have ever had. Not only was the pizza outstanding, the house salad was amazing. It was fresh romaine accompanied by olives, tomatoes, bacon bits, a light dusting of feta (I'm not usually a feta fan but this was delicious) and a house made Italian dressing to die for. All ingredients were perfectly cut to give you a little bit of each in every bite. The service was great too. We went on a Wednesday night and waited exactly 35 minutes which they told us was our estimated wait time. They text us when our table was ready and had us put in a pre-order for our pizza to get it cookin. They've got a good system down.  We had a beer from the bar as we waited for our table. That was no wait at all even though the place was packed. Very friendly staff. We will be headed back here for sure the next time we visit Chicago.

The one time that I tried this place while staying in Chicago, I personally liked their pies a lot. Having grown up on NY style pizza, it took a bit of a mental adjustment to accept this. The way I got around this psychological block was by not thinking about this as pizza. Instead, think of it as what it is: a savory pie. My wife (a true New Yorker) had trouble making this adjustment, so she wasn't super amused by this Chicago treat. I, on the other hand, found it quite delicious, although the crust was definitely a bit too hard. What I've been told by a couple of Chicago buddies is that when you order the personal sized pizza, the crust tends to be a bit more firm. I was able to confirm this at two other places after this one, where we got the sharing-sized pizzas. I must also mention the stuffed bread appetizer. It was good in so many ways. Packed and oozing with delicious cheese and spinach, surrounded by a buttery crust...I could come back here just for this.
Came for the deep dish and very much enjoyed the Classic and the Lou.  The Malanari salad was delicious too.  Great experience.

If you're going to Chicago, you're going to Lou Malnati's. Got it? Good. Oh, you don't want to wait in line for 2 hours? I don't care. You're still going. Got it? Good.  This pizza is probably the only restaurant in the world that I could wait 2 hours for and have no qualms. It's that good.  We went on a Monday night around 8, expecting there wouldn't be that much of a wait on a Monday so late. Boy were we wrong. The hostess said there would be an hour wait, but we could order it to go and have the food within 30 minutes. We went with this offer originally, but once we realized how cold it was outside, we decided to ask to hostess to put us on the wait for a table. About 30 minutes we, we decided to check in to see how much longer the wait with. Apparently there was a mix up and our name was taken off the list completely. They said they would solve it and get us a table soon. About 30 minutes later, we asked about for the approximate wait. They had never solved the issue.  However, at this point, they brought the manager out who apologized profusely. He immediately bumped us to the top of the list, cleared a table for us personally and sat us. As I've said before, making mistakes always happens. It's how management handles it after that defines superior customer service. I was very impressed.  Because of all the mix up, we did have to wait another 45 minutes for our pizza, but it was totally worth it. Deep. Rich. Heavy. Flavorful. Everything good.  I think it goes to show that despite waiting two hours, it was so good I still had to give it 5 stars. I will definitely be visiting next time I'm in town.

I've dreamed for YEARS about what my first Chicago deep dish was going to be like. After carefully browsing through yelp, I narrowed it down to Lou Malnati's. The pictures looked fantastic, reviews were good, I had a friend confirm its authenticity - I was sold. But when the pies came out... I prepared myself for disappointment... which was confirmed after taking my first bite: 1) It was not as thick as I had expected - thus, lacking in the sauce and cheese department 2) Their famous "buttercrust" was actually pretty bad... I remember I just picked off the top and discarded the crust Now, you might think I just don't like deep dish pizza. It's actually the exact opposite. I wanted to like deep dish pizza SO MUCH I gave it a second chance after this first failure. And thank god I did, because Giordano's deep dish was the best way to end my weekend in Chicago. It was exactly as I expected, the sauce was tastier, meats were better, and I actually ate the crust hah. I want to add that maybe I had a poor experience because I was brought upstairs to a weird/shady area of the restaurant instead of in the main area. There was also a separate kitchen catering to the top floor. 2 of my friends found weird stuff in their soda too... So maybe just avoid going upstairs at Lou's.
Amazing pizza. Great service at the bar (had a young male bartender, wish I could remember his name!) Will be back!

Everything I wanted from my first deep dish experience in Chicago. As expected, they were slammed when we arrived at 5:30 on a Friday, yet the staff was very courteous and prompt.  Admittedly I don't have any other deep dish pizza experiences to compare it to, but we thought the pizza was excellent.

deep dish pizza is chicago signature,  so i felt like its a must to have it before you leave.  this is my first time here for deep dish pizza.  crazy line,  tons of people waiting.  you can grab a drink while waiting to be seated.  service is good/energetic.  please expect to wait 45 min.  i ordered the lous and the classic,  pretty mich what everyone recommended.  im sorry to say,  it was not what i expected,  not juicy,  nothing special with the cheese and sauage. it is just a different shape of pizza.  crust is just okay.  overall,  deep dish pizza does not worth 45 - 60minutes wait PLEASE NOTE: when you leave you name and phone number,  make sure to let him know if you want to be text or call out your name when table is ready.

I wouldn't be a good New Yorker if I didn't make a snarky comment about deep dish not being real pizza.  With that said, of the purveyors of the Chicago style crust-tomato sauce-cheese-toppings casserole-like concoction, Lou Malnati's is among the best.  The place was kind of a zoo when I went most recently (on a Wednesday night!), but after waiting around a bit I was able to get a seat at the bar.  The bartenders were friendly and quick to deliver a beer, both things I appreciate.  Since I was traveling for work, I was dining solo, so I really appreciated that (unlike the other places I've tried) Lou Malnati's offers an individual size pizza, so I didn't have to order the "small" that was really intended for a small army.  My Chicago Classic with sausage and mushrooms was delicious (I only wish I has added green peppers or spinach) and the prices were very reasonable.  Definitely recommend.

Whoa! This is some AWESOME deep dish pizza with just the right amount of juicy grease. This isn't your typical Pizza Hut grease...it's delicious grease.  Our party of 6 arrived here at about 6:30pm on a Monday evening. We were seated within 10 minutes and the service was great. Our waitress was super friendly and attentive; although she forgot an iced tea and we were still charged for it (no, we didn't think it was worth getting grumpy about because she was otherwise very sweet and accommodating).  Our table had the calamari, cheese bread, lasagna w/ meat sauce, spaghetti with meatballs & meat sauce, a chicken Caesar salad and the 'Lou' pizza. The cheese bread was tasty (not anything that blew my mind), but the PIZZA is where it was at. Hubs and I still hadn't had Chicago deep-dish since moving here a few months ago, so we were happy that this was our first D.D.+ experience.  4 of us shared a large 'Lou' and hubs and I still took home 2 pieces. I've never too proud to take home leftovers and this place was no different. I was thrilled to walk out with leftovers.  Desserts sounded delicious, but we were too stuffed to try anything. 4/5 because beers, mixed drinks and the entrees took forever to receive. We waited well over 45 minutes (closer to an hour) for the salad, pastas and pizza. We were here for 3 hours, so this isn't a place I'd recommend if you want to get in and out quickly.  We visited this location because we had family staying at The Thompson just a few blocks away. Hubs and I live in the NW 'burbs, so we'll stick around our area the next time we want Lou Malnati's.

Very crowded for a random Tuesday night, but everyone raves about it so we had to try it.  We started with the bruschetta which was light and refreshing with clean flavors and fresh ingredients.  Then I had the Malnati's Classic Deep Dish Pizza. The sauce was very bright in flavor and the crust was perfect.  I ate the entire dish myself and, although I was VERY full, I never got that super heavy feeling afterwards.  I think that's a testament to the freshness of the ingredients.

Lou's is my favorite place for pizza in Chicago so far. I think it's a step better than Giordano's and Due.  I can't comment on the service and decor as I have only had it delivered. My favorite is the thin crust pizza (which is still considerably thicker than the St. Louis-style pizzas I normally eat at home). The corm meal crust is just the best. I haven't tried much more of their menu as the pizza in Chicago fills me up all by itself.

Maybe I am just not a Chicago Deep Dish type of guy.  The service was very good, but I don't think the wait is worth it.  We checked in about 7:55 on a Tuesday for a party of 5.  We were seated at ~9:20.  At least we could order the pizza in advance so it was served not too long after we were seated.  Perfectly time after we finished our salad.  I will say I LOVED their Malnati's Salad as did everyone elese in our group.  I had Gino's East during my last visit and I may prefer their Pizza but that is a personal choice and not due to something Lou's did.  I think next time I want pizza in Chicago I am going to try some thin crust Chicago Pizza.  Lou's has a nice crust and can taste the butter.  The sauce is nicely balanced.  They put one big covering of sausage instead of chuncks/crumbles.

I like Lou Malnati's. It's not my favorite Chicago deep dish-- the crust is too thin, the crushed tomatoes are too simple and unseasoned (rather than an actual sauce), and the cheese never seems as stringy as, for example, Uno's. The atmosphere of this place, though, is great-- with all the sports memorabilia around and the TVs to keep up on Chicago games. And the staff is fun, and super friendly. What's not to like about that?

Visited the restaurant with the family since we were near Michigan Ave.  Food is so so.  Don't get what so special about  "The Malnati Chicago Classic". It's just a pizza.  It was SO LOUD!!! in the restaurant too.  And we waited about 1 hour for it  (though we toured the area while waiting).  The only re-deeming part was the local craft beer I tasted that was unique.

Second best deep dish in Chicago but accessible (second to Uno / Due which are hard to get into).  Can't go wrong with this.  If for delivery, consider picking up if it's a long wait - an easy solution and they have quite a few locations. Malnati's salad is great and pick your toppings.  Go with crumbled sausage over the sausage patty. Otherwise like I said, a can't miss meal.

My first deep dish pizza and first time in Chicago and I couldn't be more pleased. The crust was crunchy and soft. The pizza....oooohhh so cheesy! Thank you for an amazing experience for my first stop in Chicago!!

OMG this place is always so busy. From what I'm feeling is 24x365/366. Pizza is nice all flavors and all toppings. Service is good and if you wanna skip the lines just order online and enjoy the tummies at hotels or home with friends and families!

I mean... I guess I don't get it. It's fine? The crust is pretty yummy? But we paid like $43 for a pizza after tip and I just simply don't think it's worth it. But maybe I'm missing something. (It also took over an hour. Not awesome.)

Lou Malnati's is not just the Best Deep Dish Pizza but the Best Pizza Period. And that is coming from a New Yorker. I had been to Chicago countless times and I had gone to Giordano's, Gino's East and the rest, but it wasn't until I walked into Lou's on North Wells that I had found my Pizza Mecca. Now I cannot go to Chicago without stopping by and enjoying a pie and I am obligated to bring home a half baked, dare I risk the wrath of my family.  The Butter Crust, The Sauce, sausage and cheese....understand I'm salivating just writing this... is utter perfection. Can we get a LM's in Cary?

Lou Malnati's Pizza is as authentic as you can get. We shut down the venue and had our pick of pizza slices and cookies. I tried genuine cheese and veggie and both were stunning, giving NY a run for its money. I will be back and next time I'm in Chicago will definitely recommend my friends to see this fine establishment upon seeing Chicago.

We culminated our exploration of the Magnificent Mile with a trip to Lou Malnati's Pizzeria...unfortunately we got caught in crazy unexpected Chicago rainstorm so instead of arriving for an early dinner, we arrived right at the peak of dinner time. That. Kinda. Stunk. We were hit with a wait over an hour, but luckily Lou Malnati's is fairly aware of its ability to accommodate guests - definitely put your order in beforehand. They time it to come out shortly after you sit - genius! We ordered the Chicago classic deep dish and also tried a thin crust variety. And to give some semblance of healthiness, we added a family sized spinach salad. The salad was delicious, it was light but the creaminess of the goat cheese definitely paired well with the more sweet strawberries they used as their fruit. The onions also added that sweet crunch. The Chicago classic deep dish was to die for. It had the perfect ratio of ultra gooey cheese to meat ratio. And I love that the sausage wasn't little pieces strewn randomly about...it was a 1/4" sausage patty enveloping the entire pie. That's LOVE.
